The ghastly practice existed of cutting off the head of a fallen foe, which was brought up to the capital to swell the number of skulls in the public arenas of Kumasi, over which ill-informed writers have waxed eloquent."[237]

♠ Targeted massacre ♣ present ♥ "The regime which first came to power, however, was one headed by the powerful Akyempemhene of Kumase, Owusu Koko. A son of Asantehene Osei Tutu Kwame, he had been perhaps the most influential of all the councillors during the latter part of the reign of Kwaku Dua I. In mid-1883 he carried out a massacre of many of the leading supporters of Kofi Kakari, an event that led a number of Asante politicians to seek refuge in the Gold Coast Colony."[238]

♠ General massacre ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature. The sources mention mutilation and enslavement but no general massacres.

♠ Extermination ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature. The sources mention mutilation and enslavement but no massacres.

♠ Ethnocide ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature. The sources mention mutilation and enslavement but no massacres.


Archaeological proxies:

♠ Skeletal evidence of violence ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Mass burials ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Settlement destruction ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Pictorial evidence of warfare ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

List of Wars[edit]

Asante - Conquest of Northern region (1740-1742 CE)

Asante - Conquest of the Sefwi states (1740-1742 CE)

Asante - Conquest of Wankyi (1711-1712 CE)

Asante - Conquest of Takyiman (1722-1723 CE)

Asante - Conquest of Akyem states (1742 CE)

Asante - Fante War (1806-1807 CE)

Asante - Ga-Fante War (1811 CE)

Ashante - Akim-Akwapim War (1814-1816 CE)

Asante - War against the British (1823-1831 CE)

Asante - War against the British (1863-1864 CE)

Asante - War against the British (1873-1874 CE)

Asante - War against the British (1895 CE)

Asante - British Conquest (1900 CE)

Asante - General Uprising (1883 CE)

Asante - Civil War (1884-1888 CE)

Ritual variables[edit]

A collective ritual is a ritual in which two or more people participate. With the official cult we refer to the set of collective ritual practices that are most closely associated with legitimation of the power structure (including elites, if any).

♠ RA ♣ Daniel Mullins ♥

♠ Expert ♣ ♥

Largest scale collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Yam Festival ♥ Akan communities celebrated the annual yam harvest with a public festival. 'An annual custom is always held in connection with the first fruits of each staple crop such as yam. The general name for a festival is Afahyε (afa, “festival”; hyε, “fix a day”). The chief's and head priest's house and things are refurbished [Page 35] by singing old women, the blackened stools are taken to the stream and sprinkled with water; pieces of sacrificed and new food crops are put on each stool. The spirits are invoked to start the new year and make it a good one, the new year beginning at different times in different localities.' [239]//'The Akan annual yam festival, a purificatory ceremony lasting one-two weeks usually in September or October, is called Odwira, meaning “to purify/cleanse”. (It is sometimes also called apafram). It is similar to the Apo in that all disputes are settled, bringing harmony back to the town. The central part of the festival is the re-purification of the stools and the abosom shrines. It is a festival involving remembrance of the dead, harvest, and thanksgiving.' [240]//The Yam Festival is also known as Odwira Festival in the literature: 'The Odwira Festival is the most important yearly celebration among the Ashanti people. It is held in autumn, the time when new yams are ready. They cannot be eaten until the second day of the festival, when they are paraded through the streets. The whole festival lasts for five days is celebrated slightly differently in each community. Throughout the festival, music and drumming abound. On the first day the path leading towards the chief's burial is cleaned. On the second day priests make offerings at the burial chambers and a great yam parade takes place. On the third day people mourn and fast. On the fourth a splendid feast for everyone in the community is held at the local chief's house. That night, everyone stay indoors, to avoid catching sight of the chief's thrones, symbols of the dead men's spirits, which are carried to the river to be ceremonially washed. On the fifth and final day, chiefs and other important clan members dressed in their best, parade through the town in a grand procession to pay homage to the senior local chief. Some are carried shoulder high on litters and shaded with brilliantly coloured umbrellas. Then people play music and dance late into the night.'[241]//Warren provides a description of the relevant narratives and proceedings among the Techiman-Bono:'The other major annual Bono Festival is the Yam Festival ( henerεk dibayerefoforo: literally, the chief is going to eat new yams). The myth explaining the origin of the festival states that when the Techiman-Bono people came from the cavern at Amowi, Onyame pointed out forest yams (aha bayere). Seeing that bush pigs and elephants had eaten some of the yams, they cooked a few and saw that the yam was good food. They gave some to their chief, who also enjoyed it. After that, they began to celebrate on an annual basis the day on which they first found yams. After their chief died, they fed his soul (saman) yams on the same day. Later the Bono began to plant yams, and the yam became the most important staple in the Bono diet. Every farmer celebrates the festival to thank Onyame after the harvest. The living and the deceased are all invited to share in the abundance. Every Bono chief and priest celebrates a yam festival, but before the celebrations begin, a man from the village of Kenten whose title is Akokohwedeε (woodhen) first tastes the yam. When he sees that the yam is ripe, early in the morning on the traditional day called Fodwo he informs the god Taa Mεnsah that the yam is ready to be prepared for εto (mashed yams mixed with palmoil).' [242]//'The Taa Mεnsah deity celebrates his yam festival on Fodwo, a Monday. The new yam is hung from rafters in the shrine room for some weeks before the Akokohwedeε comes to taste it. After the yam is hung, children may begin to eat new yam and the elders can [Page 57] [Page 58] begin to eat aso bayere (one species of yam). In the evening on Fodwo, the god Taa Mεnsah is prepared to eat yam after being carried on the main street from one end of the town to the other end three times and consulted. After this, the god informs the manhene that he is about to eat yam and the manhene gives the god permission to eat the yam. The manhene sends a yam to the god and it is always this yam which is cooked as εto and placed on the shrine. The next day, Tuesday, the manhene sends a sheep and wine to the god.' [243]//'Two weeks after the Taa Mεnsah Yam Festival, the yam festivals for the Queenmother, the Adontenhene, and the Nifahene are celebrated on a Monofie, a Friday. Nwonakusie, a Thursday, is the yam festival day for the Twafohene, the Adaatihene, the Akyeamehene, the Konkontiwahene, and the Krontihene. Fofie, another Friday, is the yam festival day for the manhene, the Gyaasehene, the Ankbeahene, and the Barimhene. The manhene provides about six sheep and a cow for his own yam festival. These are sacrificed, the blood being spilled on the ancestral stools; the meat is cooked and distributed.' [244]//The ethnographic material availabe refers mostly to the Ashanti and colonial periods. We have assumed here that some variant of this festival was celebrated prior to Ashanti expansion as well. The below codes were imported from Atkinson's and Whitehouse's ritual database (see also GhAshnL for reference).
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ yearly ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database, this ritual occurs 'annually'[245].
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ yearly ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database, this ritual occurs 'annually'[246].
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ not applicable ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database, this ritual occurs 'annually'[247]. Thomas Cressy: The ritual description makes it clear this is a community ritual where the community members participate in the festivities and feasts etc, so I have changed this code from 'yearly' to 'not applicable'.
♠ Duration ♣ 120 ♥ hours. 'The whole festival lasts for five days is celebrated slightly differently in each community.'[248] However, according to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual database, this ritual is coded as '1 to 6 hours/ long'[249].
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 17,000 ♥ in absolute numbers. According to the Ritual Database, 'Most members of community (50%-90%)' are 'present'[250]. The largest community consists of approx. 22,500 people, meaning that this ritual may include some 17,000 people.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ elites ♥ adult male priesthood. According to the Ritual Database, 'Most members of community (50%-90%)' are 'present'[251].
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ According to the Ritual Database, 'Most members of community (50%-90%)' are 'present'[252].
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ not applicable ♥ According to the Ritual Database, 'Most members of community (50%-90%)' are 'present'[253]. Thomas Cressy: The ritual description makes it clear this is a community ritual where the community members participate in the festivities and feasts etc, so I have changed this code from 'whole polity' to 'not applicable'.
Dysphoric elements

♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Humiliation of participants' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'[258].
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Mention of disgust' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'[259].
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [260].
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent'[261]. The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database is 0, the lowest possible [262].
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent'[263].

Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ inferred present ♥ 'On the fifth and final day, chiefs and other important clan members dressed in their best parade through the town in a grand procession to pay homage to the senior local chief.'[275]
♠ oath taking ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Unclear. 'On the fifth and final day, chiefs and other important clan members dressed in their best parade through the town in a grand procession to pay homage to the senior local chief'[276]. The act of "paying homage" to the senior local chief may well have included oath taking, but the source does not say, and the Ritual Database does not capture this sort of information. However, it is worth noting that 'Narrative or story recounted' and 'Recitation of texts' are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database'[277].
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Unclear. 'On the fifth and final day, chiefs and other important clan members dressed in their best parade through the town in a grand procession to pay homage to the senior local chief'[278]. The act of "paying homage" to the senior local chief may well have included promises of support in war, but the source does not say, and the Ritual Database does not capture this sort of information.
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Unclear. The act of "paying homage" to the senior local chief may well have included promises of support in war, but the source does not say, and the Ritual Database does not capture this sort of information.
♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Unclear. The act of "paying homage" to the senior local chief may well have included promises of support to each other's families, but the source does not say, and the Ritual Database does not capture this sort of information.

♠ other ♣ ♥

Most widespread collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Apo Festival ♥ The Apo Festival was celebrated annually and included carnivalesque elements: 'Many festivals exist among the Akan; their foundations and functions are found in the traditional religion. The Apo festival is celebrated yearly among the Brong; it is a feast of eight days duration in which complete lampooning liberty (in the form of song) of both superiors and inferiors (without punishment) is given. The people explain that if one's sunsum is hurt, the body becomes ill; often ill health is caused by evil and the hatred another person may have for you. In like manner, if you have a hatred for someone, it affects your own sunsum, so this time is set aside to allow any man to tell any other man what has offended him. This frees the spirit, and both sunsum become relaxed. During this festival there is theoretical sexual license; this isn't really taken [Page 33] Scene at a Festival [Page 34] advantage of since traditional court action can be initiated after the eight day festival. Punishment is therefore deferred until the rites are over. Should an aggrieved party take action he forfeits the right to investigation, to satisfaction, and he is also heavily fined. During this period all the priests and priestesses of the area are present with their shrines; they touch each shrine with every other one to re-establish communications which might have been lost. The major gods are taken to the river and cleansed of all evil. On the eighth day everyone makes a concerted effort to drive all evil from the area. Around twenty-five distinct Apo songs are sung, and there is a specific Apo dance for the festival.' [291]//Purification is a major element in the rituals performed: 'The festival period is, in fact, a period of coming together in which the people from all over the Techiman traditional area, including well-wishers and invitees from other states, meet in the capital to display the traditional Bono culture through singing, dancing, and drumming. The manhene and his elders, through the Barimhene, purify the soul of King Ameyaw (the chief defeated by the Asante in 1723), adorn his grave with the royal regalia of the incumbent manhene, recall the deeds that Ameyaw performed for the State (man), and present drinks, sheep, and food to his soul and those of the other ancestral chiefs of the Techiman-Bono State. Finally, the Apo is a period during which the shrines of various gods and goddesses are purified. The shrine of the main deity in Techiman Township, Taa Kεse (Taa Mεnsah), is, at this time, purified at the River Agyentoamu during the last hour of the celebration; this serves as a sign of the completion of the Apo Festival.' [292]//The festival also served as a check on authority and as a forum for the resolution of mutual resentment: 'The functions of the Apo festival seem to be four: (1) psychological release, (2) a forum for public opinion, (3) a means to periodically check those in authority, (4) a method of enforcing sanctions of behaviour.' [293] According to Warren, the restoration of amicable relations is one of the major purposes of the festival: 'This festival allows every person resident in Techiman Traditional State, without regard to class, creed, ethnic group, or race, eleven days of liberty to lampoon, in the form of songs and proverbs, the faults and malpractices of any other person, including those in authority-especially the manhene and his divisional chiefs. In addition, the people may sing the praises of those in authority in appreciation of worthy achievements so as to encourage them to even greater deeds. During this period it is strictly forbidden to fight in any way. The emphasis of the festival is upon the removal of bitterness and misfortune in the State. After all personal grudges, faults, and hatreds are sung and spoken out amicably, the end result is renewed peace and harmony among the Techiman inhabitants; the spirit (sunsum) of the [Page 56] state is cleansed after all the unspoken interpersonal bitternesses are voiced.' [294]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ not applicable ♥ Source does not mention ritual specialists [295].
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ yearly ♥ 'Apo festival is celebrated yearly; it is a feast of eight days duration in which complete lampooning liberty (in the form of song) of both superiors and inferiors (without punishment) is given.' [296]
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ not applicable ♥ 'Apo festival is celebrated yearly; it is a feast of eight days duration in which complete lampooning liberty (in the form of song) of both superiors and inferiors (without punishment) is given.' [297] Thomas Cressy: Quote from the ritual database (see inclusive codes) makes it clear this is a community ritual where all or almost all of the community members participate in the ritual, it seems very likely people were taking no part and passively watching. so I have changed this code from 'yearly' to 'not applicable'.
♠ Duration ♣ 192 ♥ hours. 'Apo festival is celebrated yearly; it is a feast of eight days duration in which complete lampooning liberty (in the form of song) of both superiors and inferiors (without punishment) is given.' [298]
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 2,000,000 ♥ in absolute numbers. Ritual Database variable 'Members of other communities, tribal groups, towns' and participation from 'All or almost all members of community (>90%)' are marked as 'present' for ritual number 69, meaning that size of the participating group is at least the size of the community. If the population is approx. 3,000,000, I'm guessing that this this ritual may involve some 2,000,000 individuals.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ not applicable ♥ Source does not mention ritual specialists [299].
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Members of other communities, tribal groups, towns' and participation from 'All or almost all members of community (>90%)' are marked as 'present' for ritual number 69, meaning that size of the participating group is at least the size of the community. If the population is approx. 3,000,000, I'm guessing that this this ritual may involve some 2,000,000 individuals.
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ not applicable ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Members of other communities, tribal groups, towns' and participation from 'All or almost all members of community (>90%)' are marked as 'present' for ritual number 69, meaning that size of the participating group is at least the size of the community. If the population is approx. 3,000,000, I'm guessing that this this ritual may involve some 2,000,000 individuals. Thomas Cressy: Quote from the ritual database makes it clear this is a community ritual where all or almost all of the community members participate in the ritual, it seems very likely people were taking no part and passively watching. so I have changed this code from 'whole polity' to 'not applicable'.
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Fasting' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [300].
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ absent ♥ 'Sleep deprivation' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [301].
♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ 'Threats or actions that evince fear' and 'Dramatic acts evincing displays of emotion from participants (tears, laughter, rage, fear etc.)' are both coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [302].
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ 'Humiliation of participants' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [303].
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ 'Mention of disgust' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [304].
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [305].
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent'[306]. The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database is 1.67.
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent'[307].
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [308]. Also worth noting that the average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database is 1.67.
♠ other ♣ ♥
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'[309].

Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ present ♥ According to Warren, the restoration of amicable relations is one of the major purposes of the festival: 'This festival allows every person resident in Techiman Traditional State, without regard to class, creed, ethnic group, or race, eleven days of liberty to lampoon, in the form of songs and proverbs, the faults and malpractices of any other person, including those in authority-especially the manhene and his divisional chiefs. In addition, the people may sing the praises of those in authority in appreciation of worthy achievements so as to encourage them to even greater deeds. During this period it is strictly forbidden to fight in any way. The emphasis of the festival is upon the removal of bitterness and misfortune in the State. After all personal grudges, faults, and hatreds are sung and spoken out amicably, the end result is renewed peace and harmony among the Techiman inhabitants; the spirit (sunsum) of the [Page 56] state is cleansed after all the unspoken interpersonal bitternesses are voiced.' [319]
♠ oath taking ♣ absent ♥ 'Narrative or story recounted' and 'Recitation of texts' are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database'[320]. There is no mention of oath taking in the description provided by the source [321].

♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ present ♥ 'Personal grudges, faults, and hatreds talked about amicably' between families, as noted in the Ritual Database [324]. According to Warren, the restoration of amicable relations is one of the major purposes of the festival: 'This festival allows every person resident in Techiman Traditional State, without regard to class, creed, ethnic group, or race, eleven days of liberty to lampoon, in the form of songs and proverbs, the faults and malpractices of any other person, including those in authority-especially the manhene and his divisional chiefs. In addition, the people may sing the praises of those in authority in appreciation of worthy achievements so as to encourage them to even greater deeds. During this period it is strictly forbidden to fight in any way. The emphasis of the festival is upon the removal of bitterness and misfortune in the State. After all personal grudges, faults, and hatreds are sung and spoken out amicably, the end result is renewed peace and harmony among the Techiman inhabitants; the spirit (sunsum) of the [Page 56] state is cleansed after all the unspoken interpersonal bitternesses are voiced.' [325]

♠ other ♣ ♥

Most frequent collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Monocot Ceremony ♥ The Monocot Ceremony was celebrated monthly and involved libations to ancestral stools: 'The Monocot ceremony occurs every forty-two days involving libations to ancestral stools. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance. At the last Monokuo for the year, the manhene pours a libation on the god. On all other occasions during the year they only go to greet the god and then return to their houses.' [335][336]//'Although the Yam and Apo festivals are annual, the Bono celebrate the Monokuo ceremony every forty-two days, on the Wednesday called Monokuo. During the Monokuo, early in the morning, the manhene pours a libation on his ancestral stools. After that, the elders come to join him and they all go to the palace for the Taa Mεnsah shrine to say good morning to him. At the last Monokuo for the year, the manhene pours a libation on the god. Otherwise, they only go to greet the god and then return to their houses. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance.' [337]//Warren also reports other ceremonies that were celebrated on a monthly basis, although the specific example used seems to be distinct from Monocot: 'The most important festival dealing with “the propitiation, solicitation, or worship of ancestral spirits is the Adae” (Rattray, 1923:92). Adae means “place for rest” or “lying down”; no work is done on these days when the living recall the deeds of the deceased and solicit them for mercy and favours. The blood of sacrificed sheep is smeared by hand on the ancestral stools (human blood is never spilled on shrines); a libation is poured on each stool. The offering, excluding the omentum, is removed in the evening by the stool-carriers. Everyone entering the stool room removes his shoes, and bares his shoulders as a sign of humbleness before the superior spirits. Many ceremonies such as this Adae follow a forty-two day cycle. The details vary from area to area; the Brong propitiate both the Samanfo and the bosom at the Adae while the Ashanti only propitiate the Samanfo. The day proceding any Adae is called dapaa, “good/lucky day”; this is a day of preparation and work, everything being scrubbed.' [338]//The ethnographic material available refers mostly to the Ashanti and colonial periods. We have assumed here that some variant of this festival was celebrated prior to Ashanti expansion as well. The below codes were imported from Atkinson's and Whitehouse's ritual database (see also GhAshnL for reference).
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ monthly ♥ The Monocot ceremony occurs every forty-two days involving libations to ancestral stools. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance.[339][340]
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ monthly ♥ The Monocot ceremony occurs every forty-two days involving libations to ancestral stools. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance.[341][342]
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ monthly ♥ The Monocot ceremony occurs every forty-two days involving libations to ancestral stools. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance.[343][344]
♠ Duration ♣ 3 ♥ hours. The Ritual Database has coded the ritual duration as 1-6 hours.
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ suspected unknown ♥ in absolute numbers
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ elites ♥ The Monocot ceremony occurs every forty-two days involving libations to ancestral stools. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance.[345][346] 'Some members of community (<50% where that is more than 15 persons)' is coded as present in the Ritual Database[347][348]
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ suspected unknown ♥
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Fasting' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[349][350]
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ absent ♥ 'Sleep deprivation' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[351][352]
♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ 'Threats or actions that evince fear' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[353]. 'Dramatic acts evincing displays of emotion from participants (tears, laughter, rage, fear etc.)' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[354].
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ 'Humiliation of participants' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[355]
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ 'Mention of disgust' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[356]
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[357]. 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[358]
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula', 'Foul or unpleasant sensations (heat, stinging), tastes or smells', 'Vomiting', 'Swallowing of undigestable objects (swords, stones)', 'Patient's body is sucked', and 'Other uncomfortable experiences' are all coded 'absent' in the Ritual Database[359]
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula', 'Foul or unpleasant sensations (heat, stinging), tastes or smells', 'Vomiting', 'Swallowing of undigestable objects (swords, stones)', 'Patient's body is sucked', and 'Other uncomfortable experiences' are all coded 'absent' in the Ritual Database[360]
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula', 'Foul or unpleasant sensations (heat, stinging), tastes or smells', 'Vomiting', 'Swallowing of undigestable objects (swords, stones)', 'Patient's body is sucked', and 'Other uncomfortable experiences' are all coded 'absent' in the Ritual Database[361]
♠ other ♣ absent ♥ List the other(s) 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula', 'Foul or unpleasant sensations (heat, stinging), tastes or smells', 'Vomiting', 'Swallowing of undigestable objects (swords, stones)', 'Patient's body is sucked', and 'Other uncomfortable experiences' are all coded 'absent' in the Ritual Database[362]
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[363]
♠ alcohol ♣ present ♥ 'Intake of alcohol' is coded as present in the Ritual Database[364] The Monocot ceremony occurs every forty-two days involving libations to ancestral stools. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance.[365][366]
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ absent ♥ 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[367].
♠ sex ♣ absent ♥ 'Sexual intercourse' is coded 'absent' in the Ritual Database[368]
♠ dancing ♣ present ♥ 'Dancing or repetitive rhythmic movement' is coded as present in the Ritual Database[369]
♠ synchronous movement ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. dancing or marching in unison) 'Marching/ procession/ Proambulation' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[370]
♠ singing ♣ present ♥ 'Singing and (repetitive) rhythmic vocalization' is coded as present in the Ritual Database[371]
♠ entertainment ♣ present ♥ Drums. The Monocot ceremony occurs every forty-two days involving libations to ancestral stools. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance.[372][373]

The Akan of Ghana: an overview of the ethnographic literature, 33-35; Ritual Database</ref>[374]. However, this does not seem to be sufficient to code this variable as 'absent'[375].
♠ oath taking ♣ absent ♥ 'Speechmaking' and 'Recitation of texts' are coded as absent in the Ritual Databaseref>Warren, Dennis M. The Akan of Ghana: an overview of the ethnographic literature, 33-35; Ritual Database</ref>[376]

♠ other ♣ ♥ List the other(s)
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ inferred absent ♥ No orthodoxy checks are mentioned by the source. 'Distribution of ritual exegesis' is coded as 'Known by all competent participants (1)' [i.e., elders and chiefs] in the Ritual Database[377][378], but the fact that only elders/chiefs participated, this suggests that there were no significant orthodoxy checks.
Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ inferred absent ♥ Monetary expenditure not mentioned by sources [379][380].
♠ property/valuable items ♣ present ♥ Schnapps or pots of palmwine.[381][382]
♠ health costs ♣ inferred absent ♥ (KB: Coded as inferred absent, as description does not mention health costs)
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of animals' is coded 'absent' in the Ritual Database[383][384]

♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database[389][390].
♠ other ♣ ♥ List the other(s)

Most euphoric collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Healing ritual in ecstatic churches ♥ In healing services it always takes a long time to build up the necessary spiritual or suggestive atmosphere. Singing, long preaching and praying, and at some centres speaking in tongues precedes it. The congregation is made to participate in the proceedings. They may pray aloud each to his own words, the sound being like the roaring of surf. They are “welded” together into a sort of power-field by laying-on of hands by an officiating prophet who is in a trance under the influence of the Holy Spirit. Palm-branches may be given to the congregation. At another prophet's centre people queue up, sing and are sprinkled with holy water. This they carefully rub in, the women opening up their blouses so as to present their breasts to the precious liquid. Then they are given some of the holy water to drink. During this lengthy process the prophet moves around and inspires the singing and drumming of the band, until the whole congregation, gently swaying, has coalesced into one mystical body. This conveys to the devotee a feeling of security and importance. Only after these preparations does the actual direct treatment begin. This may consist of a symbolic rubbing in of holy oil on the front, the ears, the toes and the hands of the patient, thus symbolizing the healing power of Christ over the five senses and the whole of life. The prophet massages liniment and holy water on his patients[391]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ yearly ♥ 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'annually'[392].
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ yearly ♥ 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'annually'[393].
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ yearly ♥ 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'annually'[394].
♠ Duration ♣ 3 ♥ hours. 'Ritual duration category' in the Ritual Database is coded as '1-6 hours' [395].
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ suspected unknown ♥ in absolute numbers
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ suspected unknown ♥

♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ 'Humiliation of participants' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[400].
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ 'Mention of disgust' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[401].
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[402]. 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[403].
♠ pain ♣ present ♥ 'Other uncomfortable experiences' is coded as present in the Ritual Database[404].
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula', and 'Foul or unpleasant sensations (heat, stinging), tastes or smells' are all coded as absent in the Ritual Database[405].
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula', and 'Foul or unpleasant sensations (heat, stinging), tastes or smells' are all coded as absent in the Ritual Database[406].

♠ other ♣ ♥

Most dysphoric collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Exorcism ♥ 'Exorcism. After a long service (preaching, announcement, testimony of an old woman said to have been raised from the dead, ordination of ministers for his church) the prophet announced that the evil spirits would now be driven out. A group of church officers and priests busied themselves gathering particulars from about forty men, women and children all eager to confess and to have their supposed witch spirits evicted. They were all lined up in rows, facing “towards Sierra Leone”. Anyone who happened to be looking in the Sierra Leone direction was warned to keep out of the way for a while lest the fleeing spirits might possess one of them. The congregation struck a hand-clapping hymn, accompanied by a band, and in this way obviously built up the psychological pressure on the “witches”, who had already been instructed to kneel down. The prophet and one or two priests moved among them, here and there putting one hand on the head of a witch, and pointing with the other in the direction of “Sierra Leone”, commanding the witch spirit to go there. Some of the witches began to tremble under the psychic stress, and this was taken as a sign that the unclean spirits were beginning to feel uneasy in their bodies. Those spirits who persisted in resisting the prophet's influence shook their owners so severely that they fell writhing on the ground, and remained there quivering for some time. In such severe cases, the prophet or one of his assistants would sprinkle holy sand on them, particularly on their shaking limbs. By close observation, the prophet established the exact spot on limbs or head through which the witch spirit had departed. This danger point was anointed with holy oil and sacred sand to provide special protection against the counter attack. When the treatment was over, the patients lay supine like so many corpses. They were soaked by a rainstorm which had set in during the process of exorcism, and more sand was laid on to symbolize their “burial”, because they were considered as ritually “dead and buried with Christ”, so the prophet told me. Not all the witches, however, reacted so violently as this, more than half of them remained kneeling and shook only moderately or not at all. “Their witch spirits are not so bad and leave earlier” I was told. The ceremony eventually came to an end. Those “dead and buried” were “raised up to new life” by the prophet or one of the priests who pulled them to their feet. Some, however, were so far gone in their stupor that they could not be reawakened to consciousness so easily, and were carried off to the adjoining rooms.'[427]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ yearly ♥ 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' is coded as 'annually' in the Ritual Database [428].
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ once per generation ♥ 'Typical frequency of participation for patient (as patient)' is coded as 'less often than annually but usually more often than once in a lifetime' in the Ritual Database [429].
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ yearly ♥ 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' is coded as 'annually' in the Ritual Database [430].
♠ Duration ♣ 3 ♥ hours. 'Ritual duration category' is coded as '1 to 6 hours' in the Ritual Database [431].
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 10 ♥ in absolute numbers 'Participation' is coded as 'Other small sub-group (<15)' in the Ritual Database [432].
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ elites ♥ Summary description mentions a 'prophet', as well as 'church officers and priests' [433].
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ The source [434] does not suggest that any specific group was excluded from participating.
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ The source [435] does not suggest that any specific group was excluded from observing.
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Fasting' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [436].
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ absent ♥ 'Sleep deprivation' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [437].
♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ 'Threats or actions that evince fear' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [438].
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ 'Humiliation of participants' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [439].
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ 'Mention of disgust' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [440].
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [441].
♠ pain ♣ present ♥ 'Notes on NVBS Other' is coded as 'fitting, shaking of participants' and 'Other uncomfortable experiences' is coded as 'present' in the Ritual Database [442].
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [443].
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ While all patients were not easily revived after the procedure, there is no suggestion that there was a risk of death [444].
♠ other ♣ ♥
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [445].
♠ alcohol ♣ absent ♥ 'Intake of alcohol' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [446].
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [447].
♠ sex ♣ absent ♥ 'Sexual intercourse' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [448].
♠ dancing ♣ present ♥ 'Dancing or repetitive rhythmic movement' is coded as 'present' in the Ritual Database [449].
♠ synchronous movement ♣ absent ♥ 'Marching/ procession/ Proambulation' and 'Use of percussion instruments' are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [450].

♠ health costs ♣ ♥ Several patients were not easy to revive at the end of the exorcism, after having been rained on, shaken, and ceremonially buried over a period of 1-6 hours[461]. Is this enough of a health cost, though?
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of animals' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [462].
