I want now to examine that inheritance role in more detail. Matrilineages (ebusua) are very salient social units to the Fanti. They figure heavily in conversations of various sorts, including discussions of political and economic maneuverings. The lineage represents the primary referent of the English word “family” as it is used by Fanti speakers. The word ebusua is the primary translation equivalent of “family” for Fanti speakers, while in anthropological terms ebusua refers to a matrilineage (the unmarked default sense) or matriclan (a denotatively correct extension).' [554] 'Inheritance is traditionally within the ebusua (lineage). The elders of the ebusua determine who will succeed to the property and positions of a deceased person. The elders are free to pick any member of the lineage as successor, or they can select an outsider to act as custodian of the property and/or as temporary filler of the position. They are supposed to pick successors who are mature and who have the skills needed for effectively using the property or filling the position.' [555] 'There are ideal norms which are followed, insofar as possible, concerning the genealogical relationship of heir to deceased: 1) Normally women inherit from women and men from men. 2) Qualified people of the deceased's own generation take precedence over those of subsequent generations, and seniors do not normally inherit from juniors (i.e., qualified people junior to the deceased come in order of seniority). 3) Genealogical qualification consists primarily in being descended from the [Page 26] mother of the person who first earned or created the property; other lineage members come afterward.' [556] 'There is, therefore, a kind of inheritance seniority (mba mpanyin mu). According to this seniority pattern (see Fig. 2), if a man. A, creates some property, the property ideally should pass to his next younger matrilineally related brother, then to the next younger, etc. In Generation -1 the eldest son of his eldest sister would come first, followed by the eldest son of his next eldest sister and so on. In Generation -2 the eldest son of the eldest daughter of A's eldest sister would come first, etc. B. C, and D inherit only after all of A's younger brothers inherit and after all the descendants of his sisters inherit. This pattern seems also to work for positions, as well.' [557] 'A woman's property descends in the same manner, I believe, from “mother” to “daughter” by seniority.' [558] Inheritance from father to son was possible under certain conditions, but rarely practiced: 'Traditionally, there has also been some limited opportunity for father-son inheritance. A man has been able, by an oral will (or, more recently, a written one), to leave a part of the property that he has earned or created himself to his children and/or wife, subject to the agreement of his ebusua, Furthermore, modern Ghanaian law permits a Fanti man to leave up to a third of his acquired property to his children and up to a third to his wife. However, in spite of the potentiality, I recorded no cases in Egyaa of sons having inherited anything from their fathers: Egyaa men give their children anything they intend for them to receive during their lifetimes, leaving their whole estate to their ebusua heirs. My understanding was that this is a more traditional and common way of transferring property to men's children than oral wills, though I collected no hard evidence on the question.' [559] 'To summarize, the only property a man can transfer to his sons is that which he has personally acquired. His ebusua controls the distribution (normally within the ebusua) of other property which he has held. The persons in the ebusua who are his most likely heirs can be different for different properties since the ordering of likely heirs depends on the genealogical “age” of the property in question.' [560] Kronenfeld provides a general description of the property system: 'Thus, the actual social effects of Fanti inheritance rules depend on the durability of property, 1) The only properties (in Egyaa, at least) durable for a long time are positions: lineage leader ( ebusua panyin) and other chiefships or stools belonging to the ebusua. Informants talked about the inheritance of position in the same way that they talked about the inheritance of property, All stools or chiefships (except possibly for some asafo 2) House sites stay within an ebusua normally, but are common enough in Egyaa not to be worth fighting over. Houses themselves seem usually to last 20-30 years at most before needing rebuilding. (This refers to traditional wattle-and-daub or adobe houses. More recent concrete block houses will probably last longer.) Houses, then, may pass down one generation of inheritance, but not much further. 3) Personal property (clothes, utensils, etc.) also seem to have a short useful life, i.e., 10-20 years. 4) Fishing boats have an expected life span of 10 years, nets around 5 years, and motors around 3 years. 5) Women's fish-smoking ovens only seem to last a couple of years. 6) An active farm will be inherited when its owner dies; in fact, however, particular farms (in [Page 27] Egyaa ) only last for a couple of years, and thus are not too important as inherited property. 7) Finally, there does seem to have been a lot of cash in Egyaa which would represent a worthwhile inheritance. Supposedly, inherited money is kept separately from earned money. But money is constantly loaned out through a kinship-based credit network, and uncollectible debts are common. The net effect, I think, is that money deriving from some particular person only goes through a couple of inheritances at most before disappearing (or going into goods). However, this is only speculation, since money, being less visible and identifiable than goods, was harder for me to follow, and presumably for the same reasons is harder for the people involved to keep track of.' [561] 'Thus positions represent the only property in Egyaa which is likely to be inherited down two generations or more. Other property is very unlikely to last beyond its first owner's immediate heirs.' [562] 'The social effects of inheritance are modified, also, by some frequency considerations. Most people do not have much property to leave anyone. Most inheritance that does occur is brother to brother; only rarely does a nephew inherit from an uncle directly (only once in each generation for any particular property — see Table 2), though eventually the brothers of that nephew (i.e., the other nephews) will get their turn with the property, if they live long enough, and if it lasts.' [563] 'There are some general social consequences of the Fanti inheritance pattern that seem worthy of consideration. One of these consequences concerns the effects of different kinds of property on the presence or absence of internal lineage segmentation. Another concerns the effects, after successive generations, of the inheritance priority assigned to generation (vs. age) on the degree to which some ancestor's property rotates among all of his descendent lines or not.' [564]
♠ primogeniture inheritance by only males ♣ absent ♥ Seniority relations determined the distribution of inherited property (see above), but there was no primogeniture per se.
♠ primogeniture inheritance by males and females ♣ absent ♥ Seniority relations determined the distribution of inherited property (see above), but there was no primogeniture per se.
♠ other inheritance practices ♣ absent ♥
♠ Trusts ♣ absent ♥ We are unsure whether matriclans can be considered trusts. We have assumed this not to be case for the time being.
♠ State expropriation ♣ present ♥ Stools were owed 'death duties' in gold, slaves and movables: '(a) Death Duties (Ayibuadie): Bowdich mentions that the King of Ashanti was ‘heir to the gold of every subject from the highest to the lowest’, and thus, according to Ashanti custom, had to contribute to the funeral custom ‘to validate his claim’. This statement, however, requires considerable qualification. While it is correct to state that, theoretically, a Chief (or rather a Stool) would sooner or later become heir—within the strict limitation implied in the Ashanti meaning of the word—to all his subjects, the majority of such death duties were received by a Stool, indirectly. It has been observed that a Chief only has direct dealings with a minority of his subordinate Chiefs, e.g. with his own Mpanyimfo and with his own Birempon, and that these officials have numerous subjects of their own whom the Head-Chief only attempts to control through them. Let us suppose that a wealthy subject died, who happened to be under one of the Mpanyimfo of the Head-Chief's Birempon. The Opanyini would succeed to a specified amount of his subordinate's private personal [Page 108] movable assets, gold-dust, slaves, cloths, and such like. On the Opanyini's death, the Birempon would take a similar proportion of his estate. The Birempon's Head-Chief, i.e. the Head of the whole Territorial Division, would not get anything on these occasions. Later, however, when the Birempon himself died, the Head-Chief would benefit by receiving the death duties from his estate, which would thus include all that he, the Birempon, had collected and accumulated in death duties from his subjects. The potential wealth of Ashanti Chiefs might thus be very great, the amount of their immediately realizable securities very small. The late Mary Kingsley, whose writings on West Africa are remarkable for observation and intuition, wrote: ‘In the capacity (eventually) to command these things his wealth lies. So take the whole together and you will see how you can have a very rich African, who could not possibly pay down £20, but a real millionaire for all that.’ The unfairness of demanding great sums as war indemnities at very short notice, which had been the policy of some of our civil and military commanders in the wars against Ashanti, may thus be realized.' [565] 'It is necessary to understand that when, in Ashanti, we speak of a Chief taking part of a man's property on death, only his personal self-acquired movable property is meant. Family property, in the possession of the deceased, which on his death reverted to the family, might not be touched. The proportion of the property of a dead man taken by a Chief varied in specified cases, and this will be noted when the Constitution of individual Stools comes under examination. In this chapter I am concerned with general principles rather than with the more minute details. Ayibuadie means literally ‘something to cover over or help the funeral rite’. There is a word in the vernacular, muhoma (lit. that with which to bind the breasts), which has a significance very similar to ayibuadie. Instead of a Chief coming down upon the estate of a dead subject, i.e. sending his Sana Hene (Treasurer) to lock up his rooms and boxes until the value of the estate had been assessed, he might leave the amount to be paid in death duties to the discretion of the relatives of the deceased. The levy then assumed more the appearance of a voluntary contribution on their part, ‘to bind the breast of the Chief’, ‘whose heart was sore’ owing to the loss of his subject and friend. This method of allowing the death duty to be paid was a more delicate and tactful way of going about the collection of this tax than the other more forcible method, but it practically amounted to [Page 109] the same thing in the end. It must not be overlooked that the claim to receive ayibuadie or muhoma involved some special obligations on the part of the recipient. Both these claims may be traced back to the original cell from which most of these more elaborate customs sprang. The house-father succeeded to the property of his dead kinsman, but he also had to see to it that he gave him a good and proper funeral. By a legal fiction, the Chief stood in a similar relationship to his subject, and by taking some of the latter's property on his death placed himself under the fictitious obligation of having to contribute to his funeral custom. By doing so he did not, however, become liable for the debts of the deceased. A Chief would also take care to see that the balance struck between what came in from ayibuadie or muhoma and what went out in funeral contributions ( nsa or nsawa) was in his favour. There is yet another expression which is sometimes confused with the above, i.e. awunyadie. This term, I think, means the inheritance of property by the legal heir.' [566] 'Death duties ( Ayibuadie): The Chief claimed ayibuadie from those subjects who served him directly. He could claim all private property on death of any gyase who was descended down the female line from a gyase female slave. In the case of the descendant of a gyase man who had married a free woman (but a subject of the Chief), a male would enter that company to which his father had belonged, but at his death the Chief would claim only one half of his private belongings, the other half going to his own kindred. The Chief of Kumawu also claimed about two-thirds of the private property of the Heads of the following fekuo (the remaining third went to the Stool of the deceased), the Atum'tufo, Asoamfo, Asokwafo, Barimfo, Obofo, Samanfo, Sodofo. He received from his Mpanyimfo (on their death) a voluntary contribution made by the successor which was known as muhoma, and generally consisted of one of the deceased's wives, a male servant, a cloth, and some gold-dust. The taking of ayibuadie or muhoma implied an obligation to contribute towards the funeral expenses and to present gifts to the dead. In the case of a wealthy man, from whose estate a considerable amount had been received in death duties, this contribution might consist of a velvet pillow ( agopekyi), a silk danta (loin-cloth), in the folds of which was wrapped a suru of gold-dust (£1); 10 s. worth of gold-dust, to mix with the fat which was used to rub down the corpse; the coffin (which it has now become the custom for the children to buy); two or three [Page opp. p 230] [Page 230] cloths, which were buried with the body; a sheep and about 10 s. in gold-dust towards the funeral expenses. In the case of a poor man, the death duties from whose estate would be a small amount, the Chief would give a sheep and a cheap cloth, ‘lest if he did not give anything, the dead should report him to the ' Samanfo (spirits)’. [These obligations are still often observed, possibly from a superstitious dread of reprisals on the part of the dead; the corresponding right to demand ayibuadie, or to expect muhoma, has on the other hand almost entirely lapsed, and this state of affairs is often given as one of the reasons for the impoverished state of Stool finances.] The Chief also informed me of another interesting possible source of revenue in olden times of which I had not previously been aware, though it is possible the custom was not confined to one Division. When the Chief had a son or daughter ( by a wife who was at the same time his own subject), and that child died, the Chief succeeded to all his or her private property and not the child's abusua (kindred group) as would ordinarily be the case. Only a Head-Chief had this right, not the lesser Chiefs—the Mpanyimfo. This rule also applied to the children of the Kyidom Hene, because he was known as the ‘son’ of the Chief.' [567] We have provisionally considered this to be a form of state expropriation.
♠ Non-state expropriation ♣ absent ♥

Equity[edit]

Sex Class and Race[edit]

Marriage

♠ Monogamy ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [568] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [569] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [570] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [571] Exogamy was the norm: 'Marriage is expected to be exogamous, and is extremely simple. There is no bride-wealth, the union being effected by the transfer of rum or other drink and some money from the groom to the bride's immediate family. Divorce is extremely easy and may be initiated by either men or women. The most usual causes are adultery and the barrenness of wives.' [572] Society was matrilineal, but legitimacy was still important: 'Legitimacy is important both for inheritance and to define a person as having, or not having, slave ancestry. It demands not only a proper marriage, however short, but also a recognized pater: he gives the child his own spiritual identity and his or her name; he admits his responsibility for the child's education, and he has the expectation that the child will carry out the father's funerary rites. [MG]' [573] Multiple residence patterns were present: 'Domestic organization long remained one of the most ambiguous aspects of Akan social structure. It was Fortes who finally delineated the key structural principles and processes through his research in the 1940s in the communities of Asokore and Agogo. He distinguished three major household types each based on a different residence pattern. First are households grouped around a minimal matrilineage, such as a woman and her sister or daughters, or a man and his sister or sister's son. Such households are based on duolocal residence, with a husband and wife living apart in different domestic units; about 62 percent of the households in Agogo were of this type.' [574] 'Second are households consisting of a man, his wife, and their children, sometimes including other kinsfolk; this type of patrilocal or virilocal unit constituted about 22 percent of the households in Agogo. Finally, there are households made up of combinations of the previous types (e.g. a man, his wife, and children) plus his sister's children. Often these reflect an avunculocal residence pattern. The matrilineal domestic group is usually preponderant in the larger communities, while virilocal or patrilocal households are the most common type in small farming villages or hamlets. But all three "types" should be viewed simply as phases in a domestic cycle. In the early years of marriage, residence is predominantly duolocal, but with the passage of time this could shift to avunculocal or patrilocal/virilocal. Thus the composition of a domestic group would evolve over time. [ROL]' [575] Fathers played a prominent role in the arrangement of marriages: 'THERE are two forms of marriage recognised in the Fanti districts of the Gold Coast Colony, ( a) Marriage by native custom, and ( b) Marriage under Ordinance No. 14 of 1884 of the Colony.' [576] 'I intend to deal only with the native custom, and I may here state that I have always relied rather on illiterate natives and chiefs, for my information, than on educated native men, for the following reasons:—the illiterate native tells one all he knows, or all he dares, and, having no reason to lie when he is not in court, he generally relates facts. A chief is the judge of his people, and, with his councillors, is the repository and exponent of the law, and must necessarily be taken as an expert. The scholar studies anything but his own customs, while an educated native is too inclined to embellish those customs, and present them in a form that would do credit to Justinian.' [577] 'According to the Family System of the Tˇw-speaking races of the Gold Coast, although the children belong to the family of the mother, and not of the father, yet the father seems always to have been the person responsible for the marriage of his children.' [578] 'He was liable for their maintenance and up-bringing, and was responsible for their actions. Thus if any of his sons, living under his roof, seduced any woman, the father had to pay satisfaction. If any of his daughters were seduced, he claimed and obtained compensation. He supplied his children with means to trade, or to make a living, and in return was entitled to all their earnings. The liability for the sons ceased on their marriage, or when they became self-supporting, so that it was to the father's advantage to find them wives as soon as possible after they reached the age of puberty, and this became recognised as a duty.' [579] 'Hence it is clear that primitive negro marriages were interparental contracts, in which the consent of the parties themselves was never considered. The father gave his son a peto and a half of gold dust, and the mother contributed half a peto, to start him in life (a peto being roughly an ounce), and he then worked for himself instead of for his father.' [580] 'As time went on fathers came to look on their daughters as sources of income, and demanded sums of money when approached for their hands; this was only natural, as they had nothing to lose by keeping them unmarried, and lost at least their services when they parted with them; whereas unmarried sons were always a possible source of danger.' [581] 'Thus it came about, within historical times, that when a man had a marriageable son he approached a man with a marriageable daughter, and having made a suitable present, which varied from one ackie (4 s. 6 d.) to four ackies (18 s.), the two were betrothed, and cohabitation completed the marriage. [Some reckon the ackie as worth 5 s.]' [582] 'Sometimes it happened, for personal reasons, that children were betrothed before they were mature; in such cases the boy's parent maintained the girl in her father's house and watched her, and was entitled to satisfaction if she were tampered with. When both had reached puberty the marriage was completed by cohabitation. The betrothal could be broken off meanwhile by the boy's parent, on forfeiting the so-called ‘consawment’ money, or by the girl's parent, by returning the money that had been paid.' [583] According to Ffoukes, marriage negotiations became more extensive in the colonial period. There was a lot of regional variation: 'This state continued so long as children quietly submitted to the dictates of their parents, but during the last five centuries the natives have been brought into touch with various European nations, and the much-despised civilisation [Page 33] has tended to modify all their customs and ideas. Sons gradually came to be consulted, and were later allowed to choose their own wives; while the consent of the women was never considered until very recently, and even now it is not usual, except in Coast towns, where girls are far more independent than in the bush.' [584] 'The marriage custom, instead of being the simple process of parents pairing off their children, now entails considerable expense. For instance, the present procedure in Cape Coast is as follows:—The relatives of the man (or more often the man himself) approach the relatives of the girl with rum, and if they appear willing a further “dash” is taken, which varies from £1 to 30 s., according to the suitor's circumstances; this is called Abombo or the “knocking” fee, as the suitor knocks at the door to ask for the girl; the father fixes the amount. On the acceptance of the abombo the girl becomes the affianced bride of the man, and although this is only a moral obligation, it is very strictly adhered to, and breach of promise is unknown to native custom. Occasional presents may now be exchanged, and shortly afterwards her parents receive the Etsir-Nsã (Fantee, Etsir a head, Nsã rum), which consists of two flasks of gin and a sum varying from five dollars (£1) to half an ounce of gold (£2) which is distributed amongst her relatives.' [585] 'Her parents then may or may not make a further claim for dowry or head money, etsirkyeradzi or etsiradzi (from etsir, “head,” kyere “to show” or “prove,” and adzi, “thing”), of one to two ounces of gold, or £6 to £9; and the man further sends a box to the girl containing cloths, handkerchiefs, a comb, lavender-water and pomade, with perhaps pipes and a supply of tobacco, and a day is fixed to hand the girl over.' [586] 'Some time usually elapses between sending the etsir nsã and contributing the etsiradzi, and this, it is alleged, is to give the man and his parents time to watch the character of the girl, as well as to meet the increasing demands of the avaricious parents who fix the dowry; but there is nothing to prevent sending both at once and completing the nuptial ceremony forthwith. However, the negro never does anything in a hurry! No precautions are now taken with the girl other than to warn her not to visit her intended husband's house before she is handed over, and she is never confined before her marriage, but satisfaction must be paid for cohabitation before she is so handed over.' [587] 'In Fanti Yankumase [Assin] the custom varies appreciably from Cape Coast, for here the suitor sends to ask the girl's family, without rum or abombo, and if they agree, both families meet to drink rum or palm wine; this ceremony, to show the couple is engaged, is called Wakagyir. Then the man seals his bond by sending three small bottles of gin to the girl's family, and this is termed etsir nsã. He also [Page 35] gives the town crier 1 s. 6 d. to publish his betrothal, and 4 s. to witnesses. He further sends 8 s. to the girl's mother to maintain her until marriage; this payment is called Ntamboba (= Tanbiba, see infra), which implies, “as the mother has looked after the child, now somebody takes her.”' [588] 'The matter then waits until the man has sufficient money, and if the girl or her family has a debt he pays it; this they call the etsiradzi. At this stage the Assins make sure that the bride-elect is a virgin, and, if not, lay their claim against the seducer. If there are no debts, the bridegroom merely provides a box, with cloths, handkerchiefs, looking-glass, and perfumes, and takes the bride home.' [589] 'In Denkera the matter is much simpler; the man asks the father for his daughter, and notifies the girl's family, if he gets the father's consent, by sending them rum; he then pays her family the abombo, which they fix, and which may vary from £1 to 30 s., and the man takes the girl home; although he may pay a further dowry of £4 or £5, but this is not essential.' [590] Marriage and divorce became more regulated in the colonial period: 'The passing of the 1884 Marriage Ordinance Act attempted to set a standard for monogamous marriage and spousal inheritance of self-acquired property. Conflict over inheritance often ended up in court where officials tried to determine whether or not a spouse was a true and therefore legal wife. Women began to organize in the 1950's to change the distinction between ‘wife’ and ‘non-wife’ in order to protect the interests of women and children. The results were the passage of the Maintenance of Children Bill in 1965 and a new divorce law in 1971. [IS]' [591] Concubinage was practiced, but the rights of concubines differed from those of wives: 'Concubinage is everywhere practised on the Coast, and is generally respected, although civilisation has made educated natives profess to disparage it; the sole difference amongst the Fantis is, that Mpata or satisfaction can be sued for by a married man if his wife commits adultery, whereas he can obtain no redress in the case of a concubine. Further, a native can hardly be said to buy his wife, as all moneys paid by him are received on trust for the good behaviour of the wife during the marriage, and are returnable to the husband if he divorces his wife for her misconduct, only vesting in her family on her death, or the death of her husband.' [592] 'Concubinage is openly permitted, and although it is not encouraged on the Coast, it is widely practised elsewhere. It is really quite as honourable a connection as the native marriage, as couples frequently live through life with no other bond than mutual affection. The essential difference is that for lack of consideration the man cannot claim damages if the woman misconducts herself; and if the man misbehaves, the woman has only to leave him at will. In fact the difference is all in favour of the woman, as will be seen when dealing with divorce. Even a married man may keep a concubine openly if his wife has no objection, but she cooks only at the wife's request; it is when a man keeps concubines clandestinely or against his wife's will that the custom is deprecated, and he has to “pacify” her whenever she finds him out. Wives do not appear to discourage it so long as they themselves get their fair share of attention. Whatever is given to a concubine is given outright, and cannot be reclaimed if she chooses to leave him for someone else. Her children can hardly be called illegitimate, as they still belong to her family, and as in the case of a chieftainess the children succeed to the stool. If she has children, and then marries another man, the natural father usually takes and brings them up, so that they may bury him; but if he does not, the husband is obliged to look after them.' [593] 'There is this great difference, however, that, whereas the father of legitimate children is bound to support them, and he is responsible for all their acts, the natural father is not so bound, the obligation and liability falling on the woman's family; he only does so to keep up his good name, and the children do not participate equally in the funeral expenses.' [594] Levirate was also practiced: 'There is a peculiar exception to one of these prohibitions, for when a Fanti dies he is succeeded by his eldest surviving brother, and if he has no brothers, by his eldest sister's eldest son. If the brother succeeds, he is said to take his [Page 44] place, and part of his duty is to marry the widow; this is called Okuranba; if the nephew ( Awofasepenyin) inherits he has a wider choice, for if the man leaves a daughter the nephew can take his choice between the widow and her daughter, but he cannot marry both. ' [595] Husbands were obliged to pay compensation to the wife in the case of divorce unless a legitimate reason for the dissolution of the marriage could be provided: 'The Fantis assert that a man may repudiate his wife at will, but, if no substantial reason is given, he forfeits the dowry and all payments made on her behalf, pays all her expenses, and in addition pays her heavy compensation, so that it is never done. Elsewhere repudiation at will is unknown.' [596] 'The following are held to be good grounds on which a husband may divorce his wife:— (1) Adultery. (2) Repeatedly insulting the husband's parents. (3) Refusal on the part of the woman to cohabit, after the man has preferred his claim against an adulterer. (4) If she becomes a notorious thief or criminal. (5) If she persists in not consenting to his taking another wife. (6) If the wife practises witchcraft. (7) Desertion.' [597] 'In all these cases it is usual for both families to meet, and appoint an arbitrator, who may be the chief or any other person to whose decision they agree to submit. The case is gone into in the presence of both families, and if the grounds are held to be sufficient, the man is ordered to “chop” ( i.e., pipe-clay) the neck and breast of the woman, and she has to parade the town to publish the fact, and to show that she is free to marry again. If she was in the wrong, the man could then claim from her family restitution of the dowry, and all the expenses he had incurred throughout the marriage on her behalf, except the actual expense of maintaining her, doctor's bills, and the cloths that she had worn out; all jewels and the cloths that he had given her and which were not worn out are also returned. In Assin she is chalked on the foot. In Denkera she is not chalked at all, and here, although actual current expenses are awarded, they are invariably remitted.' [598] 'In the case of adultery, the husband can turn the woman [Page 47] out on the spot and refuse her all further support. Inquiry might show that she had committeed adultery after gross ill-treatment or desertion; in such cases a divorce would be decreed, but the man would forfeit his expenses. For adultery he also has an alternative, in that he could sue the adulterer for damages (Birebu), which might be more than the expenses that he could claim, and are never less; this depends on his position. In Cape Coast he has to elect, and cannot claim a divorce at the same time; he can only proceed to a divorce if the woman now refuses to pay some small satisfaction, and further refuses to live with him. In Assin he may divorce as well as claim. When a wife repeatedly inveighs against her husband's family, the family take the matter up, and the husband has to get a divorce or break with his family, but all endeavours are first made to persuade the woman to desist.' [599] 'In the case of theft, unless the wife is notorious, she pacifies the husband with a sheep, and the marriage continues. If the husband refuses, he forfeits his moneys; if the woman refuses, he can claim all.' [600] 'Where a woman refuses her consent to a new wife, she is invariably won over by a handsome dash.' [601] Women could not divorce their husbands directly, but courts could order men to divorce their wives on their behalf: 'A wife cannot divorce her husband, and the husband may always claim the Ayifur if she marries any other man without being first chalked. She can, however, take him before a native court on the following grounds:—(1) Continuous illtreatment. (2) His repeated insults to her family. (3) Aggravated assault. (4) If he is a notorious thief. (5) Desertion.' [602] 'If she gets judgment the court orders the husband to “chop” her to show she is free; he further forfeits all his expenses, and has to give up all her property that he has in his possession. Also, if there have been loans or money transactions between them, accounts are rendered and balances struck. In Fanti Yankumase the husband is entitled to recover his expenses in all cases of divorce.' [603] Given how adultery was recognized as constituting legitimate grounds for divorce, we have decided to code 'present'.
♠ Formal Elite Polygamy ♣ ♥ Concubinage was practiced (see above). We are unsure whether chiefs and elites had more wives/concubines than 'commoners', although it seems likely. More material is needed.
♠ Informal Elite Polygamy ♣ ♥
♠ Elite Concubinage ♣ ♥
♠ Typical number of extramarital partners ♣ ♥

Legal rights are different on the basis of:

♠ Gender ♣ present ♥ Descent was matrilineal: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [604] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [605] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [606] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [607] Female stools and councils complemented male power hierarchies: 'Female stools complemented the hierarchy of male stools. In the village the elders, mpanyinfo, heads of the matrilineages, who constituted with the odekro the village council, had their aberewa or obaapanyin, who looked after the women's affairs. The odekro had an obaapanyin who was responsible for the affairs of the women of the village and was a member of the village council; the ohene, head of a division, and the omanhene, head of the autonomous political community, had their female counterparts known as ohemma, female ruler, who sat on their councils. The ohene and the ohemma were all of the same mogya, blood, or clan. The Asantehemma, the occupant of the female stool of the Kumasi state, and therefore of united Asante, since her male counterpart was ex officio the Asantehene, king of Asante, was a member of the Kotoko council, the executive committee or cabinet of the Asanteman Nhyiamu, general assembly of Asante rulers.' [608] 'As members of their respective councils, female stool occupants participated in the legislative and judicial processes, in the making and the unmaking of war, and in the distribution of land, the basic resource of the economy. An ohemma of a state also had her own ntam, oath, a formula for starting the judicial process, and her own court, as well as her own okyeame (spokesman) who in the Akan courts acted as prosecutor and judge.' [609] 'An ohemma was a refuge for a fugitive from the ohene's court who often successfully sought her intervention in cases of the death penalty. Called the ‘mother’ of the ohene, she was the latter's most effective adviser and she had the right to administer to him even a public admonition. The ohemma was the aberewa, wisdom personified: an Akan court panel preceded their retirement to discuss a case before passing judgement by saying that they were going to consult aberewa,the old woman. As the aberewa of the town, the ohemma was the moral guardian of the females of the political community and a kind of moral censor: she examined adolescent girls before the main puberty rites which ushered them into adulthood and licensed their marriage, and was expected to say whether or not pregnancy had occurred before the rites. A girl who was found to have become pregnant before the rites was known as kyiribra, and was punished [Page 94] with ostracism together with her partner. The polity thrived on a sound moral order.' [610] 'As the abrewa, the ohemma was also custodian of ‘custom’. She was officially the foremost authority on the genealogy of the royal matrilineage, and hence the first and final arbiter on who was qualified by blood to be a male ruler; it was said of the ohemma's stool in relation to the male stool that it was the elder stool, akonnua panyin. It was the ohemma who played the leading role in the selection of a successor to a deceased or destooled (removed from office) ohene.' [611] 'The ohemma's role in the succession to a vacant stool can be understood in terms, first, of the composite nature of most of the Akan matrilineages and, secondly, of the Akan rules of succession. The composite nature of the Akan matrilineage lay not in its segmentation over time and space, but in the incorporation into it of ‘stranger’ segments which in time became concealed; even when it was known it was not permitted for outsiders to point it out. ‘Stranger’ segments could be descended from slave women or freeborn women of another clan who, therefore, were not of pure blood and whose descendants were not eligible for the stool. The ohemma was the one who could pronounce on the fitness of potential successors for the stool from the viewpoint of true descent from the founding ancestors/ancestresses.' [612] 'Secondly, while the Akan vested the right of succession in the royal matrilineage, they left open the question of the actual successor among the eligible males, which was resolved by joint consultations between the ohemma, as leader of the royal matrilineage, and the members of the village, divisional, or national council. In the process of consultation the ohemma and the council were governed by the following rules: brothers should succeed each other before sisters' sons in the order of seniority in age; but age could be discounted in favour of superior wisdom and character in a junior person. Seniority in age could also be discounted in favour of a younger successor, if rotational succession among the segments of the royal lineage had been adopted as a ‘convention’ by the lineage and the community as a whole. Where rotation had been adopted as a working rule, both the male and female stools rotated among the segments, so that at any moment the occupants belonged to different competing segments.' [613] 'It was the ohemma who operated these rules and ensured orderly succession to the stool. On the decease or de-stoolment of an ohene, the members of the council formally asked the ohemma to nominate a candidate for their approval, and gave her three succeeding options at the end of which the councillors could in turn present a candidate for her approval. It rarely, if ever, came to this. An ohemma consulted members of her matrilineage, her husband, if she had one, and the community at large through discreet inquiries by her nkotimsefo, [Page 95] household servants, who, like the palace functionaries, were so selected as to represent the various sections of the community. The candidate she turned up was thus more often than not the result of communal consensus. It was easy to arrive at this kind of consensus in the small-scale, face-to-face communities of the period before colonial rule.' [614] However, female heads of household would delegate authority to eldest sons and other male relatives: 'I have mentioned that the eldest member of the family is recognised as the head, but where this member is a woman, and more particularly where the family is connected with a stool, the head delegates her authority to her eldest son, or the eldest male in the family. Women have, however, been [Page 400] known to occupy the stool as reigning chiefs. Adoption proper is unknown, but if a distressed native commends himself to a family, and they approve, he is received by them as a domestic slave, and, as such, becomes absorbed into it. Again, in Fanti Yankumase, for instance, if a member of another tribe settles with them, and his sept, the Kwonna (say) will not help him, he may choose one of the others, who will, and he henceforth is treated as a member of the latter.' [615] According to Rattray, women were not oppressed by husbands and other men due to support from their matrilineage: 'In the chapter on ‘the Ashanti Classificatory System’ it was [Page 79] recorded that wives were inherited in exactly the same way as any other property; even in the case of a chief who is not dead but who has been deposed, or de-stooled as it is called in West Africa, his successor has a perfect right to have his predecessor's wives transferred to him equally with any other stool property. Again, on examination of the marriage laws, it will be found that, under certain circumstances, the native idiom for ‘to marry’ is to 'yere, lit. ‘buy a wife’.' [616] 'These two isolated instances, removed from their proper context, might well lead the casual observer to suppose that an Ashanti wife was little better than a man's chattel and to point to the servile condition of women.' [617] 'But in Ashanti no woman stands alone, for behind the woman stand a united family, bound by the tie of blood, which has here a power and a meaning we can hardly grasp. ‘If you see one parrot do not throw a stone at it, for there are many others,’ runs one of their sayings.' [618] 'The whole conception of ‘mother-right’ affords the woman a protection and a status that is more than an adequate safeguard against the ill-treatment by any male or group of males.' [619] 'Her children belong to her and her clan, not to that of her husband.' [620] 'All her individually acquired and inherited property is hers and her clan's, and her husband cannot touch it. Not only is this so, but when she dies, no male even of her own clan may be her heir until all her female blood (clan) relations are extinct.' [621] 'From these facts it is clear that the position of women in Ashanti is one of great importance.' [622] '‘I am the mother of the man,’ she says, and her meaning we cannot understand until a fuller knowledge of Ashanti social and religious organization shows us what is meant.' [623] '‘I alone can transmit the blood to a king.’' [624] '‘If my sex die in the clan then that very clan becomes extinct, for be there one, or one thousand male members left, not one can transmit the blood, and the life of the clan becomes measured on this earth by the span of a man's life.’' [625] Debrunner claims that the status of senior women declined during the colonial period: In the past, old women beyond child bearing age often had honoured social positions—as senior wives of a compound, female elders, recognized mediums (akomfo), priests, even female chiefs. Nowadays however, this has somewhat changed owing to the unequal spreading of education.' [626] 'The status of women and especially old women has declined. Young school girls are often rated higher than their mothers and grandmothers by society who call them “awuraa”, madam. Secretly the old women resent it and the younger members feel guilty towards them and therefore try to ward off their guilt feeling by accusing the old women of witchery. A student writes: “Because witchery is mostly attributed to old women, any misfortune that occurs in the family of such a woman is accredited to her. If care is not taken, such women will be cast out from family matters entirely”. Administrator Tauxier finds that the old women are accused by society of witchcraft because they have become useless to it—they cannot have children and cannot give pleasure to men.' [627] Farm labour was shared, but participation in crafts was largely restricted to men: 'Men and women share in labor, but both may own farms and houses and both may provide the labor for them. With respect to crafts, only pottery making is a female activity; the others are restricted to male specialists. Even in the case of pottery making, only men are allowed to fashion pots or pipes representing anthropomorphic or zoomorphic figures. [MG]' [628] However, marriage and divorce norms discriminated along gender lines. Husbands could take concubines, but wives could not take (legitimate) lovers (see above). Husbands could divorce their wives: 'The Fantis assert that a man may repudiate his wife at will, but, if no substantial reason is given, he forfeits the dowry and all payments made on her behalf, pays all her expenses, and in addition pays her heavy compensation, so that it is never done. Elsewhere repudiation at will is unknown.' [629] 'The following are held to be good grounds on which a husband may divorce his wife:— (1) Adultery. (2) Repeatedly insulting the husband's parents. (3) Refusal on the part of the woman to cohabit, after the man has preferred his claim against an adulterer. (4) If she becomes a notorious thief or criminal. (5) If she persists in not consenting to his taking another wife. (6) If the wife practises witchcraft. (7) Desertion.' [630] 'In all these cases it is usual for both families to meet, and appoint an arbitrator, who may be the chief or any other person to whose decision they agree to submit. The case is gone into in the presence of both families, and if the grounds are held to be sufficient, the man is ordered to “chop” ( i.e., pipe-clay) the neck and breast of the woman, and she has to parade the town to publish the fact, and to show that she is free to marry again. If she was in the wrong, the man could then claim from her family restitution of the dowry, and all the expenses he had incurred throughout the marriage on her behalf, except the actual expense of maintaining her, doctor's bills, and the cloths that she had worn out; all jewels and the cloths that he had given her and which were not worn out are also returned. In Assin she is chalked on the foot. In Denkera she is not chalked at all, and here, although actual current expenses are awarded, they are invariably remitted.' [631] 'In the case of adultery, the husband can turn the woman [Page 47] out on the spot and refuse her all further support. Inquiry might show that she had committeed adultery after gross ill-treatment or desertion; in such cases a divorce would be decreed, but the man would forfeit his expenses. For adultery he also has an alternative, in that he could sue the adulterer for damages (Birebu), which might be more than the expenses that he could claim, and are never less; this depends on his position. In Cape Coast he has to elect, and cannot claim a divorce at the same time; he can only proceed to a divorce if the woman now refuses to pay some small satisfaction, and further refuses to live with him. In Assin he may divorce as well as claim. When a wife repeatedly inveighs against her husband's family, the family take the matter up, and the husband has to get a divorce or break with his family, but all endeavours are first made to persuade the woman to desist.' [632] 'In the case of theft, unless the wife is notorious, she pacifies the husband with a sheep, and the marriage continues. If the husband refuses, he forfeits his moneys; if the woman refuses, he can claim all.' [633] 'Where a woman refuses her consent to a new wife, she is invariably won over by a handsome dash.' [634] Women could not divorce their husbands directly, but courts could order men to divorce their wives on their behalf: 'A wife cannot divorce her husband, and the husband may always claim the Ayifur if she marries any other man without being first chalked. She can, however, take him before a native court on the following grounds:—(1) Continuous illtreatment. (2) His repeated insults to her family. (3) Aggravated assault. (4) If he is a notorious thief. (5) Desertion.' [635] 'If she gets judgment the court orders the husband to “chop” her to show she is free; he further forfeits all his expenses, and has to give up all her property that he has in his possession. Also, if there have been loans or money transactions between them, accounts are rendered and balances struck. In Fanti Yankumase the husband is entitled to recover his expenses in all cases of divorce.' [636] Accordingly, we have decided to code 'present'. However, it appears that gender complementarity rather than either gender equality or gender stratification was the norm.
♠ Social class ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups rather than castes: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [637] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [638] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [639] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [640] Matrilineages held and transmitted land and political positions: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]' [641] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]' [642] Lineage segments were differentiated along the lines of heritable interest in property: 'Segments: While the lineage as a whole has some corporate concern with sponsoring the funeral of any of its members and with assigning that member's property to an heir, heritable interests in various properties can differentiate lineage members. Subsets of the membership of a lineage — equalling lineage segments — are defined by the existence of any property for which members of the subsets (exclusive of others) are potential heirs. Such sets (subsets of the whole) may range from, at the one extreme, only the actual children of some man's actual sisters (in the case of property that he himself created) to, at the other extreme, all the members of the lineage (in the case of property, in effect, created by the lineage founder). In Egyaa, only chiefly positions fall in the long-lived extreme, while (almost) all other created property (in Egyaa) falls in or near the short-lived extreme. No property in Egyaa falls enough in between the two extremes to matter, but property that survived long enough to be inherited through several generations (but not substantially longer) were such to exist, would create sets of members representing intermediate segments of the lineage's membership.' [643] Slavery was practiced: 'The Akan practiced slavery, obtaining slaves from northern slave dealers, usually Muslims. War captives, criminals, persons who opposed local chiefs, and many local ritual leaders were also enslaved. Slaves were used for domestic and field labor, for sale to traders across the Sahara and Atlantic, and as sacrifices to royal and other ancestors. In the middle of the nineteenth century, slaves amounted to half of the population in many towns. [MG]' [644] Wealthy urban families relied on unfree labour, but wealth stratification had emerged before the colonial period: 'The Portuguese “blueprint” of 1572 associates gold mining, forest clearing, and food production, and implicitly postulates the existence [Page 96] of an appropriating class and a producing class. It is, I suggest, mutatis mutandis, a paradigm of sorts for the early Akan state. Those who controlled the production and sale of gold were those able to procure a supply of unfree labor. Those who procured unfree labor were those able to create arable land within the forest. Those who created the arable were those who founded the numerous early Akan polities. We see, in other words, a class of Akan entrepreneurs emerging: a class of those able to use the strength of the world bullion market, and the availability of labor locally (whether through Wangara or Portuguese suppliers), in such a way as to create the new agrarian system. These entrepreneurs were known as the aberemp[unavailable]n (sing. [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n), literally “big men” but correctly glossed in an early European source as “a superior rich man.” ' [645] 'Akan village histories make frequent reference to hunters ranging the forest in search of land suitable for agricultural exploitation—taking account, presumably, of surface relief, water resources, soil, and so forth. The role of the aberemp[unavailable]n in these explorations is often described in considerable detail. By way of illustration I shall cite the cases of two, Tabiri Heman and Akuamoa Panin.' [646] 'The descendants of free settlers became [unavailable]manmufo, citizens. Those of the proprietors became adehyeε, nobility. There remain the unfree laborers. They must surely be those who became the third major element in the composition of an [unavailable]man, namely the gyaasefo. Literally “the people of the hearth,” they were absorbed into Akan society as servants of the adehyeε. They became responsible not only for their own subsistence but for that of the nobles. They farmed for them, assumed responsibility for their debts, and provided them with a wide range of personal services as stool-carriers, drummers, hornblowers, umbrella-carriers, bathroom attendants, messengers, tradesmen, sextons, and so forth. Their masters (or mistresses) were heirs to their property. Their status, unlike that of nobles and citizens, was transmitted through the male line. Rattray commented on the matter: [Page 100] 'There is little doubt that the Gyasefo were in olden times recruited from the slave class. A “Stool” slave became one of the Gyasefo. The descendants of a Gyase woman were of course considered as Gyasefo, down the female line for all time; not only was this so, but the son of a Gyase man would ordinarily also enter the office to which his father belonged, irrespective of the position of his mother.' [647] 'It is virtually impossible to render such terms as adehyeε, [unavailable]manmufo and gyaasefo into English with the appropriate nuances. Adehyeε may preside over the affairs of anything from villages on the one hand to kingdoms on the other. Their power will rest in no small measure upon the sheer numbers of gyaasefo whose services they command; indeed, this is one index of their rank. In 1936 Oheneba Sakyi Djan manfully struggled with the problem, though with reference to the more southerly forest Akan: 'The term “Gyaase”…applies to the most immediate adherents attached to the household of any important personage. In this instance, even an ordinary well-to-do man (rich man) may have his own Gyaase, so much so that the head of a family (Opanyin or Atrankonnua) or a ruler of a town (Odekro), or a head of a division of a state (Ohene) or the supreme head or king of a state (Omanhene) should necessarily have his own Gyaase-men, and the number of the members constituting the Gyaase of each of the above heads depends on the importance of the party concerned. That is to say, the number of the members of the Gyaase attached to the Ohene's household is by far fewer than that attached to the Omanhene household.' It was all to do with achievement. The fortunes of an [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n depended first on his ability to procure the labor that, the estate established, became his gyaasefo, and second on his ability to attract free settlers to the estate. Measured in these terms the relatively unsuccessful [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n emerged as no more than a village head, an [unavailable]dekuro, and was absorbed in time into the aman (qua state) of his more successful peer, the [unavailable]hene of this or that group of towns and villages, and he in turn into the aman (qua kingdom) of those even more successful. We turn to a consideration of the most successful of all.' [648] 'ON THE BASIS OF HIS observations of Kumase society in 1817, Bowdich became strongly aware of the degree of social stratification present. Of the many indicators of this—housing, diet, hygiene, toiletry, marriage, and so forth —he commented most fully on matters of the household economy:[Page 140] 'the higher class could not support their numerous followers, or the lower their large families, in the city, and therefore employed them in plantations (in which small crooms [villages] were situated) generally within two or three miles of the capital, where their labours not only feed themselves, but supply the wants of the chief, his family, and more immediate suite. The middling orders station their slaves for the same purpose, and also to collect fruit and vegetables for sale, and when their children become numerous, a part are generally sent to be supported by these slaves in the bush.' [649] 'Bowdich's “higher class” would appear to refer to the wealthy citizens, high officeholders for the most part, whose gyaasefo or “retainers” supported them; his “middling orders” to aspirant citizens in the process of creating, through utilization of slaves, their own gyaasefo; and his “lower class” to those who perforce ensured their survival by the use of family labor. If Bowdich may be understood to be suggesting that the commanding morality of metropolitan society was one of upward mobility based on wealth, then he was undoubtedly correct. Had Bowdich remained in Kumase a few months longer, he would have observed that upward mobility was an institutionalized process.' [650] Accordingly, political influence was tied to wealth. New formal titles were created for individuals who gained wealth and thus became part of an emerging 'bourgeoisie': 'Those who attained wealth in Asante were known as the sikafo, “the monied people.” This category subsumed the smaller group of those who acquired fortunes sufficiently substantial for them to seek formal recognition of their achievement. Of these, those able to demonstrate that they had acquired through their own enterprise a modest fortune of 125 peredwans might, with the approval of the Asantehene, obtain the entitlement of wearing in public a specially designed and woven cloth known as nyaw[unavailable]ho, “you have become rich.” It would seem that it was after the acquisition of such a resource in gold dust that the aspirant (and wise) citizen would begin to invest in people and land. The title to be acquired thereby was that of asafohene, an ancient one originally and exclusively meaning “a war captain.” But the title was available at different levels depending upon the number of subjects acquired. As noticed above, Yamoa Ponko gifted to his son, Gyesi Kwame, 100 subjects, and thereby Gyesi Kwame acquired the comparatively low-ranking dignity of an asafohene of the Kyidom Stool. By contrast, in late 1861 or early 1862 the Akyempemhene Owusu Koko, already an occupant of high office in Kumase, nevertheless publicly displayed his three thousand subjects—each in possession of a gun—who must be assumed to have represented self-acquired property. An asafohene able to show command of at least a thousand subjects was entitled not only to wear the nyaw[unavailable]ho cloth but also to have a horse-tail switch ( bodua) carried before him. It was, however, the right to use not the horse-tail but the elephant-tail switch ( mena or mmara) that was the most coveted of all honors—and one carrying with it use of the ancient title of [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n.' [651] 'However many sikafo aspired to the award of the elephant tail, relatively few seem to have achieved it. Three successful nineteenth century claimants are well documented, namely, Gyaasewahene Opoku Frefre (died 1826), Ankobeahene Kwaku Tawia (died ca. 1850), and Manwerehene Kwasi Brantuo (died 1865). There were certainly others. A description of the ceremony surrounding the award was given by the Akyeamehene Kwasi Nuama in 1925. Because it is the fullest account of the procedures known to me, I cite it fully: 'Those chiefs who were allowed to use elephant tails were called Abrempons. A chief who lives on his own land with his own subjects is known by the King as Abrempon. An Abrempon must exhibit his wealth publicly by presenting £9 6s. [i.e., 1 peredwan with supplementary mmataho] to all the Abrempons in Kumase; and 10 peregwans (£80) to the King. He would then go to Tafo and pay £1 6s. to the chief there who would give him an egg to throw against a silk cotton tree. He would then return to Kumasi. He would then go to Essumja Santimanso and buy a carpet ( nsa) for £24 [3 peregwans] from the subjects of the Chief there. He must only dance on it and leave it after presenting Essumjahene with another £24. Your going and coming expenses (including the £48) will cost you some 20 pregwans. He would buy an elephant tail from the Assinhene (son of Essumjahene) for £9 6s. He would tie the elephant tail round the waist of one of his slaves and he must then past [ sic] round the outskirts of the town lying on the leaves of palm trees which have been strewn around the town, firing at his slave with blank fire from time to time. The slave falls down eventually and he then cuts the string to which the tail is fastened and takes the tail—then the ceremonies are completed, and his people applaud him. Next morning he would get mashed yam mixed with 30 peregwans and be carried on a litter round the town of Kumasi scattering largesse of the yam mixture. On the following morning he would be carried in a litter with all his regalia, his skin plastered with white clay. Then he would fix up a spear at Dwebirim (the market place) and challenge those of the same rank to remove it. After this he is called Brempon. On the last day anyone who aspires to the rank of Abrempon takes out the spear and appoints a time for performing the same ceremonies.' The Akyeamehene thus identified six stages in the ceremony. The first, the payments to the aberemp[unavailable]n of the capital and to the Asantehene, requires little comment. In the early nineteenth century Hutchison noted that the first step was, for obvious reasons, taken only “by those who are in favour with the King, and think themselves safe from palavers.” The second and third stages, the visits to Tafo and Asantemanso, involved the candidate in ancient rituals the nature of which will not be [Page 142] examined here; suffice to remind the reader that Tafo was an old (“aboriginal”) trading center, and Asantemanso one of the “cradles” of the Akan.' [652] 'The fourth stage of the ceremony, that of catching of the “elephant,” was, by a fortunate chance, once witnessed by the missionary W. West on his visit to Kumase with Owusu Ansa in 1862. Although West does not name the candidate, one may be reasonably confident that it was the Kumase Manwerehene, Kwasi Brantuo. On March 29 West noted the arrival of several dignitaries in Kumase, “to take part in the ceremony, which was that of the display of wealth, by an old chief, in order to be entitled to the honour of having the elephant's tail carried before him; an honour to which only the wealthy can aspire.” he actual charade occurred the next day: 'A slave had been selected to enact the part of the elephant. Besmeared all over with chalk, holding in his hand a small tusk, which he occasionally applied to his mouth, and having an elephant's tail attached by a piece of string behind, he was started off; while some forty or fifty men, armed with muskets, and supplied with blank cartridges, followed in pursuit, keeping up an almost constant fire. His elephantship as we were informed, made his way, according to usage, to a small kroom [village] not far from Kumasi, where he fell down as if shot, and lay there until the chief himself appeared to cut off the tail; who, having thus hunted the elephant, and possessed himself of its caudal appendage, was considered, as I suppose, entitled to have it borne before him.' The “kroom” near Kumase at which the chase ended was, seemingly, a parcel of land that the Akwamuhene donated to aspirant aberemp[unavailable]n. Kwasi Brantuo was, in fact, given the Adiebeba lands in 1862 by the Kumase Akwamuhene Akwawua Dente; and Opoku Frefre, whose candidacy will be referred to next, was awarded the Daakwadwam lands by Akwawua Dente's forerunner in office, Kwakye Kofi.' [653] 'IN THE COURSE OF HIS VISIT to Kumase in 1817, Bowdich testified unambiguously to the connection between office and wealth. “The chiefs,” he wrote, 'are fed bountifully by the labours of their slaves, and sharing large sums of the revenue (the fines their oppression has imposed on other governments), with incalculable fees for corruption or interference, refine upon the splendour of equipage even to satiety, and still possess a large surplus of income daily accumulating' Bowdich was, however, also aware of the prejudice that existed, on the part of the older aristocratic families whose fortunes had been consolidated during the wars of expansion in the earlier eighteenth century, against the parvenu rich whose profits derived principally from trade. Bowdich recorded what was clearly a partisan view of the issue. Of the encouragement of trade, he commented, 'their government would repress rather than countenance the inclination (believing no state can be aggrandized but by conquest), lest their genius for war might be enervated by it, and lest, either from the merchants increasing to a body too formidable for their wishes to be resisted, or too artful from their experience to be detected, they might sacrifice the national honour and ambition to their avarice, and furnishing Inta [Gonja], Dagwumba [Dagomba], or any of their more powerful neighbours (who have yielded to circumstances rather than force) with guns and powder (which are never to be exported from Ashantee), break the spell of their conquests, and undermine their powers.' Again, David Hume's general observations on the development of a merchant class are highly pertinent: 'This perhaps is the chief advantage which arises from commerce with strangers. It rouses men from their indolence; and presenting the gayer and more opulent part of the nation with objects of luxury, which they never before dreamed of, raises in them a desire of a more splendid way of life than what their ancestors enjoyed. And at the same time, the few merchants, who possess the secret of this importation and exportation, make great profits; and becoming rivals in wealth to the ancient nobility, tempt other adventurers to become their rivals in commerce.' [Page 152] Bowdich's report of the views of the Asante nobility appears to echo Hume: 'Were they to encourage commerce, pomp, the idol of which they are most jealous, would soon cease to be their prerogative, because it would be attainable by others; the traders growing wealthy, would vie with them; and for their own security, stimulated by reflections they have now too little at risk to originate, they would unite to repress the arbitrary power of the Aristocracy; and even if they did not, inevitably (as the chiefs conceive) divert the people's genius for war.' [654] 'It would be easy to regard such appointees, collectively, as constituting a collaborating class. But one of the purposes of this essay has been to suggest that such a concept is of little analytical importance. It has been shown that those who were to collaborate with the colonial authorities had adopted ideological positions sharply divergent from the prevailing political mores long before the loss of Asante independence could have been foreseen. It has been suggested here that in the last quarter of the nineteenth century the fundamental challenge to the dominant mercantile ideology in Asante was presented by an embryonic bourgeoisie committed to the principles of laissez faire and that no analysis of the acute political conflicts which divided the Asante nation in that period is possible without reference to such ideological factors. Moreover, the history of the Gold Coast and of Ghana in the twentieth century can be understood, I believe, only with adequate reference to the nineteenth-century situation. The development of the cocoa industry represented, perhaps, the triumph of a new bourgeoisie “liberated” by the forces of colonialism. The economic policies of Kwame Nkrumah are to be seen as in many respects reviving those of Mensa Bonsu and Agyeman Prempeh, recognizing that the rapid development of the national economy must necessarily involve, albeit on mutually acceptable terms, the participation of foreign capital and expertise. The policies of Kofi Busia appeared designed, conversely, to stimulate the growth of the indigenous middle class. Subsequent governments have vacillated between these alternative paths to salvation.' [655] While attributing class structures to non-capitalist economies is difficult, Wilks distinguishes between 'nobles', an emerging urban 'bourgeoisie', free farmers, and unfree servants: 'It is notoriously difficult to characterize the class structure of precapitalist societies. To this generalization Asante is no exception, though R. A. Kea's studies of a number of seventeenth century Akan polities have provided an invaluable lead. For present purposes the postulate is that a class reproduces itself as a class and that it does so only insofar as it has a determinate and specific, though not necessarily direct, relationship to the means of production. Consider, for example, the Asante class of the adehyeε, a word commonly but inappropriately translated [Page 294] “royalty” in English. “The old adage” (and I quote the collective wisdom of the late Asantehene and his councillors in a judgment passed down in 1964) “is that a royal is one whose ancestor had established or founded a village." This succinct statement of traditional usage defines a class within Asante society by implicit reference to a set of proprietary rights over land exercised by those who were thereby able to appropriate, in the form of tributes, taxes, and services, part of the labor-value of others settled on the land. I have elsewhere suggested that the origins of the adehyeε class are to be sought in the context of the great economic transformations associated with the development of forest agriculture. I have also suggested that the gyaasefo emerged as a servile class in precisely the same context. In this chapter I argue that the asomfo, or those in administrative service, came to constitute a class within Asante society in precisely the same sense of class. Unlike both adehyeε and gyaasefo, however, the asomfo class emerged in an urban rather than rural context, and at a much later date: its full development was, therefore, specific to Asante rather than common to Akan society in general.' [656]
♠ Ethnicity or race ♣ present ♥ The emerging peasant class was largely made up of assimilated non-Asante: 'Arhin's article is a most welcome corrective to ideological arguments which attempt to force complex realities into simple schemes. His argument (re: Fallers) that a culturally distinct peasantry can be identified in precolonial Asante is supported, as he notes, by a large and growing body of historical work. Some of this research amplifies the urban/rural distinction even more than Arhin himself does: e.g., Wilks's (1975) discussion of the importance of the urban mercantile class (the asikafo) and his discussion of the way in which the state, embodied in the city itself, enforced its power. It is impossible to discuss the rise of the Asante state without talking about the rise of Kumasi as an urban center. By definition, the rise of the state therefore presupposes the rise of a hinterland and a peasantry. Unless one were to question whether the state existed at all (which no one is doing), there is not much question about a peasantry's existing, economically, politically, and culturally.' [657] 'There are a few points which could be emphasized: the cultural distinctiveness of the peasantry is due, in part, to the enormous numbers of strangers (particularly northerners) assimilated into Asante. As the slave trade decreased in the early 19th century, after abolition, large numbers of northerners had to be absorbed into the Asante populace. As Wilks describes, the government had very specific policies for carrying out this absorption. Thus, the urban/rural distinction is not simply one of “class” (which Arhin himself says is very unclear), but also, on some level, an ethnic one. In Asante the ethnic lines became more and more blurred, and the assimilationist policy made and continues to make discussion of this issue difficult; but it is clear that in everyone's attempt to be a “Kumasi” person there is also an attempt to certify one's unquestionable (free) Asante origins, which Arhin calls the “distinctively indigenous.”' [658] The same was true of other Akan states: 'Terray has already applied the concept “peasant” to the neighbouring Abron and, comparatively, to Asante (Terray 1974, 1975), but his usage differs from mine, perhaps because the political structures of the Abron and the Asante differ. For Terray the Abron peasant “classes” consist of the subject Kulango people, whom the Akan-Abron conquered before establishing a “conquest state,” a few Abron subjects, and above all slaves acquired through raids and warfare and by purchase. It is from these that the state, dominated by the Abron aristocracy, extracted its surpluses, and it is they that the state exploited.
