The slaves, in particular, formed the main labour force in the gold mines owned by the aristocrats and provided the main reason for the existence of the state.' [659] 'Strangers' were not part of established kin networks: 'People have travelled from the Northern Territories or the Colony to Ashanti in search of employment. Some of them have settled there more or less permanently. There are many people from these areas who have lived in Ashanti most of their lives, but they are outside the Ashanti political structure. They are ‘strangers’, no matter how long they live there.' [660] 'Even Ashantis are ‘strangers’ outside their own Divisions. There are many Ashantis living in Divisions other than those in which they are subjects by kinship. This is particularly so in Kumasi, where the opportunities of employment have attracted people from all parts of Ashanti. With reference to the kinship political organization, these Ashantis are strangers, just as are the settlers from the Northern Territories and the Colony.' [661] 'These permanent but ‘stranger’ settlers, who have no political status in the traditional organization based on kinship, present the chiefs with a new problem, which has arisen most acutely in connexion with taxation.' [662] The legal rights of 'strangers' were restricted: 'Asante men and women drew power and income from a well-developed internal marketplace system with three distinct types of market, in which chiefly regulations protected their privilege as traders and carriers. Non-Asantes were restricted from trading within Asante during most of the nineteenth century, so goods from outside passed into Asante hands at the officially designated border markets whose location contracted with the limits of effective political control (Wilks 1975). Quantities of imported consumer goods, mainly manufactures and crafts, passed from border markets either to the urban daily markets or directly to the regional periodic markets in leading Asante towns (Akoto 1980). These linked the rural population to the border markets and to other parts of Asante with different food supplies. Urban daily markets in Kumasi and leading provincial capitals served the needs of town dwellers for food and consumption goods of all kinds (Lewin 1974).' [663] Mixed marriages were rare and in-marrying individuals were expected to conform to local norms: 'Mahommedan law has not influenced these marriage or family customs in the slightest degree; on the contrary, if a Hausa marries a Fanti he must conform to Fanti custom, unless the girl first embraces Mahommedanism, which is very rare, and even then her children are still held to belong to the Fanti family. Such mixed marriages are, however, rare, and are altogether unknown to the Omanhin of Denkera.' [664] Politically and ideologically, Kumasi and the Asante occupied a central position compared to other peoples and locations: 'The central position of Kumasi and the Asante people, compared with neighboring rivals, has remained remarkably consistent over several centuries despite dramatic reconfigurations of trade—a testimonial to their strenuous and effective efforts. The Asantes emerged as an identifiable political unit in the seventeenth century when Akans moved into the forest to control gold mining areas and trade routes linking the ancient caravan routes across the Sahara to the European [Page 62] shipping routes pioneered by Portuguese explorers in the late fifteenth century. The Asante capital, Kumasi, lies about halfway between the coastal fort towns and the Northern savannah towns. Asante diplomacy and warfare first focused on defeating and absorbing their former overlords to the south to maintain free access to the coast. Then attention turned to its northern borders, turning the chiefs of Brong, Gonja, and Kete Krachi into subjects or tributaries (Arhin 1975; Maier 1983). Close relations with its “home port” of Elmina were threatened several times in the early 1800s by blockades or sieges by the British and Fante. The Asantes at first attempted to send more of their trade east via Accra and west via loyal ports around Takoradi. When the hostile British took over Elmina from the Dutch in 1868, the Asante army invaded it twice, in 1870 and 1874 (Wilks 1975). To the north of Asante, repeated unrest in the subjugated Brong chiefdom of Gyaman shifted trade west from its capital, Bonduku, to Salaga, and later to a new market at Kintampo when Salaga rebelled (Arhin 1971).' [665]

Discrimination[edit]

Discrimination on the basis of gender (include de facto discrimination even when there are no explicit legal restrictions)

♠ Bureaucratic positions are open to both males and females ♣ absent ♥ The time period in question was characterized by a trend towards greater bureaucratization and functional specialization: 'State organisation became extremely complex in the Kumasi state because at the close of the 17th century it became the capital of the union of Asante states and, in the course of the following century, the seat of an empire which was roughly coterminous with the boundaries of modern Ghana and southeastern Ivory Coast (Wilks 1975: 374-86). The expansion of the state made necessary administrative reforms within Kumasi itself and for the maintenance of effective relations between the Asantehene, the head of the Asante Union and, by consent, also the head of the Kumasi state, and the heads of the conquered territories. The palace administration ( gyase) was expanded with appointive headships of innumerable functional units or palace associations ( afekuo, sing. fekuo) (Rattray 1929: 81-92; Wilks 1967: 214-28; Hagan 1971). The memberships of the palace associations, each of which had either military or nonmilitary functions, cut across the divisions, so that they formed checks on, and counterpoises to, the traditional power units. The heads of the most important of the palace associations, including the units assigned to the offspring of former and reigning Asantehene (Busia 1951: 95), were included in the state council. Since appointments to the headships of the palace associations were in the gift of the Asantehene, the administrative reform represented an intrusion of patrimonialism (Weber 1947: 347) into the traditional political organisation.' [666] 'The vast area brought under Asante control by force or threat of arms could not be governed unless new methods of controlling it were developed. From the 1760s, beginning under Asantehene Osei Kwadwo, various steps were taken to bring the control of outlying areas directly under Kumase [...] Senior officeholders in Kumase were placed in charge of particular areas of the administration, controlling considerable numbers of lesser officials. Some supervised the trade in ivory and kola, while others oversaw the gold-producing regions which now fell within the borders of Asante. A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [667] 'Significant changes in Asante administrative practice, in the direction of increasing specialization of role, were attributed to Asantehene Osei Kwadwo (1764-1777). The class of administrators was a growing one, but I do not think we should yet speak of an administrative class emerging, one reproducing itself as a class.' [668] The purpose of this new administrative structure was to 'enforce subordination of the conquered rulers to the Asantehene. For this purpose the Asante kings used an administrative staff recruited from their gyase, household organization, consisting of units of functionaries with appointive headships [...] These palace associations, called afekuo (Reondorf, 1895: 119; Rattray, 1929: 91), were recruited from free attendants, warcaptives, purchased slaves (nnonkofo), and other bondsmen; in other words, persons connected by “ties of personal loyalty” (Weber, 1947: 342) to the various Asante Kings.' [669] Appointed officials and other dependents increasingly displaced the hereditary authority of 'traditional' public functionaries: 'From Opoku Ware (1720-50) to Kwaku Duah (1834-67), these personal dependants competed with, and replaced the holders of hereditary authority, occupants of royal stools ( adehye nnwa), in Kumasi and in the component states of the Asante Union in the exercise of authority and the collection of tribute and other payments in the conquered territories. Wilks (1967: 211-214) has called this administrative organization the “Kwadwoan revolution” on the ground that it took firm root in the reign of Osei Kwadwo (1864-77) although it began in that of Opoku Ware, and has identified it as the emergence of Asante “bureaucracy”.' [670] Senior public functionaries had a stool system of their own: 'In Kumasi proper there were seventy-seven stools, representing seventy-seven public functionaries, as, for example, the Bantuma Chief, or the Chief of the Royal Burial Grove, the Ateni Chief, or the Chief of the Lamplighters.' [671] Some foreigners were employed in highly specialized roles: 'A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [672] Most government activities at Kumasi were associated with the ruler's palace and other royal structures. The above-mentioned treasury was located there as well. Women occupied the stool of the queen mother, but it appears that newly created positions for state officials were only given to men.
♠ Promotion in administrative positions is open to both males and females ♣ absent ♥ We are unsure how promotions operated in the Ashanti system.
♠ Education is available to both males and females ♣ absent ♥ It appears that education was available to a small number of elite men only. Confirmation is needed.
♠ Property can be owned by both males and females ♣ present ♥ Property was inherited matrilineally, but fathers could transmit some property to sons as well (see property variables above). Accordingly, both genders could own property.

Discrimination on the basis of social class (include de facto limitations even when there are no explicit legal restrictions)

♠ Bureaucratic positions are open to people from all social classes ♣ absent ♥ The time period in question was characterized by a trend towards greater bureaucratization and functional specialization: 'State organisation became extremely complex in the Kumasi state because at the close of the 17th century it became the capital of the union of Asante states and, in the course of the following century, the seat of an empire which was roughly coterminous with the boundaries of modern Ghana and southeastern Ivory Coast (Wilks 1975: 374-86). The expansion of the state made necessary administrative reforms within Kumasi itself and for the maintenance of effective relations between the Asantehene, the head of the Asante Union and, by consent, also the head of the Kumasi state, and the heads of the conquered territories. The palace administration ( gyase) was expanded with appointive headships of innumerable functional units or palace associations ( afekuo, sing. fekuo) (Rattray 1929: 81-92; Wilks 1967: 214-28; Hagan 1971). The memberships of the palace associations, each of which had either military or nonmilitary functions, cut across the divisions, so that they formed checks on, and counterpoises to, the traditional power units. The heads of the most important of the palace associations, including the units assigned to the offspring of former and reigning Asantehene (Busia 1951: 95), were included in the state council. Since appointments to the headships of the palace associations were in the gift of the Asantehene, the administrative reform represented an intrusion of patrimonialism (Weber 1947: 347) into the traditional political organisation.' [673] 'The vast area brought under Asante control by force or threat of arms could not be governed unless new methods of controlling it were developed. From the 1760s, beginning under Asantehene Osei Kwadwo, various steps were taken to bring the control of outlying areas directly under Kumase [...] Senior officeholders in Kumase were placed in charge of particular areas of the administration, controlling considerable numbers of lesser officials. Some supervised the trade in ivory and kola, while others oversaw the gold-producing regions which now fell within the borders of Asante. A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [674] 'Significant changes in Asante administrative practice, in the direction of increasing specialization of role, were attributed to Asantehene Osei Kwadwo (1764-1777). The class of administrators was a growing one, but I do not think we should yet speak of an administrative class emerging, one reproducing itself as a class.' [675] The purpose of this new administrative structure was to 'enforce subordination of the conquered rulers to the Asantehene. For this purpose the Asante kings used an administrative staff recruited from their gyase, household organization, consisting of units of functionaries with appointive headships [...] These palace associations, called afekuo (Reondorf, 1895: 119; Rattray, 1929: 91), were recruited from free attendants, warcaptives, purchased slaves (nnonkofo), and other bondsmen; in other words, persons connected by “ties of personal loyalty” (Weber, 1947: 342) to the various Asante Kings.' [676] Appointed officials and other dependents increasingly displaced the hereditary authority of 'traditional' public functionaries: 'From Opoku Ware (1720-50) to Kwaku Duah (1834-67), these personal dependants competed with, and replaced the holders of hereditary authority, occupants of royal stools ( adehye nnwa), in Kumasi and in the component states of the Asante Union in the exercise of authority and the collection of tribute and other payments in the conquered territories. Wilks (1967: 211-214) has called this administrative organization the “Kwadwoan revolution” on the ground that it took firm root in the reign of Osei Kwadwo (1864-77) although it began in that of Opoku Ware, and has identified it as the emergence of Asante “bureaucracy”.' [677] Senior public functionaries had a stool system of their own: 'In Kumasi proper there were seventy-seven stools, representing seventy-seven public functionaries, as, for example, the Bantuma Chief, or the Chief of the Royal Burial Grove, the Ateni Chief, or the Chief of the Lamplighters.' [678] Some foreigners were employed in highly specialized roles: 'A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [679] Most government activities at Kumasi were associated with the ruler's palace and other royal structures. The above-mentioned treasury was located there as well. While some clerical positions were available to foreigners, most courtiers and state officials were probably members of elite families.
♠ Promotion in administrative positions is open to people from all social classes ♣ absent ♥ We are unsure how promotions operated in the Ashanti system.
♠ Education is available to people from all social classes ♣ absent ♥ It appears that education was only available to a small number of elite men. This is in need of confirmation.
♠ Property can be owned by people from all social classes ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal clans: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [680] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [681] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [682] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [683] Clans held and transmitted land: 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]' [684] 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]' [685] But inheritance was divided between a man's matrilineage and his own offspring: 'Despite being jurally matrilineal, inheritance is to some extent divided between sister's children and a man's own children. The basic principle is that lineage-inherited property goes to sisters' children, and property acquired with the help of a man's wife and children is distributed among the latter at his death. [MG]' [686] Households cultivated family farms: 'The farm, known in Asante as the afuo, was essentially a smallholding capable of supporting a single family. It consisted of two or sometimes three distinct parts, the afuwa, mfufuwa and mfufuwa-nini. The land currently under cultivation was the afuwa, “the little farm” or field, and the land under fallow was the mfufuwa, literally “the non- afuwa.” A farmer's rights of tenure over his fallow were as secure as those over his land under cultivation. In some cases a farm may have attached to it further land — fallow that has not been brought back into cultivation at the appropriate time because, for example, of unsatisfactory yields or of the inability of the tenants (through illnesses, deaths, or the like) to resume cropping it. Such land is the mfufuwa-nini, literally “barren fallow.” The original tenants and their heirs retain rights to the produce from it — to the fruits of palm and kola trees, for example, and to firewood and poles — but Asante law appears not to have defined with any precision the point in time at which others might acquire rights in it and recommence farming operations. Much litigation results.' [687] Land became the property of clans through clearing of forests and cultivation. Wilks describes the process of establishing estates: 'Akan village histories make frequent reference to hunters ranging the forest in search of land suitable for agricultural exploitation—taking account, presumably, of surface relief, water resources, soil, and so forth. The role of the aberemp[unavailable]n in these explorations is often described in considerable detail. By way of illustration I shall cite the cases of two, Tabiri Heman and Akuamoa Panin.' [688] 'The aberemp[unavailable]n were essentially developers. They created estates, founding villages and clearing the arable land necessary for subsistence. I refer to such estates as “ beremp[unavailable]n-doms” (by analogy with “kingdoms,” “chiefdoms,” etc.). Of the actual work of felling, clearing, and building, and of how the imported unfree labor was used, we know nothing. Such is not the stuff of tradition. Kea has drawn attention to a possible model, that of Aduafo of Afutu and “other great lords” who had contracted with the Danish African Company to clear a site and construct a trading post for them. They brought 300 of their slaves to the site and divided them [Page 98] into two teams. One carried out the clearing while the other assembled the building materials. This was, however, at a coastal location and is therefore of uncertain relevance.' [689] 'If the creation of an estate was predicated on the procurement of unfree labor, its prosperity depended on free settlers being attracted to it. Such was the pressure on land, on arable land, that they came. Sometimes the original estate was subdivided by purchase. For example, Adu Gyamfi, by origin from Adansemanso, founded a settlement named Aboforumu. It lay about 12 miles northwest of what was to become Kumase. He subsequently sold (“as the explorers or the owners of the land”) part of the estate to new settlers, Amma Badu and Antwi, who paid him mperedwan aduosia, 60 peredwans or some 135 oz. of gold. The estate was soon to be divided yet again. We have met Akosua Yitua of Asantemanso and her son Danso Abeam, above. She had five daughters. The third of these settled at Amoaman, but her descendants “became hemmed in at this village.” They moved northward, and their leader, Adu Panin, purchased a block of land from Amma Badu and Antwi. He renamed it Ntonso. The price is not reported. The transaction is said to have occurred at the time of Oti Akenten of Kumase. Other cases did not involve purchase, but contract sometimes sealed by marriage. The case of Kyerewa Akenten and her brother, Kagya, is instructive. They left Asantemanso in search of land and, after rejecting several places as unsuitable, arrived at Oyoko, near Feyiase. They went from there 'to Odum-Anaafuo to ask Berefo Kese, the Chief of the place for some land to settle on. He showed them a site where they built their village which they named “Kagya-kurom” [Kagya's village]. Owing to the large number of the followers of Kagya and his sister, Berefo Kese presented them a large portion of his lands on which they farmed. From Kagya-kurom Berefo Kese married Kyerewa Akenten and after their marriage Berefo Kese added a much larger portion of his lands to that already in their hands and presented it to them.' [690] 'Obtaining land involved negotiation with the [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n who had developed it, who had (as it were) staked out first claims to it. Matrifiliation as such conferred no rights of settlement. It will follow that the free settlers within a beremp[unavailable]n-dom belonged to different matriclans. In fact these are dispersed almost randomly throughout forest society. As Fortes has remarked, the matriclan “delimits a diffuse field of amity, wide in extent but of minimal structural specificity.” Within the beremp[unavailable]n-dom, of the rule of exogamy, and in that respect was a socially integrative factor. But claims to land were based upon the heritable rights that the [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n conferred upon the settlers, and the matrilineages that thus arose were tied to specific tracts of land within the estate.' [691] 'From the fifteenth century onward numerous estates or beremp[unavailable]n-doms arose as the frontier of farming expanded outward from the Adanse and Amansie regions. Such has been the thrust of the argument. Some were in time to become the capitals of aman, of states; some were to be incorporated into such states; and some were to falter and vanish. The struggles that attended the process are exhaustively chronicled in Akan traditions; the nature of the process itself, whereby a class of entrepreneurs became transformed into a ruling class, is not. The key lies in an understanding of the peculiar features of Akan land proprietorship.' [692] 'A cardinal feature of the system is expressed in the maxim, afuo mu yε me deε, asase yε [unavailable]hene deε, “the farm is my property, the land is the king's.” It is necessary to extrapolate from more recent practice, described by Rattray, Busia, and Fortes among others. If the proprietor of the land conferred heritable rights to the arable on those who were permitted to settle, he also reserved or established certain rights to himself and his heirs — to his “stool.” He took an almost token part of the harvest at the time of the annual harvest festival (the odwira), but required a more substantial share of the produce of the land as opposed to the arable: fish, snails, game, kola, minerals, and the like. He could levy a wide range of taxes, such as peato for military expenses, ayieto for funerals, and [unavailable]manto to defray the costs of making regalia and putting up buildings. Most importantly, he could require the provision of labor for military service or, for example, for work on the roads. Such, briefly, were what led Potekhin to refer to “the relatively easy feudal dues of the free members of the community.” Relatively easy” they may or may not have been; there was variation from place to place and time to time. “Feudal” they were not, for the free settlers acquired almost unassailable titles to the land they farmed, while the various taxes and services provided to the landholder were ad hoc and sporadic and did not approximate in character to a rent, whether economic or otherwise.' [693] 'The descendants of free settlers became [unavailable]manmufo, citizens. Those of the proprietors became adehyeε, nobility. There remain the unfree laborers. They must surely be those who became the third major element in the composition of an [unavailable]man, namely the gyaasefo. Literally “the people of the hearth,” they were absorbed into Akan society as servants of the adehyeε. They became responsible not only for their own subsistence but for that of the nobles. They farmed for them, assumed responsibility for their debts, and provided them with a wide range of personal services as stool-carriers, drummers, hornblowers, umbrella-carriers, bathroom attendants, messengers, tradesmen, sextons, and so forth. Their masters (or mistresses) were heirs to their property. Their status, unlike that of nobles and citizens, was transmitted through the male line. Rattray commented on the matter: [Page 100] 'There is little doubt that the Gyasefo were in olden times recruited from the slave class. A “Stool” slave became one of the Gyasefo. The descendants of a Gyase woman were of course considered as Gyasefo, down the female line for all time; not only was this so, but the son of a Gyase man would ordinarily also enter the office to which his father belonged, irrespective of the position of his mother.' [694] While wealth stratification was present, all free individuals could own property in principle.

Discrimination on the basis of ethnicity/race

♠ Bureaucratic positions are open to people from all ethnic/racial groups ♣ absent ♥ The time period in question was characterized by a trend towards greater bureaucratization and functional specialization: 'State organisation became extremely complex in the Kumasi state because at the close of the 17th century it became the capital of the union of Asante states and, in the course of the following century, the seat of an empire which was roughly coterminous with the boundaries of modern Ghana and southeastern Ivory Coast (Wilks 1975: 374-86). The expansion of the state made necessary administrative reforms within Kumasi itself and for the maintenance of effective relations between the Asantehene, the head of the Asante Union and, by consent, also the head of the Kumasi state, and the heads of the conquered territories. The palace administration ( gyase) was expanded with appointive headships of innumerable functional units or palace associations ( afekuo, sing. fekuo) (Rattray 1929: 81-92; Wilks 1967: 214-28; Hagan 1971). The memberships of the palace associations, each of which had either military or nonmilitary functions, cut across the divisions, so that they formed checks on, and counterpoises to, the traditional power units. The heads of the most important of the palace associations, including the units assigned to the offspring of former and reigning Asantehene (Busia 1951: 95), were included in the state council. Since appointments to the headships of the palace associations were in the gift of the Asantehene, the administrative reform represented an intrusion of patrimonialism (Weber 1947: 347) into the traditional political organisation.' [695] 'The vast area brought under Asante control by force or threat of arms could not be governed unless new methods of controlling it were developed. From the 1760s, beginning under Asantehene Osei Kwadwo, various steps were taken to bring the control of outlying areas directly under Kumase [...] Senior officeholders in Kumase were placed in charge of particular areas of the administration, controlling considerable numbers of lesser officials. Some supervised the trade in ivory and kola, while others oversaw the gold-producing regions which now fell within the borders of Asante. A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [696] 'Significant changes in Asante administrative practice, in the direction of increasing specialization of role, were attributed to Asantehene Osei Kwadwo (1764-1777). The class of administrators was a growing one, but I do not think we should yet speak of an administrative class emerging, one reproducing itself as a class.' [697] The purpose of this new administrative structure was to 'enforce subordination of the conquered rulers to the Asantehene. For this purpose the Asante kings used an administrative staff recruited from their gyase, household organization, consisting of units of functionaries with appointive headships [...] These palace associations, called afekuo (Reondorf, 1895: 119; Rattray, 1929: 91), were recruited from free attendants, warcaptives, purchased slaves (nnonkofo), and other bondsmen; in other words, persons connected by “ties of personal loyalty” (Weber, 1947: 342) to the various Asante Kings.' [698] Appointed officials and other dependents increasingly displaced the hereditary authority of 'traditional' public functionaries: 'From Opoku Ware (1720-50) to Kwaku Duah (1834-67), these personal dependants competed with, and replaced the holders of hereditary authority, occupants of royal stools ( adehye nnwa), in Kumasi and in the component states of the Asante Union in the exercise of authority and the collection of tribute and other payments in the conquered territories. Wilks (1967: 211-214) has called this administrative organization the “Kwadwoan revolution” on the ground that it took firm root in the reign of Osei Kwadwo (1864-77) although it began in that of Opoku Ware, and has identified it as the emergence of Asante “bureaucracy”.' [699] Senior public functionaries had a stool system of their own: 'In Kumasi proper there were seventy-seven stools, representing seventy-seven public functionaries, as, for example, the Bantuma Chief, or the Chief of the Royal Burial Grove, the Ateni Chief, or the Chief of the Lamplighters.' [700] Some foreigners were employed in highly specialized roles: 'A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [701] Most government activities at Kumasi were associated with the ruler's palace and other royal structures. The above-mentioned treasury was located there as well. While some clerical positions were available to foreigners, most courtiers and state officials were probably members of elite families. Accordingly, we have coded 'absent'.
♠ Promotion in administrative positions is open to people from all ethnic/racial groups ♣ absent ♥ We are unsure how promotions operated in the Ashanti system.
♠ Education is available to people from all ethnic/racial groups ♣ absent ♥ It appears that education was only available to a small number of elite men. This is in need of confirmation.
♠ Property can be owned by people from all ethnic/racial groups ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal clans: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [702] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [703] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [704] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [705] Clans held and transmitted land: 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]' [706] 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]' [707] But inheritance was divided between a man's matrilineage and his own offspring: 'Despite being jurally matrilineal, inheritance is to some extent divided between sister's children and a man's own children. The basic principle is that lineage-inherited property goes to sisters' children, and property acquired with the help of a man's wife and children is distributed among the latter at his death. [MG]' [708] Households cultivated family farms: 'The farm, known in Asante as the afuo, was essentially a smallholding capable of supporting a single family. It consisted of two or sometimes three distinct parts, the afuwa, mfufuwa and mfufuwa-nini. The land currently under cultivation was the afuwa, “the little farm” or field, and the land under fallow was the mfufuwa, literally “the non- afuwa.” A farmer's rights of tenure over his fallow were as secure as those over his land under cultivation. In some cases a farm may have attached to it further land — fallow that has not been brought back into cultivation at the appropriate time because, for example, of unsatisfactory yields or of the inability of the tenants (through illnesses, deaths, or the like) to resume cropping it. Such land is the mfufuwa-nini, literally “barren fallow.” The original tenants and their heirs retain rights to the produce from it — to the fruits of palm and kola trees, for example, and to firewood and poles — but Asante law appears not to have defined with any precision the point in time at which others might acquire rights in it and recommence farming operations. Much litigation results.' [709] Land became the property of clans through clearing of forests and cultivation. Wilks describes the process of establishing estates: 'Akan village histories make frequent reference to hunters ranging the forest in search of land suitable for agricultural exploitation—taking account, presumably, of surface relief, water resources, soil, and so forth. The role of the aberemp[unavailable]n in these explorations is often described in considerable detail. By way of illustration I shall cite the cases of two, Tabiri Heman and Akuamoa Panin.' [710] 'The aberemp[unavailable]n were essentially developers. They created estates, founding villages and clearing the arable land necessary for subsistence. I refer to such estates as “ beremp[unavailable]n-doms” (by analogy with “kingdoms,” “chiefdoms,” etc.). Of the actual work of felling, clearing, and building, and of how the imported unfree labor was used, we know nothing. Such is not the stuff of tradition. Kea has drawn attention to a possible model, that of Aduafo of Afutu and “other great lords” who had contracted with the Danish African Company to clear a site and construct a trading post for them. They brought 300 of their slaves to the site and divided them [Page 98] into two teams. One carried out the clearing while the other assembled the building materials. This was, however, at a coastal location and is therefore of uncertain relevance.' [711] 'If the creation of an estate was predicated on the procurement of unfree labor, its prosperity depended on free settlers being attracted to it. Such was the pressure on land, on arable land, that they came. Sometimes the original estate was subdivided by purchase. For example, Adu Gyamfi, by origin from Adansemanso, founded a settlement named Aboforumu. It lay about 12 miles northwest of what was to become Kumase. He subsequently sold (“as the explorers or the owners of the land”) part of the estate to new settlers, Amma Badu and Antwi, who paid him mperedwan aduosia, 60 peredwans or some 135 oz. of gold. The estate was soon to be divided yet again. We have met Akosua Yitua of Asantemanso and her son Danso Abeam, above. She had five daughters. The third of these settled at Amoaman, but her descendants “became hemmed in at this village.” They moved northward, and their leader, Adu Panin, purchased a block of land from Amma Badu and Antwi. He renamed it Ntonso. The price is not reported. The transaction is said to have occurred at the time of Oti Akenten of Kumase. Other cases did not involve purchase, but contract sometimes sealed by marriage. The case of Kyerewa Akenten and her brother, Kagya, is instructive. They left Asantemanso in search of land and, after rejecting several places as unsuitable, arrived at Oyoko, near Feyiase. They went from there 'to Odum-Anaafuo to ask Berefo Kese, the Chief of the place for some land to settle on. He showed them a site where they built their village which they named “Kagya-kurom” [Kagya's village]. Owing to the large number of the followers of Kagya and his sister, Berefo Kese presented them a large portion of his lands on which they farmed. From Kagya-kurom Berefo Kese married Kyerewa Akenten and after their marriage Berefo Kese added a much larger portion of his lands to that already in their hands and presented it to them.' [712] 'Obtaining land involved negotiation with the [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n who had developed it, who had (as it were) staked out first claims to it. Matrifiliation as such conferred no rights of settlement. It will follow that the free settlers within a beremp[unavailable]n-dom belonged to different matriclans. In fact these are dispersed almost randomly throughout forest society. As Fortes has remarked, the matriclan “delimits a diffuse field of amity, wide in extent but of minimal structural specificity.” Within the beremp[unavailable]n-dom, of the rule of exogamy, and in that respect was a socially integrative factor. But claims to land were based upon the heritable rights that the [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n conferred upon the settlers, and the matrilineages that thus arose were tied to specific tracts of land within the estate.' [713] 'From the fifteenth century onward numerous estates or beremp[unavailable]n-doms arose as the frontier of farming expanded outward from the Adanse and Amansie regions. Such has been the thrust of the argument. Some were in time to become the capitals of aman, of states; some were to be incorporated into such states; and some were to falter and vanish. The struggles that attended the process are exhaustively chronicled in Akan traditions; the nature of the process itself, whereby a class of entrepreneurs became transformed into a ruling class, is not. The key lies in an understanding of the peculiar features of Akan land proprietorship.' [714] 'A cardinal feature of the system is expressed in the maxim, afuo mu yε me deε, asase yε [unavailable]hene deε, “the farm is my property, the land is the king's.” It is necessary to extrapolate from more recent practice, described by Rattray, Busia, and Fortes among others. If the proprietor of the land conferred heritable rights to the arable on those who were permitted to settle, he also reserved or established certain rights to himself and his heirs — to his “stool.” He took an almost token part of the harvest at the time of the annual harvest festival (the odwira), but required a more substantial share of the produce of the land as opposed to the arable: fish, snails, game, kola, minerals, and the like. He could levy a wide range of taxes, such as peato for military expenses, ayieto for funerals, and [unavailable]manto to defray the costs of making regalia and putting up buildings. Most importantly, he could require the provision of labor for military service or, for example, for work on the roads. Such, briefly, were what led Potekhin to refer to “the relatively easy feudal dues of the free members of the community.” Relatively easy” they may or may not have been; there was variation from place to place and time to time. “Feudal” they were not, for the free settlers acquired almost unassailable titles to the land they farmed, while the various taxes and services provided to the landholder were ad hoc and sporadic and did not approximate in character to a rent, whether economic or otherwise.' [715] 'The descendants of free settlers became [unavailable]manmufo, citizens. Those of the proprietors became adehyeε, nobility. There remain the unfree laborers. They must surely be those who became the third major element in the composition of an [unavailable]man, namely the gyaasefo. Literally “the people of the hearth,” they were absorbed into Akan society as servants of the adehyeε. They became responsible not only for their own subsistence but for that of the nobles. They farmed for them, assumed responsibility for their debts, and provided them with a wide range of personal services as stool-carriers, drummers, hornblowers, umbrella-carriers, bathroom attendants, messengers, tradesmen, sextons, and so forth. Their masters (or mistresses) were heirs to their property. Their status, unlike that of nobles and citizens, was transmitted through the male line. Rattray commented on the matter: [Page 100] 'There is little doubt that the Gyasefo were in olden times recruited from the slave class. A “Stool” slave became one of the Gyasefo. The descendants of a Gyase woman were of course considered as Gyasefo, down the female line for all time; not only was this so, but the son of a Gyase man would ordinarily also enter the office to which his father belonged, irrespective of the position of his mother.' [716] While wealth stratification was present, all free individuals could own property in principle. This probably included all Akan groups within the Ashanti empire.

Social Mobility[edit]

Status[edit]

Elite status

♠ elite status is hereditary ♣ present ♥ Chiefly positions and stools were passed on within matrilineages (see below).
♠ elite status is selected ♣ present ♥ Some 'newly rich' men obtained recently introduced special titles (see below).
♠ formal system of hereditary social status ♣ absent ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups rather than castes: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [717] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [718] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [719] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [720] Matrilineages held and transmitted land and political positions: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]' [721] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]' [722] Lineage segments were differentiated along the lines of heritable interest in property: 'Segments: While the lineage as a whole has some corporate concern with sponsoring the funeral of any of its members and with assigning that member's property to an heir, heritable interests in various properties can differentiate lineage members. Subsets of the membership of a lineage — equalling lineage segments — are defined by the existence of any property for which members of the subsets (exclusive of others) are potential heirs. Such sets (subsets of the whole) may range from, at the one extreme, only the actual children of some man's actual sisters (in the case of property that he himself created) to, at the other extreme, all the members of the lineage (in the case of property, in effect, created by the lineage founder). In Egyaa, only chiefly positions fall in the long-lived extreme, while (almost) all other created property (in Egyaa) falls in or near the short-lived extreme. No property in Egyaa falls enough in between the two extremes to matter, but property that survived long enough to be inherited through several generations (but not substantially longer) were such to exist, would create sets of members representing intermediate segments of the lineage's membership.' [723] Slavery was practiced: 'The Akan practiced slavery, obtaining slaves from northern slave dealers, usually Muslims. War captives, criminals, persons who opposed local chiefs, and many local ritual leaders were also enslaved. Slaves were used for domestic and field labor, for sale to traders across the Sahara and Atlantic, and as sacrifices to royal and other ancestors. In the middle of the nineteenth century, slaves amounted to half of the population in many towns. [MG]' [724] Wealthy urban families relied on unfree labour, but wealth stratification had emerged before the colonial period: 'The Portuguese “blueprint” of 1572 associates gold mining, forest clearing, and food production, and implicitly postulates the existence [Page 96] of an appropriating class and a producing class. It is, I suggest, mutatis mutandis, a paradigm of sorts for the early Akan state. Those who controlled the production and sale of gold were those able to procure a supply of unfree labor. Those who procured unfree labor were those able to create arable land within the forest. Those who created the arable were those who founded the numerous early Akan polities. We see, in other words, a class of Akan entrepreneurs emerging: a class of those able to use the strength of the world bullion market, and the availability of labor locally (whether through Wangara or Portuguese suppliers), in such a way as to create the new agrarian system. These entrepreneurs were known as the aberemp[unavailable]n (sing. [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n), literally “big men” but correctly glossed in an early European source as “a superior rich man.” ' [725] 'Akan village histories make frequent reference to hunters ranging the forest in search of land suitable for agricultural exploitation—taking account, presumably, of surface relief, water resources, soil, and so forth. The role of the aberemp[unavailable]n in these explorations is often described in considerable detail. By way of illustration I shall cite the cases of two, Tabiri Heman and Akuamoa Panin.' [726] 'The descendants of free settlers became [unavailable]manmufo, citizens. Those of the proprietors became adehyeε, nobility. There remain the unfree laborers. They must surely be those who became the third major element in the composition of an [unavailable]man, namely the gyaasefo. Literally “the people of the hearth,” they were absorbed into Akan society as servants of the adehyeε. They became responsible not only for their own subsistence but for that of the nobles. They farmed for them, assumed responsibility for their debts, and provided them with a wide range of personal services as stool-carriers, drummers, hornblowers, umbrella-carriers, bathroom attendants, messengers, tradesmen, sextons, and so forth. Their masters (or mistresses) were heirs to their property. Their status, unlike that of nobles and citizens, was transmitted through the male line. Rattray commented on the matter: [Page 100] 'There is little doubt that the Gyasefo were in olden times recruited from the slave class. A “Stool” slave became one of the Gyasefo. The descendants of a Gyase woman were of course considered as Gyasefo, down the female line for all time; not only was this so, but the son of a Gyase man would ordinarily also enter the office to which his father belonged, irrespective of the position of his mother.' [727] 'It is virtually impossible to render such terms as adehyeε, [unavailable]manmufo and gyaasefo into English with the appropriate nuances. Adehyeε may preside over the affairs of anything from villages on the one hand to kingdoms on the other. Their power will rest in no small measure upon the sheer numbers of gyaasefo whose services they command; indeed, this is one index of their rank. In 1936 Oheneba Sakyi Djan manfully struggled with the problem, though with reference to the more southerly forest Akan: 'The term “Gyaase”…applies to the most immediate adherents attached to the household of any important personage. In this instance, even an ordinary well-to-do man (rich man) may have his own Gyaase, so much so that the head of a family (Opanyin or Atrankonnua) or a ruler of a town (Odekro), or a head of a division of a state (Ohene) or the supreme head or king of a state (Omanhene) should necessarily have his own Gyaase-men, and the number of the members constituting the Gyaase of each of the above heads depends on the importance of the party concerned. That is to say, the number of the members of the Gyaase attached to the Ohene's household is by far fewer than that attached to the Omanhene household.' It was all to do with achievement. The fortunes of an [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n depended first on his ability to procure the labor that, the estate established, became his gyaasefo, and second on his ability to attract free settlers to the estate. Measured in these terms the relatively unsuccessful [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n emerged as no more than a village head, an [unavailable]dekuro, and was absorbed in time into the aman (qua state) of his more successful peer, the [unavailable]hene of this or that group of towns and villages, and he in turn into the aman (qua kingdom) of those even more successful. We turn to a consideration of the most successful of all.' [728] 'ON THE BASIS OF HIS observations of Kumase society in 1817, Bowdich became strongly aware of the degree of social stratification present. Of the many indicators of this—housing, diet, hygiene, toiletry, marriage, and so forth —he commented most fully on matters of the household economy:[Page 140] 'the higher class could not support their numerous followers, or the lower their large families, in the city, and therefore employed them in plantations (in which small crooms [villages] were situated) generally within two or three miles of the capital, where their labours not only feed themselves, but supply the wants of the chief, his family, and more immediate suite. The middling orders station their slaves for the same purpose, and also to collect fruit and vegetables for sale, and when their children become numerous, a part are generally sent to be supported by these slaves in the bush.' [729] 'Bowdich's “higher class” would appear to refer to the wealthy citizens, high officeholders for the most part, whose gyaasefo or “retainers” supported them; his “middling orders” to aspirant citizens in the process of creating, through utilization of slaves, their own gyaasefo; and his “lower class” to those who perforce ensured their survival by the use of family labor. If Bowdich may be understood to be suggesting that the commanding morality of metropolitan society was one of upward mobility based on wealth, then he was undoubtedly correct. Had Bowdich remained in Kumase a few months longer, he would have observed that upward mobility was an institutionalized process.' [730] Accordingly, political influence was tied to wealth. New formal titles were created for individuals who gained wealth and thus became part of an emerging 'bourgeoisie': 'Those who attained wealth in Asante were known as the sikafo, “the monied people.” This category subsumed the smaller group of those who acquired fortunes sufficiently substantial for them to seek formal recognition of their achievement. Of these, those able to demonstrate that they had acquired through their own enterprise a modest fortune of 125 peredwans might, with the approval of the Asantehene, obtain the entitlement of wearing in public a specially designed and woven cloth known as nyaw[unavailable]ho, “you have become rich.” It would seem that it was after the acquisition of such a resource in gold dust that the aspirant (and wise) citizen would begin to invest in people and land. The title to be acquired thereby was that of asafohene, an ancient one originally and exclusively meaning “a war captain.” But the title was available at different levels depending upon the number of subjects acquired. As noticed above, Yamoa Ponko gifted to his son, Gyesi Kwame, 100 subjects, and thereby Gyesi Kwame acquired the comparatively low-ranking dignity of an asafohene of the Kyidom Stool. By contrast, in late 1861 or early 1862 the Akyempemhene Owusu Koko, already an occupant of high office in Kumase, nevertheless publicly displayed his three thousand subjects—each in possession of a gun—who must be assumed to have represented self-acquired property. An asafohene able to show command of at least a thousand subjects was entitled not only to wear the nyaw[unavailable]ho cloth but also to have a horse-tail switch ( bodua) carried before him. It was, however, the right to use not the horse-tail but the elephant-tail switch ( mena or mmara) that was the most coveted of all honors—and one carrying with it use of the ancient title of [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n.' [731] 'However many sikafo aspired to the award of the elephant tail, relatively few seem to have achieved it. Three successful nineteenth century claimants are well documented, namely, Gyaasewahene Opoku Frefre (died 1826), Ankobeahene Kwaku Tawia (died ca. 1850), and Manwerehene Kwasi Brantuo (died 1865). There were certainly others. A description of the ceremony surrounding the award was given by the Akyeamehene Kwasi Nuama in 1925. Because it is the fullest account of the procedures known to me, I cite it fully: 'Those chiefs who were allowed to use elephant tails were called Abrempons. A chief who lives on his own land with his own subjects is known by the King as Abrempon. An Abrempon must exhibit his wealth publicly by presenting £9 6s. [i.e., 1 peredwan with supplementary mmataho] to all the Abrempons in Kumase; and 10 peregwans (£80) to the King. He would then go to Tafo and pay £1 6s. to the chief there who would give him an egg to throw against a silk cotton tree. He would then return to Kumasi. He would then go to Essumja Santimanso and buy a carpet ( nsa) for £24 [3 peregwans] from the subjects of the Chief there. He must only dance on it and leave it after presenting Essumjahene with another £24. Your going and coming expenses (including the £48) will cost you some 20 pregwans. He would buy an elephant tail from the Assinhene (son of Essumjahene) for £9 6s. He would tie the elephant tail round the waist of one of his slaves and he must then past [ sic] round the outskirts of the town lying on the leaves of palm trees which have been strewn around the town, firing at his slave with blank fire from time to time. The slave falls down eventually and he then cuts the string to which the tail is fastened and takes the tail—then the ceremonies are completed, and his people applaud him. Next morning he would get mashed yam mixed with 30 peregwans and be carried on a litter round the town of Kumasi scattering largesse of the yam mixture. On the following morning he would be carried in a litter with all his regalia, his skin plastered with white clay. Then he would fix up a spear at Dwebirim (the market place) and challenge those of the same rank to remove it. After this he is called Brempon. On the last day anyone who aspires to the rank of Abrempon takes out the spear and appoints a time for performing the same ceremonies.' The Akyeamehene thus identified six stages in the ceremony. The first, the payments to the aberemp[unavailable]n of the capital and to the Asantehene, requires little comment. In the early nineteenth century Hutchison noted that the first step was, for obvious reasons, taken only “by those who are in favour with the King, and think themselves safe from palavers.” The second and third stages, the visits to Tafo and Asantemanso, involved the candidate in ancient rituals the nature of which will not be [Page 142] examined here; suffice to remind the reader that Tafo was an old (“aboriginal”) trading center, and Asantemanso one of the “cradles” of the Akan.' [732] 'The fourth stage of the ceremony, that of catching of the “elephant,” was, by a fortunate chance, once witnessed by the missionary W. West on his visit to Kumase with Owusu Ansa in 1862. Although West does not name the candidate, one may be reasonably confident that it was the Kumase Manwerehene, Kwasi Brantuo. On March 29 West noted the arrival of several dignitaries in Kumase, “to take part in the ceremony, which was that of the display of wealth, by an old chief, in order to be entitled to the honour of having the elephant's tail carried before him; an honour to which only the wealthy can aspire.” he actual charade occurred the next day: 'A slave had been selected to enact the part of the elephant. Besmeared all over with chalk, holding in his hand a small tusk, which he occasionally applied to his mouth, and having an elephant's tail attached by a piece of string behind, he was started off; while some forty or fifty men, armed with muskets, and supplied with blank cartridges, followed in pursuit, keeping up an almost constant fire. His elephantship as we were informed, made his way, according to usage, to a small kroom [village] not far from Kumasi, where he fell down as if shot, and lay there until the chief himself appeared to cut off the tail; who, having thus hunted the elephant, and possessed himself of its caudal appendage, was considered, as I suppose, entitled to have it borne before him.' The “kroom” near Kumase at which the chase ended was, seemingly, a parcel of land that the Akwamuhene donated to aspirant aberemp[unavailable]n. Kwasi Brantuo was, in fact, given the Adiebeba lands in 1862 by the Kumase Akwamuhene Akwawua Dente; and Opoku Frefre, whose candidacy will be referred to next, was awarded the Daakwadwam lands by Akwawua Dente's forerunner in office, Kwakye Kofi.' [733] 'IN THE COURSE OF HIS VISIT to Kumase in 1817, Bowdich testified unambiguously to the connection between office and wealth. “The chiefs,” he wrote, 'are fed bountifully by the labours of their slaves, and sharing large sums of the revenue (the fines their oppression has imposed on other governments), with incalculable fees for corruption or interference, refine upon the splendour of equipage even to satiety, and still possess a large surplus of income daily accumulating' Bowdich was, however, also aware of the prejudice that existed, on the part of the older aristocratic families whose fortunes had been consolidated during the wars of expansion in the earlier eighteenth century, against the parvenu rich whose profits derived principally from trade. Bowdich recorded what was clearly a partisan view of the issue. Of the encouragement of trade, he commented, 'their government would repress rather than countenance the inclination (believing no state can be aggrandized but by conquest), lest their genius for war might be enervated by it, and lest, either from the merchants increasing to a body too formidable for their wishes to be resisted, or too artful from their experience to be detected, they might sacrifice the national honour and ambition to their avarice, and furnishing Inta [Gonja], Dagwumba [Dagomba], or any of their more powerful neighbours (who have yielded to circumstances rather than force) with guns and powder (which are never to be exported from Ashantee), break the spell of their conquests, and undermine their powers.' Again, David Hume's general observations on the development of a merchant class are highly pertinent: 'This perhaps is the chief advantage which arises from commerce with strangers. It rouses men from their indolence; and presenting the gayer and more opulent part of the nation with objects of luxury, which they never before dreamed of, raises in them a desire of a more splendid way of life than what their ancestors enjoyed. And at the same time, the few merchants, who possess the secret of this importation and exportation, make great profits; and becoming rivals in wealth to the ancient nobility, tempt other adventurers to become their rivals in commerce.' [Page 152] Bowdich's report of the views of the Asante nobility appears to echo Hume: 'Were they to encourage commerce, pomp, the idol of which they are most jealous, would soon cease to be their prerogative, because it would be attainable by others; the traders growing wealthy, would vie with them; and for their own security, stimulated by reflections they have now too little at risk to originate, they would unite to repress the arbitrary power of the Aristocracy; and even if they did not, inevitably (as the chiefs conceive) divert the people's genius for war.' [734] 'It would be easy to regard such appointees, collectively, as constituting a collaborating class. But one of the purposes of this essay has been to suggest that such a concept is of little analytical importance. It has been shown that those who were to collaborate with the colonial authorities had adopted ideological positions sharply divergent from the prevailing political mores long before the loss of Asante independence could have been foreseen. It has been suggested here that in the last quarter of the nineteenth century the fundamental challenge to the dominant mercantile ideology in Asante was presented by an embryonic bourgeoisie committed to the principles of laissez faire and that no analysis of the acute political conflicts which divided the Asante nation in that period is possible without reference to such ideological factors. Moreover, the history of the Gold Coast and of Ghana in the twentieth century can be understood, I believe, only with adequate reference to the nineteenth-century situation. The development of the cocoa industry represented, perhaps, the triumph of a new bourgeoisie “liberated” by the forces of colonialism. The economic policies of Kwame Nkrumah are to be seen as in many respects reviving those of Mensa Bonsu and Agyeman Prempeh, recognizing that the rapid development of the national economy must necessarily involve, albeit on mutually acceptable terms, the participation of foreign capital and expertise. The policies of Kofi Busia appeared designed, conversely, to stimulate the growth of the indigenous middle class. Subsequent governments have vacillated between these alternative paths to salvation.' [735] While attributing class structures to non-capitalist economies is difficult, Wilks distinguishes between 'nobles', an emerging urban 'bourgeoisie', free farmers, and unfree servants: 'It is notoriously difficult to characterize the class structure of precapitalist societies. To this generalization Asante is no exception, though R. A. Kea's studies of a number of seventeenth century Akan polities have provided an invaluable lead. For present purposes the postulate is that a class reproduces itself as a class and that it does so only insofar as it has a determinate and specific, though not necessarily direct, relationship to the means of production. Consider, for example, the Asante class of the adehyeε, a word commonly but inappropriately translated [Page 294] “royalty” in English. “The old adage” (and I quote the collective wisdom of the late Asantehene and his councillors in a judgment passed down in 1964) “is that a royal is one whose ancestor had established or founded a village." This succinct statement of traditional usage defines a class within Asante society by implicit reference to a set of proprietary rights over land exercised by those who were thereby able to appropriate, in the form of tributes, taxes, and services, part of the labor-value of others settled on the land. I have elsewhere suggested that the origins of the adehyeε class are to be sought in the context of the great economic transformations associated with the development of forest agriculture. I have also suggested that the gyaasefo emerged as a servile class in precisely the same context. In this chapter I argue that the asomfo, or those in administrative service, came to constitute a class within Asante society in precisely the same sense of class. Unlike both adehyeε and gyaasefo, however, the asomfo class emerged in an urban rather than rural context, and at a much later date: its full development was, therefore, specific to Asante rather than common to Akan society in general.' [736] However, this does not seem to constitute a caste system.

♠ social mobility ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups rather than castes: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [737] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [738] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [739] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [740] Matrilineages held and transmitted land and political positions: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]' [741] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]' [742] Lineage segments were differentiated along the lines of heritable interest in property: 'Segments: While the lineage as a whole has some corporate concern with sponsoring the funeral of any of its members and with assigning that member's property to an heir, heritable interests in various properties can differentiate lineage members. Subsets of the membership of a lineage — equalling lineage segments — are defined by the existence of any property for which members of the subsets (exclusive of others) are potential heirs. Such sets (subsets of the whole) may range from, at the one extreme, only the actual children of some man's actual sisters (in the case of property that he himself created) to, at the other extreme, all the members of the lineage (in the case of property, in effect, created by the lineage founder). In Egyaa, only chiefly positions fall in the long-lived extreme, while (almost) all other created property (in Egyaa) falls in or near the short-lived extreme. No property in Egyaa falls enough in between the two extremes to matter, but property that survived long enough to be inherited through several generations (but not substantially longer) were such to exist, would create sets of members representing intermediate segments of the lineage's membership.' [743] Slavery was practiced: 'The Akan practiced slavery, obtaining slaves from northern slave dealers, usually Muslims. War captives, criminals, persons who opposed local chiefs, and many local ritual leaders were also enslaved. Slaves were used for domestic and field labor, for sale to traders across the Sahara and Atlantic, and as sacrifices to royal and other ancestors. In the middle of the nineteenth century, slaves amounted to half of the population in many towns. [MG]' [744] Wealthy urban families relied on unfree labour, but wealth stratification had emerged before the colonial period: 'The Portuguese “blueprint” of 1572 associates gold mining, forest clearing, and food production, and implicitly postulates the existence [Page 96] of an appropriating class and a producing class. It is, I suggest, mutatis mutandis, a paradigm of sorts for the early Akan state. Those who controlled the production and sale of gold were those able to procure a supply of unfree labor. Those who procured unfree labor were those able to create arable land within the forest. Those who created the arable were those who founded the numerous early Akan polities. We see, in other words, a class of Akan entrepreneurs emerging: a class of those able to use the strength of the world bullion market, and the availability of labor locally (whether through Wangara or Portuguese suppliers), in such a way as to create the new agrarian system. These entrepreneurs were known as the aberemp[unavailable]n (sing. [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n), literally “big men” but correctly glossed in an early European source as “a superior rich man.” ' [745] 'Akan village histories make frequent reference to hunters ranging the forest in search of land suitable for agricultural exploitation—taking account, presumably, of surface relief, water resources, soil, and so forth. The role of the aberemp[unavailable]n in these explorations is often described in considerable detail. By way of illustration I shall cite the cases of two, Tabiri Heman and Akuamoa Panin.' [746] 'The descendants of free settlers became [unavailable]manmufo, citizens. Those of the proprietors became adehyeε, nobility. There remain the unfree laborers. They must surely be those who became the third major element in the composition of an [unavailable]man, namely the gyaasefo. Literally “the people of the hearth,” they were absorbed into Akan society as servants of the adehyeε. They became responsible not only for their own subsistence but for that of the nobles. They farmed for them, assumed responsibility for their debts, and provided them with a wide range of personal services as stool-carriers, drummers, hornblowers, umbrella-carriers, bathroom attendants, messengers, tradesmen, sextons, and so forth. Their masters (or mistresses) were heirs to their property. Their status, unlike that of nobles and citizens, was transmitted through the male line. Rattray commented on the matter: [Page 100] 'There is little doubt that the Gyasefo were in olden times recruited from the slave class. A “Stool” slave became one of the Gyasefo. The descendants of a Gyase woman were of course considered as Gyasefo, down the female line for all time; not only was this so, but the son of a Gyase man would ordinarily also enter the office to which his father belonged, irrespective of the position of his mother.' [747] 'It is virtually impossible to render such terms as adehyeε, [unavailable]manmufo and gyaasefo into English with the appropriate nuances. Adehyeε may preside over the affairs of anything from villages on the one hand to kingdoms on the other. Their power will rest in no small measure upon the sheer numbers of gyaasefo whose services they command; indeed, this is one index of their rank. In 1936 Oheneba Sakyi Djan manfully struggled with the problem, though with reference to the more southerly forest Akan: 'The term “Gyaase”…applies to the most immediate adherents attached to the household of any important personage. In this instance, even an ordinary well-to-do man (rich man) may have his own Gyaase, so much so that the head of a family (Opanyin or Atrankonnua) or a ruler of a town (Odekro), or a head of a division of a state (Ohene) or the supreme head or king of a state (Omanhene) should necessarily have his own Gyaase-men, and the number of the members constituting the Gyaase of each of the above heads depends on the importance of the party concerned. That is to say, the number of the members of the Gyaase attached to the Ohene's household is by far fewer than that attached to the Omanhene household.' It was all to do with achievement.
