The fortunes of an [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n depended first on his ability to procure the labor that, the estate established, became his gyaasefo, and second on his ability to attract free settlers to the estate. Measured in these terms the relatively unsuccessful [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n emerged as no more than a village head, an [unavailable]dekuro, and was absorbed in time into the aman (qua state) of his more successful peer, the [unavailable]hene of this or that group of towns and villages, and he in turn into the aman (qua kingdom) of those even more successful. We turn to a consideration of the most successful of all.' [748] 'ON THE BASIS OF HIS observations of Kumase society in 1817, Bowdich became strongly aware of the degree of social stratification present. Of the many indicators of this—housing, diet, hygiene, toiletry, marriage, and so forth —he commented most fully on matters of the household economy:[Page 140] 'the higher class could not support their numerous followers, or the lower their large families, in the city, and therefore employed them in plantations (in which small crooms [villages] were situated) generally within two or three miles of the capital, where their labours not only feed themselves, but supply the wants of the chief, his family, and more immediate suite. The middling orders station their slaves for the same purpose, and also to collect fruit and vegetables for sale, and when their children become numerous, a part are generally sent to be supported by these slaves in the bush.' [749] 'Bowdich's “higher class” would appear to refer to the wealthy citizens, high officeholders for the most part, whose gyaasefo or “retainers” supported them; his “middling orders” to aspirant citizens in the process of creating, through utilization of slaves, their own gyaasefo; and his “lower class” to those who perforce ensured their survival by the use of family labor. If Bowdich may be understood to be suggesting that the commanding morality of metropolitan society was one of upward mobility based on wealth, then he was undoubtedly correct. Had Bowdich remained in Kumase a few months longer, he would have observed that upward mobility was an institutionalized process.' [750] Accordingly, political influence was tied to wealth. New formal titles were created for individuals who gained wealth and thus became part of an emerging 'bourgeoisie': 'Those who attained wealth in Asante were known as the sikafo, “the monied people.” This category subsumed the smaller group of those who acquired fortunes sufficiently substantial for them to seek formal recognition of their achievement. Of these, those able to demonstrate that they had acquired through their own enterprise a modest fortune of 125 peredwans might, with the approval of the Asantehene, obtain the entitlement of wearing in public a specially designed and woven cloth known as nyaw[unavailable]ho, “you have become rich.” It would seem that it was after the acquisition of such a resource in gold dust that the aspirant (and wise) citizen would begin to invest in people and land. The title to be acquired thereby was that of asafohene, an ancient one originally and exclusively meaning “a war captain.” But the title was available at different levels depending upon the number of subjects acquired. As noticed above, Yamoa Ponko gifted to his son, Gyesi Kwame, 100 subjects, and thereby Gyesi Kwame acquired the comparatively low-ranking dignity of an asafohene of the Kyidom Stool. By contrast, in late 1861 or early 1862 the Akyempemhene Owusu Koko, already an occupant of high office in Kumase, nevertheless publicly displayed his three thousand subjects—each in possession of a gun—who must be assumed to have represented self-acquired property. An asafohene able to show command of at least a thousand subjects was entitled not only to wear the nyaw[unavailable]ho cloth but also to have a horse-tail switch ( bodua) carried before him. It was, however, the right to use not the horse-tail but the elephant-tail switch ( mena or mmara) that was the most coveted of all honors—and one carrying with it use of the ancient title of [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n.' [751] 'However many sikafo aspired to the award of the elephant tail, relatively few seem to have achieved it. Three successful nineteenth century claimants are well documented, namely, Gyaasewahene Opoku Frefre (died 1826), Ankobeahene Kwaku Tawia (died ca. 1850), and Manwerehene Kwasi Brantuo (died 1865). There were certainly others. A description of the ceremony surrounding the award was given by the Akyeamehene Kwasi Nuama in 1925. Because it is the fullest account of the procedures known to me, I cite it fully: 'Those chiefs who were allowed to use elephant tails were called Abrempons. A chief who lives on his own land with his own subjects is known by the King as Abrempon. An Abrempon must exhibit his wealth publicly by presenting £9 6s. [i.e., 1 peredwan with supplementary mmataho] to all the Abrempons in Kumase; and 10 peregwans (£80) to the King. He would then go to Tafo and pay £1 6s. to the chief there who would give him an egg to throw against a silk cotton tree. He would then return to Kumasi. He would then go to Essumja Santimanso and buy a carpet ( nsa) for £24 [3 peregwans] from the subjects of the Chief there. He must only dance on it and leave it after presenting Essumjahene with another £24. Your going and coming expenses (including the £48) will cost you some 20 pregwans. He would buy an elephant tail from the Assinhene (son of Essumjahene) for £9 6s. He would tie the elephant tail round the waist of one of his slaves and he must then past [ sic] round the outskirts of the town lying on the leaves of palm trees which have been strewn around the town, firing at his slave with blank fire from time to time. The slave falls down eventually and he then cuts the string to which the tail is fastened and takes the tail—then the ceremonies are completed, and his people applaud him. Next morning he would get mashed yam mixed with 30 peregwans and be carried on a litter round the town of Kumasi scattering largesse of the yam mixture. On the following morning he would be carried in a litter with all his regalia, his skin plastered with white clay. Then he would fix up a spear at Dwebirim (the market place) and challenge those of the same rank to remove it. After this he is called Brempon. On the last day anyone who aspires to the rank of Abrempon takes out the spear and appoints a time for performing the same ceremonies.' The Akyeamehene thus identified six stages in the ceremony. The first, the payments to the aberemp[unavailable]n of the capital and to the Asantehene, requires little comment. In the early nineteenth century Hutchison noted that the first step was, for obvious reasons, taken only “by those who are in favour with the King, and think themselves safe from palavers.” The second and third stages, the visits to Tafo and Asantemanso, involved the candidate in ancient rituals the nature of which will not be [Page 142] examined here; suffice to remind the reader that Tafo was an old (“aboriginal”) trading center, and Asantemanso one of the “cradles” of the Akan.' [752] 'The fourth stage of the ceremony, that of catching of the “elephant,” was, by a fortunate chance, once witnessed by the missionary W. West on his visit to Kumase with Owusu Ansa in 1862. Although West does not name the candidate, one may be reasonably confident that it was the Kumase Manwerehene, Kwasi Brantuo. On March 29 West noted the arrival of several dignitaries in Kumase, “to take part in the ceremony, which was that of the display of wealth, by an old chief, in order to be entitled to the honour of having the elephant's tail carried before him; an honour to which only the wealthy can aspire.” he actual charade occurred the next day: 'A slave had been selected to enact the part of the elephant. Besmeared all over with chalk, holding in his hand a small tusk, which he occasionally applied to his mouth, and having an elephant's tail attached by a piece of string behind, he was started off; while some forty or fifty men, armed with muskets, and supplied with blank cartridges, followed in pursuit, keeping up an almost constant fire. His elephantship as we were informed, made his way, according to usage, to a small kroom [village] not far from Kumasi, where he fell down as if shot, and lay there until the chief himself appeared to cut off the tail; who, having thus hunted the elephant, and possessed himself of its caudal appendage, was considered, as I suppose, entitled to have it borne before him.' The “kroom” near Kumase at which the chase ended was, seemingly, a parcel of land that the Akwamuhene donated to aspirant aberemp[unavailable]n. Kwasi Brantuo was, in fact, given the Adiebeba lands in 1862 by the Kumase Akwamuhene Akwawua Dente; and Opoku Frefre, whose candidacy will be referred to next, was awarded the Daakwadwam lands by Akwawua Dente's forerunner in office, Kwakye Kofi.' [753] 'IN THE COURSE OF HIS VISIT to Kumase in 1817, Bowdich testified unambiguously to the connection between office and wealth. “The chiefs,” he wrote, 'are fed bountifully by the labours of their slaves, and sharing large sums of the revenue (the fines their oppression has imposed on other governments), with incalculable fees for corruption or interference, refine upon the splendour of equipage even to satiety, and still possess a large surplus of income daily accumulating' Bowdich was, however, also aware of the prejudice that existed, on the part of the older aristocratic families whose fortunes had been consolidated during the wars of expansion in the earlier eighteenth century, against the parvenu rich whose profits derived principally from trade. Bowdich recorded what was clearly a partisan view of the issue. Of the encouragement of trade, he commented, 'their government would repress rather than countenance the inclination (believing no state can be aggrandized but by conquest), lest their genius for war might be enervated by it, and lest, either from the merchants increasing to a body too formidable for their wishes to be resisted, or too artful from their experience to be detected, they might sacrifice the national honour and ambition to their avarice, and furnishing Inta [Gonja], Dagwumba [Dagomba], or any of their more powerful neighbours (who have yielded to circumstances rather than force) with guns and powder (which are never to be exported from Ashantee), break the spell of their conquests, and undermine their powers.' Again, David Hume's general observations on the development of a merchant class are highly pertinent: 'This perhaps is the chief advantage which arises from commerce with strangers. It rouses men from their indolence; and presenting the gayer and more opulent part of the nation with objects of luxury, which they never before dreamed of, raises in them a desire of a more splendid way of life than what their ancestors enjoyed. And at the same time, the few merchants, who possess the secret of this importation and exportation, make great profits; and becoming rivals in wealth to the ancient nobility, tempt other adventurers to become their rivals in commerce.' [Page 152] Bowdich's report of the views of the Asante nobility appears to echo Hume: 'Were they to encourage commerce, pomp, the idol of which they are most jealous, would soon cease to be their prerogative, because it would be attainable by others; the traders growing wealthy, would vie with them; and for their own security, stimulated by reflections they have now too little at risk to originate, they would unite to repress the arbitrary power of the Aristocracy; and even if they did not, inevitably (as the chiefs conceive) divert the people's genius for war.' [754] 'It would be easy to regard such appointees, collectively, as constituting a collaborating class. But one of the purposes of this essay has been to suggest that such a concept is of little analytical importance. It has been shown that those who were to collaborate with the colonial authorities had adopted ideological positions sharply divergent from the prevailing political mores long before the loss of Asante independence could have been foreseen. It has been suggested here that in the last quarter of the nineteenth century the fundamental challenge to the dominant mercantile ideology in Asante was presented by an embryonic bourgeoisie committed to the principles of laissez faire and that no analysis of the acute political conflicts which divided the Asante nation in that period is possible without reference to such ideological factors. Moreover, the history of the Gold Coast and of Ghana in the twentieth century can be understood, I believe, only with adequate reference to the nineteenth-century situation. The development of the cocoa industry represented, perhaps, the triumph of a new bourgeoisie “liberated” by the forces of colonialism. The economic policies of Kwame Nkrumah are to be seen as in many respects reviving those of Mensa Bonsu and Agyeman Prempeh, recognizing that the rapid development of the national economy must necessarily involve, albeit on mutually acceptable terms, the participation of foreign capital and expertise. The policies of Kofi Busia appeared designed, conversely, to stimulate the growth of the indigenous middle class. Subsequent governments have vacillated between these alternative paths to salvation.' [755] While attributing class structures to non-capitalist economies is difficult, Wilks distinguishes between 'nobles', an emerging urban 'bourgeoisie', free farmers, and unfree servants: 'It is notoriously difficult to characterize the class structure of precapitalist societies. To this generalization Asante is no exception, though R. A. Kea's studies of a number of seventeenth century Akan polities have provided an invaluable lead. For present purposes the postulate is that a class reproduces itself as a class and that it does so only insofar as it has a determinate and specific, though not necessarily direct, relationship to the means of production. Consider, for example, the Asante class of the adehyeε, a word commonly but inappropriately translated [Page 294] “royalty” in English. “The old adage” (and I quote the collective wisdom of the late Asantehene and his councillors in a judgment passed down in 1964) “is that a royal is one whose ancestor had established or founded a village." This succinct statement of traditional usage defines a class within Asante society by implicit reference to a set of proprietary rights over land exercised by those who were thereby able to appropriate, in the form of tributes, taxes, and services, part of the labor-value of others settled on the land. I have elsewhere suggested that the origins of the adehyeε class are to be sought in the context of the great economic transformations associated with the development of forest agriculture. I have also suggested that the gyaasefo emerged as a servile class in precisely the same context. In this chapter I argue that the asomfo, or those in administrative service, came to constitute a class within Asante society in precisely the same sense of class. Unlike both adehyeε and gyaasefo, however, the asomfo class emerged in an urban rather than rural context, and at a much later date: its full development was, therefore, specific to Asante rather than common to Akan society in general.' [756] While chiefly positions and stools were passed on within matrilineages, the fact that 'newly rich' men could obtain special titles seems to indicate some degree of social mobility.

♠ recruitment of chief executive ♣ higher ♥ Arhin describes the power hierarchy from the village upwards: 'Female stools complemented the hierarchy of male stools. In the village the elders, mpanyinfo, heads of the matrilineages, who constituted with the odekro the village council, had their aberewa or obaapanyin, who looked after the women's affairs. The odekro had an obaapanyin who was responsible for the affairs of the women of the village and was a member of the village council; the ohene, head of a division, and the omanhene, head of the autonomous political community, had their female counterparts known as ohemma, female ruler, who sat on their councils. The ohene and the ohemma were all of the same mogya, blood, or clan. The Asantehemma, the occupant of the female stool of the Kumasi state, and therefore of united Asante, since her male counterpart was ex officio the Asantehene, king of Asante, was a member of the Kotoko council, the executive committee or cabinet of the Asanteman Nhyiamu, general assembly of Asante rulers.' [757] Major and minor chiefs were also summoned to council: 'Where the paramount King of a state summons the Head-Chiefs of provinces and chiefs of minor communities to attend a State Council, it is the privilege of the Councillors of the several communities composing the State, according to their rank and importance, to accompany their several Heads to the capital and to join in the “palaver,” or discussion, that will take place, the King in person presiding over the deliberations, supported by his own Councillors and principal Linguists. This is the full Parliament of the people, who are thus fully and duly represented in every way from the highest to the lowest. The commands which go forth from this assembly are binding upon every individual family of the entire State, from the most important province to the most insignificant hamlet, and the sanction operates equally upon all.' [758] The paramount executive authority was the Asantehene: 'The King is the Chief Executive Officer of the State, but not the Executive Council of the State. Such a council exists, and any acts done by the King without its concurrence are liable to be set aside.' [759] The attribution of concrete entities to a particular executive level is not always clear, though, especially in the early period: 'The state of the union that emerged after the War of Independence was obviously a very fluid one. The Asanteman is referred to as the Asante Aman Nnum, the Five Asante States, but there is no clear consensus about which states comprised the original union. [...] The fact of the matter seems to have been that the coalition against the Denkyira included what were no more than “estates” on the one hand, like Bekwae, and what were established states on the other, like Mampon, Dwaben, and Kumase itself. Some were to decline and some were to prosper; some were to become powerful components of the Asanteman and some were to become little more than their clients.' [760] On the executive level it therefore seems best to go with the stool system: 'Every Asante village was a microcosm of the Asante economic, social, and political universe. Its population included both rulers and ruled, both “owners” of the land with the right of succession to the local, divisional, and state stools and free men grouped in other lineages with corporate interests in other political offices.' [761] Only a few leaders in executive positions achieved the additional special status of Abrempon or 'big man': 'However many sikafo aspired to the award of the elephant tail, relatively few seem to have achieved it. Three successful nineteenth century claimants are well documented, namely, Gyaasewahene Opoku Frefre (died 1826), Ankobeahene Kwaku Tawia (died ca. 1850), and Manwerehene Kwasi Brantuo (died 1865). [...] I know of no female recipient of the honor. I do not think that women were disbarred by reason of their sex, rather that few if any achieved the necessary level of accumulation. [...] Those chiefs who were allowed to use elephant tails were called Abrempons. A chief who lives on his own land with his own subjects is known by the King as Abrempon.' [762] The initiation required involved presentations of wealth as well as ritualized ceremonial. However, the office of Asantehene as well as other chiefly positions were passed on within matrilineages. We have codde for 'higher than top nobility' in order to reflect the Asantehene's superior status when compared to regional leaders.
♠ extreme status elevation ♣ absent ♥ We have found no evidence of lower-status individuals occupying the office of Asantehene.
♠ extreme status diminution ♣ absent ♥ We have found no evidence of destooled Asantehenes being demoted to slave status.

♠ occupational mobility ♣ present ♥ Cultivation systems varied with local ecology: 'The different ecological zones have given rise to contrasting types of agriculture. In the north the main subsistence and cash crop is yams, followed by guinea corn; by 1950 there still had not been any large-scale development of export crops. In the south, a much larger variety of subsistence crops are grown, especially yams, cocoyams, manioc, and maize. Also, there has been widespread development of major commercial crops such as the kola-nut and cocoa, which has become the main economic activity in the southern zone. In former times, until the end of the nineteenth century, farm work was done by servile labor: slaves, pawns, and various kinds of servants. Today sharecropping and hired labor are the most prevalent, although domestic peonage is still common. [ROL]' [763] While the rural population consisted primarily of farmers and craftsmen, the towns offered a more diverse labor market: 'The Kumasi Central Market is among the largest in West Africa and lies at the center of a vast market region. Traders, wholesalers, distributors, transporters, and retailers make up a complex network of exchanges, which are bolstered by a variety of kin, ethnic, and local ties. Commodity chiefs control the wholesale end of the business regulating prices. In the early nineteenth century men moved into commercial farming, leaving women to run the markets. [IS]' [764] 'But by the late eighteenth century the capital, Kumase, and several other major centers of local administration - Bekwae, Dwaben, Kokofu, and Mampon, for example - had come to offer a wide range of employment opportunities other than farming: in court, in the civil and military administrations, in business, in crafts, and so forth. In the early nineteenth century Kumase was already a town of about 20,000 people, few of whom were directly engaged in food production.' [765] Craft specializaton was also present: 'The Ashanti are noted for their expertise in a variety of specialized crafts. These include weaving, woodcarving, ceramics, and metallurgy. Weaving is a highly developed craft, with dozens of standardized and named textile designs. Weaving in cotton and silk is of a technically and aesthetically high order, and much commerce is built around it. Woodcarvings have also become a valuable commodity, especially with the rise of the tourist trade in the late twentieth century. Woodcarving is divided into many branches, each with its own specialists. Among the major products are wooden sculptures of outstanding artistic quality, talking-drums (NTUPANE), and the famous wooden "stools," which are symbolic and ritual objects rather than items of furniture.' [766] 'One of the most specialized crafts is metallurgy. Traditionally, Ashanti metal smiths worked in iron, brass, bronze, silver, and gold. Agricultural implements and other metal utensils were made of iron. Using a lost-wax process, smiths cast brass and bronze gold weights (MRAMMUE) of geometric, human, or animal forms. Although these objects are now mainly of interest to art collectors, their original function was practical; they were standard weights used to measure gold dust. [ROL]' [767] 'Craft production was an individual undertaking, and apprentice craftsmen were more often sons than sisters' sons. There were concentrations of certain crafts in certain villages, which were founded with war captives or refugees. Among these were settlements in the Kumase district such as Bonwire (cloth weaving), Ntonso (cloth dyeing), Pankrono (pottery), Ahwia (woodworking), and Breman and Adum (metalworking). Blacksmithery and joinery which catered to the needs of cultivators were scattered throughout the kingdom (Bowdich 1819, Dupuis 1824, Freeman 1967 [1898]). The crafts concerned with the elaboration of regalia were located in the immediate neighbourhood of the state capitals and the imperial capital of Kumasi (Rattray 1927: 216-308; Arhin 1982). Craft practitioners owned their own tools, and the factors that conditioned production were agricultural demand and state requirements.' [768] Trade was also important: 'There were early cultural and commercial links with the empires of the southern Sahara. The major commodities exchanged were gold from the Akan region and salt from the Sahara. The main Akan trading town was Bighu (Bitu) with links to Jenne on the Niger bend. Trade in gold and slaves formed the commercial basis of the traditional Ashanti state. Kola-nuts were also exported to the north. Today cocoa is Ghana's main export commodity. [IS]' [769] This seems to suggest that occupational mobility was present to an extent in cities.

Slavery[edit]

♠ Proportion of population enslaved ♣ 50% ♥ Slavery was widely practiced: 'The Akan practiced slavery, obtaining slaves from northern slave dealers, usually Muslims. War captives, criminals, persons who opposed local chiefs, and many local ritual leaders were also enslaved. Slaves were used for domestic and field labor, for sale to traders across the Sahara and Atlantic, and as sacrifices to royal and other ancestors. In the middle of the nineteenth century, slaves amounted to half of the population in many towns. [MG]' [770] Uncles could 'pawn' their nephew and nieces: 'An uncle had the power to pawn his nephew or niece. The whole legal position of pawns ( nwowa) will be examined later in detail under that heading. An uncle was expected to give the father of the person he wished to pawn ‘the first refusal’, that is, to ask him if he would not himself like to take his own child as his pawn. In any case, whether the father desired to do so or not, he might not protest or interfere. My Ashanti informants state that the person to be pawned would not wish him to do either, and remarked, Oba ose ose dome abusua (‘A child may resemble his father, but affection (duty) is for the blood relations’); and again, Gyadua si abontene ne hi wo fie (‘The gyadua (tree) may stand in the street, but its roots are in the house). ‘His uncle may not beat or punish your child while he is under your care, but, on the other hand, you may spend much money on your children, consulting the gods, yet when their uncle's house becomes poor he will sell them.’' [771] 'An uncle had the power to compel his niece to divorce her husband so that he might pawn her to raise money to ‘buy the head’ of one of his abusua. He would give her husband the option to advance the money, taking his wife as a pawn, but if he could not or would not do so, two courses were open to him: ( a) To put white clay upon his wife's back, i. e. divorce her, to enable her uncle to pawn her elsewhere, or, ( b) Pawn himself or his nephew to pay the debt of his wife's uncle.' [772] 'My informant added, ‘If you refused to do either of these things, the uncle would “swear an oath” upon you to buy your wife for some large amount ( tramma), for your wife is the property of her uncle, she is his agyapadie (inherited ancestral property).' [773] There were multiple classes of slaves: 'The Akan groups are characterized by matrilineal descent, inheritance, and succession. The Fanti and Ashanti have exogamous patrilineages also, making a double descent system. There is polygamy. In traditional Ghana when custom had determining influence on social life, a preference was given to cross-cousin marriage which among other things ensured that, in spite of matrilineal system of inheritance, the daughters of a man benefited from his property which they and their mother helped him to acquire. Local endogamy and traditional slavery and debt slavery also prevailed. There are no endogamous castes and no initiation schools.' [774] 'Slaves were not allowed to mix freely with free-men or allowed to go to the chief's palace; they were required to work harder and to do the dirty work. Moreover they were not accorded a funeral custom. There were four sub-classes of slaves. (1) The akoa (plural nkoa) originally referred only to voluntary servitude of a person to, for example, his MoBr (w[unavailable]fa). The best translation originally would have been “subject”; in reality it came to include persons whom another person had power over, merging with [unavailable]d[unavailable]nk[unavailable], the slave proper. (2) [unavailable]d[unavailable]nk[unavailable] (plural nn[unavailable]nk[unavailable], nn[unavailable]nk[unavailable]fo is a non-Akan purchased expressly as a slave. The second generation would always be termed akoa. They were usually bought at Salaga, a male costing the equivalent in cowries of 9,000 kola nuts, a female costing the equivalent of 14,000 kola nuts. Outside of Ashanti the master had life and death prerogative over his slaves; within Ashanti any execution had to be performed by the Asantehene's executioners. (3) The dommum was a foreign prisoner of war or tribute. All these [Page 40] classes of slaves could marry, own property (including his own slaves), swear an oath, and become heir to his master. A slave could swear an oath to be taken by another master if badly treated. Slaves could be sacrificed, and a reserve of them were kept at a special village (Akyere kurom). (4) An akyere was a slave condemned to death for an offense but saved until a sacrifice was required.' [775] Slaves could not hold stools and only inherited their master's wealth if no matrikin were present: 'Inheritance is arranged by the ohurew or executor responsible for all the funeral arrangements. Ideally the ohurew is the deceased's father's younger brother's son, in the same generation but preferably junior to the deceased. For a female deceased the ideal is FaBrDa. A dying declaration (samansew) is binding if there are witnesses. Although the ohurew is required to settle and distribute the estate, there is a constant problem of distinguishing family from self-acquired property. “The uncle seems in theory the heir to the personal property of his nephews, but almost invariably he waives his right in favour of the deceased's next eldest brother” (Rattray 1929:4). Next in line after eldest brother is the next brother in age until all the deceased's brothers are exhausted. Next is SiSo, then MoSiSo, and finally after all the male possibilities are exhausted the females are eligible for male property, beginning with the deceased's eldest sister. If all relatives are dead, the property (but never a stool) is inherited by a slave, even before the man's actual children — who are completely excluded. This same line of inheritance is followed in the succession for a stool, except that the line stops at slaves and women.' [776] But slaves could be adopted into matrilineages: 'Douglas has argued that “matrilineal descent groups are organised to recruit members by other means additional to direct lineal descent”; that “matrilineal descent goes with a quality of openness in the texture of effective descent groups”; and that [Page 80] 'because of the open texture of its descent groups and its bias towards a wide-ranging recruitment of manpower, matriliny is well adapted to any situation in which competing demands for men are higher than demands for material resources.' We suggest, then, that this “open texture” may have been at least one of the factors dictating the new form of social organization that appeared [Page 81] at the time of the clearances: the matriclan functioned to facilitate the assimilation of strangers and, to the point, of the unfree labor being drawn into the forest country. From more recent times we know that those of unfree origins were assimilated as rapidly as possible into the class of free Asante commoners and their acquired status afforded full protection of the law. An Ashanti slave,” wrote Rattray, in nine cases out of ten, possibly became an adopted member of the family, and in time his descendants so merged and intermarried with the owner's kinsmen that only a few would know their origin.' But Rattray still failed to allow fully for the “open texture” of the matrilineal group. The view has been expressed to the writer on many occasions that “in the old days” women married at a young age and men at a relatively advanced one; hat a male slave might often become the third, fourth, or even fifth husband of a (by then elderly) free woman, so that any children she bore by him would be free; and that female slaves were often married by free men and their children immediately adopted into the father's lineage.' [777] But slaves had no recourse to corporate descent groups of their own and could be ritually sacrificed: 'Such briefly were the rights of an Ashantislave. They seemed in many instances practically the ordinary privileges of any Ashanti free man, with whom, in these respects, his position did not seem to compare so unfavourably. The chief danger in which his peculiar status placed him appears to me to lie in the fact that the slave was generally a solitary creature more or less at the mercy of a single individual. Every one around him was in a sense ‘the slave’ of some one, but such persons had always behind them a whole group of relatives, whose numbers and wealth and power were ever at their disposal. The slave was not ordinarily possessed jointly (a position which would have ensured certain safeguards); at least, not when a member of a family had purchased him with the proceeds of his own individual labour. It seems probable that circumstances generally would have tended towards his kind treatment. An Ashanti slave, in nine cases out of ten, possibly became an adopted member of the family, and in time his descendants so merged and intermarried with the owner's kinsmen that only a few would know their origin. One outstanding fact, however, remained, i.e. that the status of a slave, i.e. an odonko, could never be lost, and, when necessity arose, or the terrible practice of human sacrifice became the vogue, an otherwise kind and considerate master would turn instinctively to the man who had no friend in the world, in order to satisfy the need for money or for a victim. The liability to be sacrificed at funeral customs may have been an ever-present fear in the mind of a West African slave. Many persons indeed were inevitably condemned to such an end. This idea was, as time went on, developed in an extraordinary degree. Whole villages existed where all the inhabitants were looked upon as a human reservoir from which, when occasion arose, sacrificial victims might be drawn. Such villages were called Akyere kurom (village of Akyere). Akyere means a slave who, instead of suffering immediate capital punishment for some offence of which he had been found guilty, was [Page 43] held over till his unhappy services were required. Meanwhile the person thus condemned went about his or her ordinary vocations, possibly was kept waiting for death for many years, married, brought children into the world, who again married and bore grandchildren to the original culprit. All these descendants (through the female line) inherited the liability of their ancestor to suffer capital punishment at any moment, and helped to swell a reserve of potential funeral victims.' [778] Slaves featured prominently in the trade with European powers: 'The fact of the matter is, then, that when the Portuguese entered the Akan gold trade in 1471, those they sought to do business with already had strong consumer preferences, formed in the context of their prior involvement with the Wangara. There was, however, one commodity that was not available from the northern traders: firearms. Initially, so it seems, a brisk exchange of guns for gold took place at Elmina, though such transactions were banned by papal decree. Pope Sixtus IV was petitioned to lift the restriction. On 28 January 1481, he forgave those who had transgressed but reaffirmed the ban. The Christian fear that arms sold at Elmina might find their way into Muslim hands was, in the circumstances, not entirely without foundation. The decision to build the fort of São Jorge at Elmina was taken in the belief that other Portuguese-manufactured produce—“silk, woollen and linen cloths, and other domestic goods” —would find a ready market there. Certainly objects of copper and brass did, whether shaving bowls, urinals, chamber pots, water jugs, bells, boxes, or bracelets (manilhas). Portuguese cloth, however, was apparently not so well received, and the Casa de Guiné in Lisbon was obliged to procure North African “lambens,” “aljaravias,” and the like, to service the Elmina trade. Vogt has suggested that in the late fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries cloth accounted for about 40 percent of the business done at São Jorge, and metals for about 37 percent. Next to these was the sale of slaves, accounting for about 10 percent of trade. Duarte Pacheco Pereira's informants on the Gambia spoke, as we have seen, of the merchants of Bitu, “Banbarranaa,” and “Bahaa” going to “Toom,” that is, the Akan country, “to buy gold in exchange for the merchandise and slaves which they take there.” In the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries a strong demand for labor arose in forest Akan society as local entrepreneurs, the aberemp[unavailable]n, sought to increase the extent of the cleared land available for tillage (see chapters 2 and 3). Slaves, in other words, could readily be traded against gold. By virtue of their command of the maritime routes, the Portuguese were able to insinuate themselves into this lucrative business. By 1479 Portuguese vessels were already [Page 24] moving slaves to Elmina from as far east as the Benin coast, and after 1515 the islands of São Tomé and Principe were developed as depots for the expanding enterprise. “Both during the life of Don João (1481-95) and of Dom Manuel (1495-1521),” wrote De Barros, 'this sale of slaves continued from Beny [Benin] to Mina, for ordinarily the ships that left this Kingdom went to Beny to buy the slaves, and then carried them to the Mina, until this trade was altered on account of the great inconvenience which arose. A large caravel was wont to sail from the island of S. Thome, where the slaves of the coast of Beny joined those from the kingdom of Congo, because all the vessels that sailed to those parts called there, and this caravel carried them from the island to Mina.' [779] 'For the period 1500-35 it has been estimated that the Portuguese imported ten to twelve thousand slaves to Elmina, though the figure takes no account of those landed by smugglers and interlopers. Although their sale accounted for only some 10 percent of the Portuguese trade at Elmina, it was critical in luring the inland merchants to the coast. “An adequate and continuous supply of slaves was indispensable for the success of Portuguese trade at São Jorge da Mina,” Vogt remarks. “Without such slaves, much of the remainder of the trade-goods would not have been sold.” The total cost, including purchase price, transportation, and food, of a slave procured in the Slave Rivers and sold at Elmina was reckoned at about one-third of an ounce of gold. The sale price ranged from about three to six ounces, according to physique.' [780] We have adopted the estimate provided by eHRAF, but this may overestimate the number of slaves in Asante. Clarification is needed.

♠ Proportion of population enserfed ♣ ♥ Unfree labourers were slaves rather than serfs (see above).

Types

♠ Chattel slavery ♣ present ♥ See above.
♠ Elite slavery ♣ absent ♥
♠ Bonded serfdom ♣ absent ♥
♠ Corvée labor to a landowner ♣ ♥ We are unsure whether corvée was practiced. More material may be needed.
♠ Corvée labor to the state ♣ ♥ We are unsure whether corvée was practiced. More material may be needed.

Restraints

♠ Owners can execute slaves ♣ absent ♥ Within Asante, state executioners, not masters, executed slaves (see above).
♠ Owners can impose corporal punishment on slaves ♣ inferred present ♥ Within Asante, state executioners, not masters, executed slaves (see above). But we have assumed that owners could still impose non-lethal punishment on slaves.
♠ Corporal punishment by the state ♣ present ♥ Within Asante, state executioners, not masters, executed slaves (see above).

Human sacrifice

♠ Prisoners ♣ present ♥ Slaves (some of whom were prisoners of war or foreigners bought as chattel) could be sacrificed: "One of the earliest European accounts of Asante, in 1701, already alludes to the sacrifice of captives taken in war.92 The earliest contemporary sources suggesting an especial extravagance of scale of human sacrifice in Asante, however, is a report of 1797 claiming that between 1,400 and 1,500 people had been sacrificed for the funerals of the royal princes, an excess which allegedly provoked a popular rebellion.93 The funeral of the mother of an Asante king in 1809 is said to have been marked by the sacrifice of no less than 3,000 human victims, over 2,000 of whom were prisoners of war.94 These accounts, based on hearsay, are very probably exaggerated, but the earliest detailed first-hand descriptions of Asante, produced by British missions to the capital Kumase in 1817 and 1820, con- firm the practice of human sacrifice on an extravagant scale. Human sacrifices were offered at private as well as at royal funerals, and also to gods to ensure the success of Asante military operations and on occasions of national disaster. In addition, human victims were killed at regular Asante festivals, such as the annual Yam festival (Odwira), which involved over 100 deaths a year, and the monthly Adae Festival, at which over 70 people were killed on one occasion in 1820.95 Richard Burton, seeking to defend Dahomey against charges of excess in these matters in the 1860s, could reasonably claim that Asante was worse." [781] See also slavery above. Ashanti sacrifice of captives: "As a nineteenth-century Ashanti king candidly told the British: 'If I were to abolish human sacrifice, I should deprive myself of one of the most effectual means of keeping the people in subjection.'"[782]
♠ Low social class ♣ present ♥ See above.
♠ Elites ♣ absent ♥
♠ Retainers ♣ absent ♥
♠ Outsiders ♣ present ♥ See above.

Religion and Normative Ideology[edit]

♠ RA ♣ Eva Brandl ♥

♠ Expert ♣ ♥

♠ Name of Official Cult ♣ Akan Religion ♥

♠ alternate Names of Official Cult ♣ ♥

♠ Name of other significant religious or ideological systems ♣ Christianity; Islam ♥ 'The Akan have largely been Christian since the nineteenth century, except for most kings, who have had to retain their indigenous religious status and practices. European Christian missions were highly successful, bringing not only Christianity but also education, and most Akan have been literate for a long time. Islam has a long history among the Akan, having been introduced by early traders from the north. Royalty made use of Muslim scribes for court duties. The Akan have a long history of "prophets" of many kinds-Christian, Muslim, and "heathen"-and of separatist Christian movements. All these various forms of religious belief and activity exist side by side, and most people have recourse to all of them, according to their particular needs and wishes. [MG]' [783]

♠ Description of the Normative Ideology ♣ ♥ eHRAF provides the following summary: 'Indigenous Akan religion is based upon the worship of a High God, various spirits or deities, and ancestors. The High God-known as Onyame, Onyankopon, and by other names-is the Creator, now otiose; Asase Yaa, the goddess of the earth, accompanies him. The ancestors live in the land of the dead and may demand offerings, in the past including those of slaves.' [784] 'Spirits or deities are many, and the living can communicate with them through prayer, sacrifice, and possession. Each has its own OSOFO, or priest; an OKOMFO is a living spirit medium who interprets the words of a spirit who is consulted to remove sickness and human disasters. [MG]' [785] 'The royal ancestors are at the heart of the ritual protection of a kingdom. They are "fed" at shrines in the form of blackened stools of wood and kept in the "stool rooms" in palaces and houses. Traditionally, the stools were anointed with human blood, gunpowder, and spider webs, and given alcoholic drink; human sacrifices are no longer made. Each kingdom and town has, or had in past years, an annual purification ritual, known as ODWIRA, in which the king, the office of kingship, the kingdom, and the town are purified of the pollution of the preceding year; this is often known in the literature as a "yam festival." [MG]' [786]

Deification of Rulers[edit]

♠ Rulers are legitimated by gods ♣ present ♥ Arhin describes the power hierarchy from the village upwards: 'Female stools complemented the hierarchy of male stools. In the village the elders, mpanyinfo, heads of the matrilineages, who constituted with the odekro the village council, had their aberewa or obaapanyin, who looked after the women's affairs. The odekro had an obaapanyin who was responsible for the affairs of the women of the village and was a member of the village council; the ohene, head of a division, and the omanhene, head of the autonomous political community, had their female counterparts known as ohemma, female ruler, who sat on their councils. The ohene and the ohemma were all of the same mogya, blood, or clan. The Asantehemma, the occupant of the female stool of the Kumasi state, and therefore of united Asante, since her male counterpart was ex officio the Asantehene, king of Asante, was a member of the Kotoko council, the executive committee or cabinet of the Asanteman Nhyiamu, general assembly of Asante rulers.' [787] Major and minor chiefs were also summoned to council: 'Where the paramount King of a state summons the Head-Chiefs of provinces and chiefs of minor communities to attend a State Council, it is the privilege of the Councillors of the several communities composing the State, according to their rank and importance, to accompany their several Heads to the capital and to join in the “palaver,” or discussion, that will take place, the King in person presiding over the deliberations, supported by his own Councillors and principal Linguists. This is the full Parliament of the people, who are thus fully and duly represented in every way from the highest to the lowest. The commands which go forth from this assembly are binding upon every individual family of the entire State, from the most important province to the most insignificant hamlet, and the sanction operates equally upon all.' [788] The paramount executive authority was the Asantehene: 'The King is the Chief Executive Officer of the State, but not the Executive Council of the State. Such a council exists, and any acts done by the King without its concurrence are liable to be set aside.' [789] The attribution of concrete entities to a particular executive level is not always clear, though, especially in the early period: 'The state of the union that emerged after the War of Independence was obviously a very fluid one. The Asanteman is referred to as the Asante Aman Nnum, the Five Asante States, but there is no clear consensus about which states comprised the original union. [...] The fact of the matter seems to have been that the coalition against the Denkyira included what were no more than “estates” on the one hand, like Bekwae, and what were established states on the other, like Mampon, Dwaben, and Kumase itself. Some were to decline and some were to prosper; some were to become powerful components of the Asanteman and some were to become little more than their clients.' [790] Government was organized in a system of stools: 'Every Asante village was a microcosm of the Asante economic, social, and political universe. Its population included both rulers and ruled, both “owners” of the land with the right of succession to the local, divisional, and state stools and free men grouped in other lineages with corporate interests in other political offices.' [791] Chiefship had a sacred character as rulers were thought to have a special connection to the ancestors: 'Chiefship in Ashanti is a sacred office. This has been shown by the rites of the chief's enstoolment and by his part in ceremonies such as have been described. As long as he sits upon the stool of [Page 37] the ancestors his person is sacred. As the successor of the ancestors he performed various rites for the welfare of his people. With that office were joined other functions which may be described as administrative, executive, judicial, and military. If he abused his power, he was divested of it by having his special connexion with his ancestors, established on his enstoolment, severed. This happened when he committed or was made to commit one of the tabooed acts. His sanctity was violated and he was no longer able to sit on the stool of the ancestors. Thus, the Ashanti destool a chief by bumping his buttocks on the ground, or taking his sandals off his feet, or by mutilating his body. After such an act the chief was no longer in special contact with the ancestors, and having lost his sanctity he became automatically divested of all the other functions pertaining to the office of chiefship.' [792]

♠ Rulers control supernatural energy ♣ absent ♥

♠ Rulers are descendants of gods ♣ absent ♥

♠ Rulers become gods after death ♣ absent ♥

♠ Automatic deification ♣ absent ♥

♠ Rulers are gods ♣ absent ♥

Normative Ideological Aspects of Equity and Prosociality[edit]

♠ Ideological reinforcement of equality ♣ absent ♥

♠ Ideological thought equates rulers and commoners ♣ absent ♥
♠ Ideological thought equates elites and commoners ♣ absent ♥
♠ Ideological thought equates all ethnicities ♣ absent ♥
♠ Ideological thought equates men and women ♣ absent ♥
♠ Ideological thought equates people of all locations ♣ absent ♥
♠ Ideological thought distinguishes rulers and commoners ♣ present ♥ Arhin describes the power hierarchy from the village upwards: 'Female stools complemented the hierarchy of male stools. In the village the elders, mpanyinfo, heads of the matrilineages, who constituted with the odekro the village council, had their aberewa or obaapanyin, who looked after the women's affairs. The odekro had an obaapanyin who was responsible for the affairs of the women of the village and was a member of the village council; the ohene, head of a division, and the omanhene, head of the autonomous political community, had their female counterparts known as ohemma, female ruler, who sat on their councils. The ohene and the ohemma were all of the same mogya, blood, or clan. The Asantehemma, the occupant of the female stool of the Kumasi state, and therefore of united Asante, since her male counterpart was ex officio the Asantehene, king of Asante, was a member of the Kotoko council, the executive committee or cabinet of the Asanteman Nhyiamu, general assembly of Asante rulers.' [793] Major and minor chiefs were also summoned to council: 'Where the paramount King of a state summons the Head-Chiefs of provinces and chiefs of minor communities to attend a State Council, it is the privilege of the Councillors of the several communities composing the State, according to their rank and importance, to accompany their several Heads to the capital and to join in the “palaver,” or discussion, that will take place, the King in person presiding over the deliberations, supported by his own Councillors and principal Linguists. This is the full Parliament of the people, who are thus fully and duly represented in every way from the highest to the lowest. The commands which go forth from this assembly are binding upon every individual family of the entire State, from the most important province to the most insignificant hamlet, and the sanction operates equally upon all.' [794] The paramount executive authority was the Asantehene: 'The King is the Chief Executive Officer of the State, but not the Executive Council of the State. Such a council exists, and any acts done by the King without its concurrence are liable to be set aside.' [795] The attribution of concrete entities to a particular executive level is not always clear, though, especially in the early period: 'The state of the union that emerged after the War of Independence was obviously a very fluid one. The Asanteman is referred to as the Asante Aman Nnum, the Five Asante States, but there is no clear consensus about which states comprised the original union. [...] The fact of the matter seems to have been that the coalition against the Denkyira included what were no more than “estates” on the one hand, like Bekwae, and what were established states on the other, like Mampon, Dwaben, and Kumase itself. Some were to decline and some were to prosper; some were to become powerful components of the Asanteman and some were to become little more than their clients.' [796] Government was organized in a system of stools: 'Every Asante village was a microcosm of the Asante economic, social, and political universe. Its population included both rulers and ruled, both “owners” of the land with the right of succession to the local, divisional, and state stools and free men grouped in other lineages with corporate interests in other political offices.' [797] Chiefship had a sacred character as rulers were thought to have a special connection to the ancestors: 'Chiefship in Ashanti is a sacred office. This has been shown by the rites of the chief's enstoolment and by his part in ceremonies such as have been described. As long as he sits upon the stool of [Page 37] the ancestors his person is sacred. As the successor of the ancestors he performed various rites for the welfare of his people. With that office were joined other functions which may be described as administrative, executive, judicial, and military. If he abused his power, he was divested of it by having his special connexion with his ancestors, established on his enstoolment, severed. This happened when he committed or was made to commit one of the tabooed acts. His sanctity was violated and he was no longer able to sit on the stool of the ancestors. Thus, the Ashanti destool a chief by bumping his buttocks on the ground, or taking his sandals off his feet, or by mutilating his body. After such an act the chief was no longer in special contact with the ancestors, and having lost his sanctity he became automatically divested of all the other functions pertaining to the office of chiefship.' [798] Insulting or attacking a ruler was a capital offence: 'Because of the importance of upholding one's name, for both the living and the dead, the greater percentage of quarrels and lawsuits deal with abuse (atendidie); the abuse of the Asantehene is a capital crime. Assult on any type of [Page 53] official might be a capital crime depending on the circumstances. Other capital crimes include treason, a plot to destool without a just cause (epow), stealing (kr[unavailable]no) from a chief, the abosom, the dead, or stealing the first fruits of a harvest prior to the festival. “One of the most terrible sins of which an Asanti could be guilty (Rattray 1929:311) was to curse the Asantehene” (hyira [unavailable]hene), “bless king”), this was considered to be regicide.' [799]
♠ Ideological thought distinguishes elites and commoners ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups rather than castes: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [800] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [801] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [802] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [803] Matrilineages held and transmitted land and political positions: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]' [804] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]' [805] Lineage segments were differentiated along the lines of heritable interest in property: 'Segments: While the lineage as a whole has some corporate concern with sponsoring the funeral of any of its members and with assigning that member's property to an heir, heritable interests in various properties can differentiate lineage members. Subsets of the membership of a lineage — equalling lineage segments — are defined by the existence of any property for which members of the subsets (exclusive of others) are potential heirs. Such sets (subsets of the whole) may range from, at the one extreme, only the actual children of some man's actual sisters (in the case of property that he himself created) to, at the other extreme, all the members of the lineage (in the case of property, in effect, created by the lineage founder). In Egyaa, only chiefly positions fall in the long-lived extreme, while (almost) all other created property (in Egyaa) falls in or near the short-lived extreme. No property in Egyaa falls enough in between the two extremes to matter, but property that survived long enough to be inherited through several generations (but not substantially longer) were such to exist, would create sets of members representing intermediate segments of the lineage's membership.' [806] Slavery was practiced: 'The Akan practiced slavery, obtaining slaves from northern slave dealers, usually Muslims. War captives, criminals, persons who opposed local chiefs, and many local ritual leaders were also enslaved. Slaves were used for domestic and field labor, for sale to traders across the Sahara and Atlantic, and as sacrifices to royal and other ancestors. In the middle of the nineteenth century, slaves amounted to half of the population in many towns. [MG]' [807] Wealthy urban families relied on unfree labour, but wealth stratification had emerged before the colonial period: 'The Portuguese “blueprint” of 1572 associates gold mining, forest clearing, and food production, and implicitly postulates the existence [Page 96] of an appropriating class and a producing class. It is, I suggest, mutatis mutandis, a paradigm of sorts for the early Akan state. Those who controlled the production and sale of gold were those able to procure a supply of unfree labor. Those who procured unfree labor were those able to create arable land within the forest. Those who created the arable were those who founded the numerous early Akan polities. We see, in other words, a class of Akan entrepreneurs emerging: a class of those able to use the strength of the world bullion market, and the availability of labor locally (whether through Wangara or Portuguese suppliers), in such a way as to create the new agrarian system. These entrepreneurs were known as the aberemp[unavailable]n (sing. [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n), literally “big men” but correctly glossed in an early European source as “a superior rich man.” ' [808] 'Akan village histories make frequent reference to hunters ranging the forest in search of land suitable for agricultural exploitation—taking account, presumably, of surface relief, water resources, soil, and so forth. The role of the aberemp[unavailable]n in these explorations is often described in considerable detail. By way of illustration I shall cite the cases of two, Tabiri Heman and Akuamoa Panin.' [809] 'The descendants of free settlers became [unavailable]manmufo, citizens. Those of the proprietors became adehyeε, nobility. There remain the unfree laborers. They must surely be those who became the third major element in the composition of an [unavailable]man, namely the gyaasefo. Literally “the people of the hearth,” they were absorbed into Akan society as servants of the adehyeε. They became responsible not only for their own subsistence but for that of the nobles. They farmed for them, assumed responsibility for their debts, and provided them with a wide range of personal services as stool-carriers, drummers, hornblowers, umbrella-carriers, bathroom attendants, messengers, tradesmen, sextons, and so forth. Their masters (or mistresses) were heirs to their property. Their status, unlike that of nobles and citizens, was transmitted through the male line. Rattray commented on the matter: [Page 100] 'There is little doubt that the Gyasefo were in olden times recruited from the slave class. A “Stool” slave became one of the Gyasefo. The descendants of a Gyase woman were of course considered as Gyasefo, down the female line for all time; not only was this so, but the son of a Gyase man would ordinarily also enter the office to which his father belonged, irrespective of the position of his mother.' [810] 'It is virtually impossible to render such terms as adehyeε, [unavailable]manmufo and gyaasefo into English with the appropriate nuances. Adehyeε may preside over the affairs of anything from villages on the one hand to kingdoms on the other. Their power will rest in no small measure upon the sheer numbers of gyaasefo whose services they command; indeed, this is one index of their rank. In 1936 Oheneba Sakyi Djan manfully struggled with the problem, though with reference to the more southerly forest Akan: 'The term “Gyaase”…applies to the most immediate adherents attached to the household of any important personage. In this instance, even an ordinary well-to-do man (rich man) may have his own Gyaase, so much so that the head of a family (Opanyin or Atrankonnua) or a ruler of a town (Odekro), or a head of a division of a state (Ohene) or the supreme head or king of a state (Omanhene) should necessarily have his own Gyaase-men, and the number of the members constituting the Gyaase of each of the above heads depends on the importance of the party concerned. That is to say, the number of the members of the Gyaase attached to the Ohene's household is by far fewer than that attached to the Omanhene household.' It was all to do with achievement. The fortunes of an [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n depended first on his ability to procure the labor that, the estate established, became his gyaasefo, and second on his ability to attract free settlers to the estate. Measured in these terms the relatively unsuccessful [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n emerged as no more than a village head, an [unavailable]dekuro, and was absorbed in time into the aman (qua state) of his more successful peer, the [unavailable]hene of this or that group of towns and villages, and he in turn into the aman (qua kingdom) of those even more successful. We turn to a consideration of the most successful of all.' [811] 'ON THE BASIS OF HIS observations of Kumase society in 1817, Bowdich became strongly aware of the degree of social stratification present. Of the many indicators of this—housing, diet, hygiene, toiletry, marriage, and so forth —he commented most fully on matters of the household economy:[Page 140] 'the higher class could not support their numerous followers, or the lower their large families, in the city, and therefore employed them in plantations (in which small crooms [villages] were situated) generally within two or three miles of the capital, where their labours not only feed themselves, but supply the wants of the chief, his family, and more immediate suite. The middling orders station their slaves for the same purpose, and also to collect fruit and vegetables for sale, and when their children become numerous, a part are generally sent to be supported by these slaves in the bush.' [812] 'Bowdich's “higher class” would appear to refer to the wealthy citizens, high officeholders for the most part, whose gyaasefo or “retainers” supported them; his “middling orders” to aspirant citizens in the process of creating, through utilization of slaves, their own gyaasefo; and his “lower class” to those who perforce ensured their survival by the use of family labor. If Bowdich may be understood to be suggesting that the commanding morality of metropolitan society was one of upward mobility based on wealth, then he was undoubtedly correct. Had Bowdich remained in Kumase a few months longer, he would have observed that upward mobility was an institutionalized process.' [813] Accordingly, political influence was tied to wealth. New formal titles were created for individuals who gained wealth and thus became part of an emerging 'bourgeoisie': 'Those who attained wealth in Asante were known as the sikafo, “the monied people.” This category subsumed the smaller group of those who acquired fortunes sufficiently substantial for them to seek formal recognition of their achievement. Of these, those able to demonstrate that they had acquired through their own enterprise a modest fortune of 125 peredwans might, with the approval of the Asantehene, obtain the entitlement of wearing in public a specially designed and woven cloth known as nyaw[unavailable]ho, “you have become rich.” It would seem that it was after the acquisition of such a resource in gold dust that the aspirant (and wise) citizen would begin to invest in people and land. The title to be acquired thereby was that of asafohene, an ancient one originally and exclusively meaning “a war captain.” But the title was available at different levels depending upon the number of subjects acquired. As noticed above, Yamoa Ponko gifted to his son, Gyesi Kwame, 100 subjects, and thereby Gyesi Kwame acquired the comparatively low-ranking dignity of an asafohene of the Kyidom Stool. By contrast, in late 1861 or early 1862 the Akyempemhene Owusu Koko, already an occupant of high office in Kumase, nevertheless publicly displayed his three thousand subjects—each in possession of a gun—who must be assumed to have represented self-acquired property. An asafohene able to show command of at least a thousand subjects was entitled not only to wear the nyaw[unavailable]ho cloth but also to have a horse-tail switch ( bodua) carried before him. It was, however, the right to use not the horse-tail but the elephant-tail switch ( mena or mmara) that was the most coveted of all honors—and one carrying with it use of the ancient title of [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n.' [814] 'However many sikafo aspired to the award of the elephant tail, relatively few seem to have achieved it. Three successful nineteenth century claimants are well documented, namely, Gyaasewahene Opoku Frefre (died 1826), Ankobeahene Kwaku Tawia (died ca. 1850), and Manwerehene Kwasi Brantuo (died 1865). There were certainly others. A description of the ceremony surrounding the award was given by the Akyeamehene Kwasi Nuama in 1925. Because it is the fullest account of the procedures known to me, I cite it fully: 'Those chiefs who were allowed to use elephant tails were called Abrempons. A chief who lives on his own land with his own subjects is known by the King as Abrempon. An Abrempon must exhibit his wealth publicly by presenting £9 6s. [i.e., 1 peredwan with supplementary mmataho] to all the Abrempons in Kumase; and 10 peregwans (£80) to the King. He would then go to Tafo and pay £1 6s. to the chief there who would give him an egg to throw against a silk cotton tree. He would then return to Kumasi. He would then go to Essumja Santimanso and buy a carpet ( nsa) for £24 [3 peregwans] from the subjects of the Chief there. He must only dance on it and leave it after presenting Essumjahene with another £24. Your going and coming expenses (including the £48) will cost you some 20 pregwans. He would buy an elephant tail from the Assinhene (son of Essumjahene) for £9 6s. He would tie the elephant tail round the waist of one of his slaves and he must then past [ sic] round the outskirts of the town lying on the leaves of palm trees which have been strewn around the town, firing at his slave with blank fire from time to time. The slave falls down eventually and he then cuts the string to which the tail is fastened and takes the tail—then the ceremonies are completed, and his people applaud him. Next morning he would get mashed yam mixed with 30 peregwans and be carried on a litter round the town of Kumasi scattering largesse of the yam mixture. On the following morning he would be carried in a litter with all his regalia, his skin plastered with white clay. Then he would fix up a spear at Dwebirim (the market place) and challenge those of the same rank to remove it. After this he is called Brempon. On the last day anyone who aspires to the rank of Abrempon takes out the spear and appoints a time for performing the same ceremonies.' The Akyeamehene thus identified six stages in the ceremony. The first, the payments to the aberemp[unavailable]n of the capital and to the Asantehene, requires little comment. In the early nineteenth century Hutchison noted that the first step was, for obvious reasons, taken only “by those who are in favour with the King, and think themselves safe from palavers.” The second and third stages, the visits to Tafo and Asantemanso, involved the candidate in ancient rituals the nature of which will not be [Page 142] examined here; suffice to remind the reader that Tafo was an old (“aboriginal”) trading center, and Asantemanso one of the “cradles” of the Akan.' [815] 'The fourth stage of the ceremony, that of catching of the “elephant,” was, by a fortunate chance, once witnessed by the missionary W. West on his visit to Kumase with Owusu Ansa in 1862. Although West does not name the candidate, one may be reasonably confident that it was the Kumase Manwerehene, Kwasi Brantuo. On March 29 West noted the arrival of several dignitaries in Kumase, “to take part in the ceremony, which was that of the display of wealth, by an old chief, in order to be entitled to the honour of having the elephant's tail carried before him; an honour to which only the wealthy can aspire.” he actual charade occurred the next day: 'A slave had been selected to enact the part of the elephant. Besmeared all over with chalk, holding in his hand a small tusk, which he occasionally applied to his mouth, and having an elephant's tail attached by a piece of string behind, he was started off; while some forty or fifty men, armed with muskets, and supplied with blank cartridges, followed in pursuit, keeping up an almost constant fire. His elephantship as we were informed, made his way, according to usage, to a small kroom [village] not far from Kumasi, where he fell down as if shot, and lay there until the chief himself appeared to cut off the tail; who, having thus hunted the elephant, and possessed himself of its caudal appendage, was considered, as I suppose, entitled to have it borne before him.' The “kroom” near Kumase at which the chase ended was, seemingly, a parcel of land that the Akwamuhene donated to aspirant aberemp[unavailable]n. Kwasi Brantuo was, in fact, given the Adiebeba lands in 1862 by the Kumase Akwamuhene Akwawua Dente; and Opoku Frefre, whose candidacy will be referred to next, was awarded the Daakwadwam lands by Akwawua Dente's forerunner in office, Kwakye Kofi.' [816] 'IN THE COURSE OF HIS VISIT to Kumase in 1817, Bowdich testified unambiguously to the connection between office and wealth. “The chiefs,” he wrote, 'are fed bountifully by the labours of their slaves, and sharing large sums of the revenue (the fines their oppression has imposed on other governments), with incalculable fees for corruption or interference, refine upon the splendour of equipage even to satiety, and still possess a large surplus of income daily accumulating' Bowdich was, however, also aware of the prejudice that existed, on the part of the older aristocratic families whose fortunes had been consolidated during the wars of expansion in the earlier eighteenth century, against the parvenu rich whose profits derived principally from trade. Bowdich recorded what was clearly a partisan view of the issue. Of the encouragement of trade, he commented, 'their government would repress rather than countenance the inclination (believing no state can be aggrandized but by conquest), lest their genius for war might be enervated by it, and lest, either from the merchants increasing to a body too formidable for their wishes to be resisted, or too artful from their experience to be detected, they might sacrifice the national honour and ambition to their avarice, and furnishing Inta [Gonja], Dagwumba [Dagomba], or any of their more powerful neighbours (who have yielded to circumstances rather than force) with guns and powder (which are never to be exported from Ashantee), break the spell of their conquests, and undermine their powers.' Again, David Hume's general observations on the development of a merchant class are highly pertinent: 'This perhaps is the chief advantage which arises from commerce with strangers. It rouses men from their indolence; and presenting the gayer and more opulent part of the nation with objects of luxury, which they never before dreamed of, raises in them a desire of a more splendid way of life than what their ancestors enjoyed. And at the same time, the few merchants, who possess the secret of this importation and exportation, make great profits; and becoming rivals in wealth to the ancient nobility, tempt other adventurers to become their rivals in commerce.' [Page 152] Bowdich's report of the views of the Asante nobility appears to echo Hume: 'Were they to encourage commerce, pomp, the idol of which they are most jealous, would soon cease to be their prerogative, because it would be attainable by others; the traders growing wealthy, would vie with them; and for their own security, stimulated by reflections they have now too little at risk to originate, they would unite to repress the arbitrary power of the Aristocracy; and even if they did not, inevitably (as the chiefs conceive) divert the people's genius for war.' [817] 'It would be easy to regard such appointees, collectively, as constituting a collaborating class. But one of the purposes of this essay has been to suggest that such a concept is of little analytical importance. It has been shown that those who were to collaborate with the colonial authorities had adopted ideological positions sharply divergent from the prevailing political mores long before the loss of Asante independence could have been foreseen. It has been suggested here that in the last quarter of the nineteenth century the fundamental challenge to the dominant mercantile ideology in Asante was presented by an embryonic bourgeoisie committed to the principles of laissez faire and that no analysis of the acute political conflicts which divided the Asante nation in that period is possible without reference to such ideological factors. Moreover, the history of the Gold Coast and of Ghana in the twentieth century can be understood, I believe, only with adequate reference to the nineteenth-century situation. The development of the cocoa industry represented, perhaps, the triumph of a new bourgeoisie “liberated” by the forces of colonialism. The economic policies of Kwame Nkrumah are to be seen as in many respects reviving those of Mensa Bonsu and Agyeman Prempeh, recognizing that the rapid development of the national economy must necessarily involve, albeit on mutually acceptable terms, the participation of foreign capital and expertise. The policies of Kofi Busia appeared designed, conversely, to stimulate the growth of the indigenous middle class. Subsequent governments have vacillated between these alternative paths to salvation.' [818] While attributing class structures to non-capitalist economies is difficult, Wilks distinguishes between 'nobles', an emerging urban 'bourgeoisie', free farmers, and unfree servants: 'It is notoriously difficult to characterize the class structure of precapitalist societies. To this generalization Asante is no exception, though R. A. Kea's studies of a number of seventeenth century Akan polities have provided an invaluable lead. For present purposes the postulate is that a class reproduces itself as a class and that it does so only insofar as it has a determinate and specific, though not necessarily direct, relationship to the means of production. Consider, for example, the Asante class of the adehyeε, a word commonly but inappropriately translated [Page 294] “royalty” in English. “The old adage” (and I quote the collective wisdom of the late Asantehene and his councillors in a judgment passed down in 1964) “is that a royal is one whose ancestor had established or founded a village." This succinct statement of traditional usage defines a class within Asante society by implicit reference to a set of proprietary rights over land exercised by those who were thereby able to appropriate, in the form of tributes, taxes, and services, part of the labor-value of others settled on the land. I have elsewhere suggested that the origins of the adehyeε class are to be sought in the context of the great economic transformations associated with the development of forest agriculture. I have also suggested that the gyaasefo emerged as a servile class in precisely the same context. In this chapter I argue that the asomfo, or those in administrative service, came to constitute a class within Asante society in precisely the same sense of class.
