♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ present ♥ "One of the earliest European accounts of Asante, in 1701, already alludes to the sacrifice of captives taken in war.92 The earliest contemporary sources suggesting an especial extravagance of scale of human sacrifice in Asante, however, is a report of 1797 claiming that between 1,400 and 1,500 people had been sacrificed for the funerals of the royal princes, an excess which allegedly provoked a popular rebellion.93 The funeral of the mother of an Asante king in 1809 is said to have been marked by the sacri- fice of no less than 3,000 human victims, over 2,000 of whom were prisoners of war.94 These accounts, based on hearsay, are very probably exaggerated, but the earliest detailed first-hand descriptions of Asante, produced by British missions to the capital Kumase in 1817 and 1820, con- firm the practice of human sacrifice on an extravagant scale. Human sacrifices were offered at private as well as at royal funerals, and also to gods to ensure the success of Asante military operations and on occasions of national disaster. In addition, human victims were killed at regular Asante festivals, such as the annual Yam festival (Odwira), which involved over 100 deaths a year, and the monthly Adae Festival, at which over 70 people were killed on one occasion in 1820.95 Richard Burton, seeking to defend Dahomey against charges of excess in these matters in the 1860s, could reasonably claim that Asante was worse." [929]
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ inferred present ♥ "One of the earliest European accounts of Asante, in 1701, already alludes to the sacrifice of captives taken in war.92 The earliest contemporary sources suggesting an especial extravagance of scale of human sacrifice in Asante, however, is a report of 1797 claiming that between 1,400 and 1,500 people had been sacrificed for the funerals of the royal princes, an excess which allegedly provoked a popular rebellion.93 The funeral of the mother of an Asante king in 1809 is said to have been marked by the sacri- fice of no less than 3,000 human victims, over 2,000 of whom were prisoners of war.94 These accounts, based on hearsay, are very probably exaggerated, but the earliest detailed first-hand descriptions of Asante, produced by British missions to the capital Kumase in 1817 and 1820, con- firm the practice of human sacrifice on an extravagant scale. Human sacrifices were offered at private as well as at royal funerals, and also to gods to ensure the success of Asante military operations and on occasions of national disaster. In addition, human victims were killed at regular Asante festivals, such as the annual Yam festival (Odwira), which involved over 100 deaths a year, and the monthly Adae Festival, at which over 70 people were killed on one occasion in 1820.95 Richard Burton, seeking to defend Dahomey against charges of excess in these matters in the 1860s, could reasonably claim that Asante was worse." [930] In the exaggerated statement of 3,000 victims, we can infer that those who were not captives were slaves: "Seventeenth century sources refer frequently to the practice of human sacrifice, especially of slaves, at the funerals of chiefs and important men in the coastal kingdoms,89 and there is one report also of the sacrifice of captives taken in war to a god.90 Doubtless human sacrifice was practised in the interior at this period also. But nothing suggests that human sacrifice in this area had attained any especially grand scale before the rise of Asante." [931]
♠ human sacrifice of a low-status individual ♣ inferred present ♥ "One of the earliest European accounts of Asante, in 1701, already alludes to the sacrifice of captives taken in war.92 The earliest contemporary sources suggesting an especial extravagance of scale of human sacrifice in Asante, however, is a report of 1797 claiming that between 1,400 and 1,500 people had been sacrificed for the funerals of the royal princes, an excess which allegedly provoked a popular rebellion.93 The funeral of the mother of an Asante king in 1809 is said to have been marked by the sacri- fice of no less than 3,000 human victims, over 2,000 of whom were prisoners of war.94 These accounts, based on hearsay, are very probably exaggerated, but the earliest detailed first-hand descriptions of Asante, produced by British missions to the capital Kumase in 1817 and 1820, con- firm the practice of human sacrifice on an extravagant scale. Human sacrifices were offered at private as well as at royal funerals, and also to gods to ensure the success of Asante military operations and on occasions of national disaster. In addition, human victims were killed at regular Asante festivals, such as the annual Yam festival (Odwira), which involved over 100 deaths a year, and the monthly Adae Festival, at which over 70 people were killed on one occasion in 1820.95 Richard Burton, seeking to defend Dahomey against charges of excess in these matters in the 1860s, could reasonably claim that Asante was worse." [932] In the exaggerated statement of 3,000 victims, we can infer that those who were not captives were slaves: "Seventeenth century sources refer frequently to the practice of human sacrifice, especially of slaves, at the funerals of chiefs and important men in the coastal kingdoms,89 and there is one report also of the sacrifice of captives taken in war to a god.90 Doubtless human sacrifice was practised in the interior at this period also. But nothing suggests that human sacrifice in this area had attained any especially grand scale before the rise of Asante." [933]
♠ human sacrifice of a criminal ♣ inferred absent ♥ "One of the earliest European accounts of Asante, in 1701, already alludes to the sacrifice of captives taken in war.92 The earliest contemporary sources suggesting an especial extravagance of scale of human sacrifice in Asante, however, is a report of 1797 claiming that between 1,400 and 1,500 people had been sacrificed for the funerals of the royal princes, an excess which allegedly provoked a popular rebellion.93 The funeral of the mother of an Asante king in 1809 is said to have been marked by the sacri- fice of no less than 3,000 human victims, over 2,000 of whom were prisoners of war.94 These accounts, based on hearsay, are very probably exaggerated, but the earliest detailed first-hand descriptions of Asante, produced by British missions to the capital Kumase in 1817 and 1820, con- firm the practice of human sacrifice on an extravagant scale. Human sacrifices were offered at private as well as at royal funerals, and also to gods to ensure the success of Asante military operations and on occasions of national disaster. In addition, human victims were killed at regular Asante festivals, such as the annual Yam festival (Odwira), which involved over 100 deaths a year, and the monthly Adae Festival, at which over 70 people were killed on one occasion in 1820.95 Richard Burton, seeking to defend Dahomey against charges of excess in these matters in the 1860s, could reasonably claim that Asante was worse." [934] In the exaggerated statement of 3,000 victims, we can infer that those who were not captives were slaves: "Seventeenth century sources refer frequently to the practice of human sacrifice, especially of slaves, at the funerals of chiefs and important men in the coastal kingdoms,89 and there is one report also of the sacrifice of captives taken in war to a god.90 Doubtless human sacrifice was practised in the interior at this period also. But nothing suggests that human sacrifice in this area had attained any especially grand scale before the rise of Asante." [935]
♠ human sacrifice of a high status individual ♣ inferred absent ♥ "One of the earliest European accounts of Asante, in 1701, already alludes to the sacrifice of captives taken in war.92 The earliest contemporary sources suggesting an especial extravagance of scale of human sacrifice in Asante, however, is a report of 1797 claiming that between 1,400 and 1,500 people had been sacrificed for the funerals of the royal princes, an excess which allegedly provoked a popular rebellion.93 The funeral of the mother of an Asante king in 1809 is said to have been marked by the sacri- fice of no less than 3,000 human victims, over 2,000 of whom were prisoners of war.94 These accounts, based on hearsay, are very probably exaggerated, but the earliest detailed first-hand descriptions of Asante, produced by British missions to the capital Kumase in 1817 and 1820, con- firm the practice of human sacrifice on an extravagant scale. Human sacrifices were offered at private as well as at royal funerals, and also to gods to ensure the success of Asante military operations and on occasions of national disaster. In addition, human victims were killed at regular Asante festivals, such as the annual Yam festival (Odwira), which involved over 100 deaths a year, and the monthly Adae Festival, at which over 70 people were killed on one occasion in 1820.95 Richard Burton, seeking to defend Dahomey against charges of excess in these matters in the 1860s, could reasonably claim that Asante was worse." [936] In the exaggerated statement of 3,000 victims, we can infer that those who were not captives were slaves: "Seventeenth century sources refer frequently to the practice of human sacrifice, especially of slaves, at the funerals of chiefs and important men in the coastal kingdoms,89 and there is one report also of the sacrifice of captives taken in war to a god.90 Doubtless human sacrifice was practised in the interior at this period also. But nothing suggests that human sacrifice in this area had attained any especially grand scale before the rise of Asante." [937]
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ inferred absent ♥ "One of the earliest European accounts of Asante, in 1701, already alludes to the sacrifice of captives taken in war.92 The earliest contemporary sources suggesting an especial extravagance of scale of human sacrifice in Asante, however, is a report of 1797 claiming that between 1,400 and 1,500 people had been sacrificed for the funerals of the royal princes, an excess which allegedly provoked a popular rebellion.93 The funeral of the mother of an Asante king in 1809 is said to have been marked by the sacri- fice of no less than 3,000 human victims, over 2,000 of whom were prisoners of war.94 These accounts, based on hearsay, are very probably exaggerated, but the earliest detailed first-hand descriptions of Asante, produced by British missions to the capital Kumase in 1817 and 1820, con- firm the practice of human sacrifice on an extravagant scale. Human sacrifices were offered at private as well as at royal funerals, and also to gods to ensure the success of Asante military operations and on occasions of national disaster. In addition, human victims were killed at regular Asante festivals, such as the annual Yam festival (Odwira), which involved over 100 deaths a year, and the monthly Adae Festival, at which over 70 people were killed on one occasion in 1820.95 Richard Burton, seeking to defend Dahomey against charges of excess in these matters in the 1860s, could reasonably claim that Asante was worse." [938] In the exaggerated statement of 3,000 victims, we can infer that those who were not captives were slaves: "Seventeenth century sources refer frequently to the practice of human sacrifice, especially of slaves, at the funerals of chiefs and important men in the coastal kingdoms,89 and there is one report also of the sacrifice of captives taken in war to a god.90 Doubtless human sacrifice was practised in the interior at this period also. But nothing suggests that human sacrifice in this area had attained any especially grand scale before the rise of Asante." [939]
♠ human sacrifice of other ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Maximum known number of victims in a HS event ♣ 70 ♥ "One of the earliest European accounts of Asante, in 1701, already alludes to the sacrifice of captives taken in war.92 The earliest contemporary sources suggesting an especial extravagance of scale of human sacrifice in Asante, however, is a report of 1797 claiming that between 1,400 and 1,500 people had been sacrificed for the funerals of the royal princes, an excess which allegedly provoked a popular rebellion.93 The funeral of the mother of an Asante king in 1809 is said to have been marked by the sacrifice of no less than 3,000 human victims, over 2,000 of whom were prisoners of war.94 These accounts, based on hearsay, are very probably exaggerated, but the earliest detailed first-hand descriptions of Asante, produced by British missions to the capital Kumase in 1817 and 1820, confirm the practice of human sacrifice on an extravagant scale. Human sacrifices were offered at private as well as at royal funerals, and also to gods to ensure the success of Asante military operations and on occasions of national disaster. In addition, human victims were killed at regular Asante festivals, such as the annual Yam festival (Odwira), which involved over 100 deaths a year, and the monthly Adae Festival, at which over 70 people were killed on one occasion in 1820.95 Richard Burton, seeking to defend Dahomey against charges of excess in these matters in the 1860s, could reasonably claim that Asante was worse." [940]
♠ Capital Punishment for Religious Offenses ♣ inferred present ♥ "Wilks makes an interesting attempt to assimilate the practice of human sacrifice in Asante to a recognisable European custom, by arguing that what European visitors to Asante interpreted as sacrifices were really no more than public executions." [941] "Also clearly distinct from human sacrifice, though also very common in West Africa, is the execution of witches, or more accurately the death of witches through trial by ordeal, commonly administered in the form of poison. This practice is easily confounded with human sacrifice, since it tended to occur on a large scale in the context of funerals, when there were suspicions that the deceased had been killed by witchcraft. But since it involves punishment for a supposed offence, rather than killing for a religious or ritual purpose, it is evidently conceptually distinct from human sacrifice. It is also likely to affect a different range of victims, and vari- ations in its incidence may have to be explained by other factors than those affecting human sacrifice." [942]
♠ Capital Punishment for Witchcraft ♣ ♥
♠ Influential figure forbids human sacrifice for in-group member ♣ {absent; present}: 1701-1874 CE; present: 1875-1895 CE ♥ "In Asante also, disputes over human sacrifice played some role in the deposition of two kings during the eighteenth century, but the details are far from being clear. King Kusi Obodum, who was deposed in 1764, is said by one traditional account to have alienated his chiefs and people by forbidding human sacrifices. This, however, is probably a misunderstanding: other accounts stress rather Kusi Obodum's lack of military success, and it seems likely therefore that the true complaint against him (as against Adandozan in Dahomey in 1818) was that he was failing to secure sufficient war captives for sacrifice, rather than that he had banned sacrifices. A similar ambiguity surrounds the disputes which led to the deposition of King Osei Kwame in 1798. A contemporary report of 1797 states that the killing of excessive numbers of people for the funerals of two Asante princes had led to a rebellion against Osei Kwame, which was ended by an agreement that 'the king may no longer kill or sacrifice anyone', but that convicted criminals should instead be sold as slaves at the coast.157 Here again, however, it seems improbable that this was really a total abolition of human sacrifice (far less of capital punishment), and more likely that it was an attempt to impose limitations and controls on the practice, perhaps specifically to restrict the sacrifice of free citizens. Moreover, an account of these disputes recorded a generation later gives a quite different account, which makes the king rather than his subjects the initiator of reform. This claims that Osei Kwame was deposed for his attachment to Islam, which had led him to prohibit many religious festivals involving human sacrifice, although he still continued to offer human victims to the royal ancestors. This suggests that Osei Kwame was not so much seeking to suppress human sacrifice altogether, as to concentrate its practice upon the cult of the royal ancestors. On this supposition, the to accounts may perhaps be reconciled: Osei Kwame, it may be suggested, sought to enhance royal power by prohibiting or reducing human sacrifice for the non-ancestral cults, while the opposition in turn sought to impose limits on the ancestral sacrifices. What was at issue was not the legitimacy of human sacrifice as such, but rather the rival claims for victims of the royal ancestor cult and the cults of the gods, which in turn expressed the tension between royal and chiefly power. The situation which arose in Asante in the aftermath of the British punitive expedition against it in 1874 is somewhat clearer. There was then a move to abolish human sacrifice, as was required by the treaty of 1874, and laws to this effect were promulgated in 1876 and 1881. The practical effect of these laws seems to have been, in 1876 to restrict sacrifices to convicted murderers, and in 1881 to abolish public executions at religious ceremonies. In part, of course, these reforms were merely a response to British pressure, born out of a desire for better relations with the British. As the king of Asante himself explained in a letter to the British authorities in 1876: 'The King and people knowing very well that human sacrifice is distressing to the feelings of whitemen, and that their friendship will not go well with them while they keep up that custom, they determined to abolish it'. 160 But more than this was involved. It appears from Ivor Wilks' work that the issue of human sacrifice served as a symbol in a struggle between modernizers and traditionalists in late nineteenth century Asante, between those who supported and those who opposed the reshaping of Asante institutions and values on the model of those of Europe. The discontinuation of the sacrifice of war captives implicit in the law of 1876 served specifically to symbolize the renunciation of the militarist (or, in Wilks' own term, 'imperialist') policies which had earlier been dominant in Asante, but which had been decisively discredited by the defeat of 1874." [943]
♠ Influential figure forbids human sacrifice universally ♣ {absent; present}: 1701-1874 CE; present: 1875-1895 CE ♥ "In Asante also, disputes over human sacrifice played some role in the deposition of two kings during the eighteenth century, but the details are far from being clear. King Kusi Obodum, who was deposed in 1764, is said by one traditional account to have alienated his chiefs and people by forbidding human sacrifices. This, however, is probably a misunderstanding: other accounts stress rather Kusi Obodum's lack of military success, and it seems likely therefore that the true complaint against him (as against Adandozan in Dahomey in 1818) was that he was failing to secure sufficient war captives for sacrifice, rather than that he had banned sacrifices. A similar ambiguity surrounds the disputes which led to the deposition of King Osei Kwame in 1798. A contemporary report of 1797 states that the killing of excessive numbers of people for the funerals of two Asante princes had led to a rebellion against Osei Kwame, which was ended by an agreement that 'the king may no longer kill or sacrifice anyone', but that convicted criminals should instead be sold as slaves at the coast.157 Here again, however, it seems improbable that this was really a total abolition of human sacrifice (far less of capital punishment), and more likely that it was an attempt to impose limitations and controls on the practice, perhaps specifically to restrict the sacrifice of free citizens. Moreover, an account of these disputes recorded a generation later gives a quite different account, which makes the king rather than his subjects the initiator of reform. This claims that Osei Kwame was deposed for his attachment to Islam, which had led him to prohibit many religious festivals involving human sacrifice, although he still continued to offer human victims to the royal ancestors. This suggests that Osei Kwame was not so much seeking to suppress human sacrifice altogether, as to concentrate its practice upon the cult of the royal ancestors. On this supposition, the to accounts may perhaps be reconciled: Osei Kwame, it may be suggested, sought to enhance royal power by prohibiting or reducing human sacrifice for the non-ancestral cults, while the opposition in turn sought to impose limits on the ancestral sacrifices. What was at issue was not the legitimacy of human sacrifice as such, but rather the rival claims for victims of the royal ancestor cult and the cults of the gods, which in turn expressed the tension between royal and chiefly power. The situation which arose in Asante in the aftermath of the British punitive expedition against it in 1874 is somewhat clearer. There was then a move to abolish human sacrifice, as was required by the treaty of 1874, and laws to this effect were promulgated in 1876 and 1881. The practical effect of these laws seems to have been, in 1876 to restrict sacrifices to convicted murderers, and in 1881 to abolish public executions at religious ceremonies. In part, of course, these reforms were merely a response to British pressure, born out of a desire for better relations with the British. As the king of Asante himself explained in a letter to the British authorities in 1876: 'The King and people knowing very well that human sacrifice is distressing to the feelings of whitemen, and that their friendship will not go well with them while they keep up that custom, they determined to abolish it'. 160 But more than this was involved. It appears from Ivor Wilks' work that the issue of human sacrifice served as a symbol in a struggle between modernizers and traditionalists in late nineteenth century Asante, between those who supported and those who opposed the reshaping of Asante institutions and values on the model of those of Europe. The discontinuation of the sacrifice of war captives implicit in the law of 1876 served specifically to symbolize the renunciation of the militarist (or, in Wilks' own term, 'imperialist') policies which had earlier been dominant in Asante, but which had been decisively discredited by the defeat of 1874." [944]
♠ Official cult forbids human sacrifice for in-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ "In Asante also, disputes over human sacrifice played some role in the deposition of two kings during the eighteenth century, but the details are far from being clear. King Kusi Obodum, who was deposed in 1764, is said by one traditional account to have alienated his chiefs and people by forbidding human sacrifices. This, however, is probably a misunderstanding: other accounts stress rather Kusi Obodum's lack of military success, and it seems likely therefore that the true complaint against him (as against Adandozan in Dahomey in 1818) was that he was failing to secure sufficient war captives for sacrifice, rather than that he had banned sacrifices. A similar ambiguity surrounds the disputes which led to the deposition of King Osei Kwame in 1798. A contemporary report of 1797 states that the killing of excessive numbers of people for the funerals of two Asante princes had led to a rebellion against Osei Kwame, which was ended by an agreement that 'the king may no longer kill or sacrifice anyone', but that convicted criminals should instead be sold as slaves at the coast.157 Here again, however, it seems improbable that this was really a total abolition of human sacrifice (far less of capital punishment), and more likely that it was an attempt to impose limitations and controls on the practice, perhaps specifically to restrict the sacrifice of free citizens. Moreover, an account of these disputes recorded a generation later gives a quite different account, which makes the king rather than his subjects the initiator of reform. This claims that Osei Kwame was deposed for his attachment to Islam, which had led him to prohibit many religious festivals involving human sacrifice, although he still continued to offer human victims to the royal ancestors. This suggests that Osei Kwame was not so much seeking to suppress human sacrifice altogether, as to concentrate its practice upon the cult of the royal ancestors. On this supposition, the to accounts may perhaps be reconciled: Osei Kwame, it may be suggested, sought to enhance royal power by prohibiting or reducing human sacrifice for the non-ancestral cults, while the opposition in turn sought to impose limits on the ancestral sacrifices. What was at issue was not the legitimacy of human sacrifice as such, but rather the rival claims for victims of the royal ancestor cult and the cults of the gods, which in turn expressed the tension between royal and chiefly power. The situation which arose in Asante in the aftermath of the British punitive expedition against it in 1874 is somewhat clearer. There was then a move to abolish human sacrifice, as was required by the treaty of 1874, and laws to this effect were promulgated in 1876 and 1881. The practical effect of these laws seems to have been, in 1876 to restrict sacrifices to convicted murderers, and in 1881 to abolish public executions at religious ceremonies. In part, of course, these reforms were merely a response to British pressure, born out of a desire for better relations with the British. As the king of Asante himself explained in a letter to the British authorities in 1876: 'The King and people knowing very well that human sacrifice is distressing to the feelings of whitemen, and that their friendship will not go well with them while they keep up that custom, they determined to abolish it'. 160 But more than this was involved. It appears from Ivor Wilks' work that the issue of human sacrifice served as a symbol in a struggle between modernizers and traditionalists in late nineteenth century Asante, between those who supported and those who opposed the reshaping of Asante institutions and values on the model of those of Europe. The discontinuation of the sacrifice of war captives implicit in the law of 1876 served specifically to symbolize the renunciation of the militarist (or, in Wilks' own term, 'imperialist') policies which had earlier been dominant in Asante, but which had been decisively discredited by the defeat of 1874." [945] The official cult did not prohibit it, but other practical reasons, including an alliance with the British, made the prohibition politically desirable.
♠ Official cult forbids human sacrifice universally ♣ inferred absent ♥ "In Asante also, disputes over human sacrifice played some role in the deposition of two kings during the eighteenth century, but the details are far from being clear. King Kusi Obodum, who was deposed in 1764, is said by one traditional account to have alienated his chiefs and people by forbidding human sacrifices. This, however, is probably a misunderstanding: other accounts stress rather Kusi Obodum's lack of military success, and it seems likely therefore that the true complaint against him (as against Adandozan in Dahomey in 1818) was that he was failing to secure sufficient war captives for sacrifice, rather than that he had banned sacrifices. A similar ambiguity surrounds the disputes which led to the deposition of King Osei Kwame in 1798. A contemporary report of 1797 states that the killing of excessive numbers of people for the funerals of two Asante princes had led to a rebellion against Osei Kwame, which was ended by an agreement that 'the king may no longer kill or sacrifice anyone', but that convicted criminals should instead be sold as slaves at the coast.157 Here again, however, it seems improbable that this was really a total abolition of human sacrifice (far less of capital punishment), and more likely that it was an attempt to impose limitations and controls on the practice, perhaps specifically to restrict the sacrifice of free citizens. Moreover, an account of these disputes recorded a generation later gives a quite different account, which makes the king rather than his subjects the initiator of reform. This claims that Osei Kwame was deposed for his attachment to Islam, which had led him to prohibit many religious festivals involving human sacrifice, although he still continued to offer human victims to the royal ancestors. This suggests that Osei Kwame was not so much seeking to suppress human sacrifice altogether, as to concentrate its practice upon the cult of the royal ancestors. On this supposition, the to accounts may perhaps be reconciled: Osei Kwame, it may be suggested, sought to enhance royal power by prohibiting or reducing human sacrifice for the non-ancestral cults, while the opposition in turn sought to impose limits on the ancestral sacrifices. What was at issue was not the legitimacy of human sacrifice as such, but rather the rival claims for victims of the royal ancestor cult and the cults of the gods, which in turn expressed the tension between royal and chiefly power. The situation which arose in Asante in the aftermath of the British punitive expedition against it in 1874 is somewhat clearer. There was then a move to abolish human sacrifice, as was required by the treaty of 1874, and laws to this effect were promulgated in 1876 and 1881. The practical effect of these laws seems to have been, in 1876 to restrict sacrifices to convicted murderers, and in 1881 to abolish public executions at religious ceremonies. In part, of course, these reforms were merely a response to British pressure, born out of a desire for better relations with the British. As the king of Asante himself explained in a letter to the British authorities in 1876: 'The King and people knowing very well that human sacrifice is distressing to the feelings of whitemen, and that their friendship will not go well with them while they keep up that custom, they determined to abolish it'. 160 But more than this was involved. It appears from Ivor Wilks' work that the issue of human sacrifice served as a symbol in a struggle between modernizers and traditionalists in late nineteenth century Asante, between those who supported and those who opposed the reshaping of Asante institutions and values on the model of those of Europe. The discontinuation of the sacrifice of war captives implicit in the law of 1876 served specifically to symbolize the renunciation of the militarist (or, in Wilks' own term, 'imperialist') policies which had earlier been dominant in Asante, but which had been decisively discredited by the defeat of 1874." [946] The official cult did not prohibit it, but other practical reasons, including an alliance with the British, made the prohibition politically desirable.

Moralizing Supernatural Powers[edit]

♠ Moral concern is primary ♣ inferred absent ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is certain ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing norms are broad ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is targeted ♣ inferred present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement of rulers ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing religion adopted by elites ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing religion adopted by commoners ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement in afterlife ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement in this life ♣ inferred present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is agentic ♣ present ♥

These data were reviewed by expert advisors and consultants. For a detailed description of these data, refer to the relevant Analytic Narratives, reference tables, and acknowledgements page. [947] [948] [949]

Normative Ideological precepts concerning morality/supernatural beings[edit]

Supernatural beings (e.g., gods, spirits, ancestors)

♠ Number of officially sanctioned supernatural beings ♣ polytheistic ♥ The pantheon was made up of an omnipotent, omnipresent and omniscient high/creator god as well as various other deities, spirits and ancestors. eHRAF provides the following summary: 'Indigenous Akan religion is based upon the worship of a High God, various spirits or deities, and ancestors. The High God-known as Onyame, Onyankopon, and by other names-is the Creator, now otiose; Asase Yaa, the goddess of the earth, accompanies him. The ancestors live in the land of the dead and may demand offerings, in the past including those of slaves.'[950] It is unclear how many spirits and gods there were, which is partly due to the fact that different towns and other localities had their own gods. We have focused on the ‘native’ religion, not converts to Christianity.
♠ Omnipresent supernatural beings ♣ present ♥ 'The various strong, or “praise,” names of Onyankopon better indicate his nature or his divine characteristics. He is Totarobonsu, that is to say, “he pours and pours, and the waters are made.” He is never dried up. Another strong name of Onyankopon Kwame is Abommubuwafre, that is to say, “he is the one who when lamentation or weeping comes upon you, you call upon.” When thus called upon, he answers you. Another strong name of Onyankopon is Nya-amane-kose, that is to say, “he is the one to whom if you report (or tell) any need or trouble, he is able to help you.” Onyankopon Kwame's further strong name is Brckyirihuade, that is to say, “he is the one who knows what is happening in his presence as well as behind his back.” He is the knower of the universe of things.'[951]
♠ Omniscient supernatural beings ♣ inferred present ♥ The following quote suggests that the creator god had some form of omniscience, but it is not clear that it was the sort of omniscience that allowed him to look into people's thoughts. 'The various strong, or “praise,” names of Onyankopon better indicate his nature or his divine characteristics. He is Totarobonsu, that is to say, “he pours and pours, and the waters are made.” He is never dried up. Another strong name of Onyankopon Kwame is Abommubuwafre, that is to say, “he is the one who when lamentation or weeping comes upon you, you call upon.” When thus called upon, he answers you. Another strong name of Onyankopon is Nya-amane-kose, that is to say, “he is the one to whom if you report (or tell) any need or trouble, he is able to help you.” Onyankopon Kwame's further strong name is Brckyirihuade, that is to say, “he is the one who knows what is happening in his presence as well as behind his back.” He is the knower of the universe of things.'[952]
♠ Omnipotent supernatural beings ♣ present ♥ 'In three specific ways Onyankopon is Nana. First, that he is Creator; it was he who made all men, and all men are his children. He made mother and mother gave birth to you, and he is therefore your Nana. In the second place, Onyankopon is Nana because he provides all that man needs for existence; that in the farm and that in the house; that in the field and that in the water; that for conduct and that for life; all are obtained from God, and therefore he is Nana. In the third place: as our drummers know how to indicate, whether we are alive or whether we die, we depend upon Onyankopon. He protects us from all manner of troubles—national troubles, family troubles and troubles of existence, he it is to whom we run for safety, he is the one who saves our lives, he it is who is our supreme commander. He is supremely the Great Being in all these cases, and he is therefore greater even than the Ohene.'[953] 'The various strong, or “praise,” names of Onyankopon better indicate his nature or his divine characteristics. He is Totarobonsu, that is to say, “he pours and pours, and the waters are made.” He is never dried up. Another strong name of Onyankopon Kwame is Abommubuwafre, that is to say, “he is the one who when lamentation or weeping comes upon you, you call upon.” When thus called upon, he answers you. Another strong name of Onyankopon is Nya-amane-kose, that is to say, “he is the one to whom if you report (or tell) any need or trouble, he is able to help you.” Onyankopon Kwame's further strong name is Brckyirihuade, that is to say, “he is the one who knows what is happening in his presence as well as behind his back.” He is the knower of the universe of things.'[954]
♠ High Gods (creator gods) ♣ moralizing ♥ Onyankopon created and governs the cosmos: this is clearly expressed in the first two of the following four quotes. The third and fourth clearly show that only those who follow obra (good conduct; e.g. reciprocity, mutual aid) join the Nana (ancestors) in the afterlife, and the third one implies (but, it should be noted, does not state clearly) that Onyankopon decides who has followed obra when it says that the Nana 'show the right way in which mortal man should live so as to come to the Supreme Being.' 'In three specific ways Onyankopon is Nana. First, that he is Creator; it was he who made all men, and all men are his children. He made mother and mother gave birth to you, and he is therefore your Nana. In the second place, Onyankopon is Nana because he provides all that man needs for existence; that in the farm and that in the house; that in the field and that in the water; that for conduct and that for life; all are obtained from God, and therefore he is Nana. In the third place: as our drummers know how to indicate, whether we are alive or whether we die, we depend upon Onyankopon. He protects us from all manner of troubles—national troubles, family troubles and troubles of existence, he it is to whom we run for safety, he is the one who saves our lives, he it is who is our supreme commander. He is supremely the Great Being in all these cases, and he is therefore greater even than the Ohene.'[955] 'The various strong, or “praise,” names of Onyankopon better indicate his nature or his divine characteristics. He is Totarobonsu, that is to say, “he pours and pours, and the waters are made.” He is never dried up. Another strong name of Onyankopon Kwame is Abommubuwafre, that is to say, “he is the one who when lamentation or weeping comes upon you, you call upon.” When thus called upon, he answers you. Another strong name of Onyankopon is Nya-amane-kose, that is to say, “he is the one to whom if you report (or tell) any need or trouble, he is able to help you.” Onyankopon Kwame's further strong name is Brckyirihuade, that is to say, “he is the one who knows what is happening in his presence as well as behind his back.” He is the knower of the universe of things.' [956] 'All ancestors are children of Nyame. Ancestors pass on to their children those things required of them by the Supreme Being as his children. They stand (mediate) between their children and the Supreme Being. They show the right way in which mortal man should live so as to come to the Supreme Being. That good or right way is called conduct (obra) or good conduct (obra pa). The Ga people call it dzenba (world-coming) [Page 24] that is, way of being, or living, in this world; the way in which one makes good or behaves himself in the world.'[957] 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[958]
♠ Creator Gods ♣ present ♥ 'In three specific ways Onyankopon is Nana. First, that he is Creator; it was he who made all men, and all men are his children. He made mother and mother gave birth to you, and he is therefore your Nana. In the second place, Onyankopon is Nana because he provides all that man needs for existence; that in the farm and that in the house; that in the field and that in the water; that for conduct and that for life; all are obtained from God, and therefore he is Nana. In the third place: as our drummers know how to indicate, whether we are alive or whether we die, we depend upon Onyankopon. He protects us from all manner of troubles—national troubles, family troubles and troubles of existence, he it is to whom we run for safety, he is the one who saves our lives, he it is who is our supreme commander. He is supremely the Great Being in all these cases, and he is therefore greater even than the Ohene.'[959]
♠ Supreme Ruler Gods ♣ present ♥ 'In three specific ways Onyankopon is Nana. First, that he is Creator; it was he who made all men, and all men are his children. He made mother and mother gave birth to you, and he is therefore your Nana. In the second place, Onyankopon is Nana because he provides all that man needs for existence; that in the farm and that in the house; that in the field and that in the water; that for conduct and that for life; all are obtained from God, and therefore he is Nana. In the third place: as our drummers know how to indicate, whether we are alive or whether we die, we depend upon Onyankopon. He protects us from all manner of troubles—national troubles, family troubles and troubles of existence, he it is to whom we run for safety, he is the one who saves our lives, he it is who is our supreme commander. He is supremely the Great Being in all these cases, and he is therefore greater even than the Ohene.'[960] 'The various strong, or “praise,” names of Onyankopon better indicate his nature or his divine characteristics. He is Totarobonsu, that is to say, “he pours and pours, and the waters are made.” He is never dried up. Another strong name of Onyankopon Kwame is Abommubuwafre, that is to say, “he is the one who when lamentation or weeping comes upon you, you call upon.” When thus called upon, he answers you. Another strong name of Onyankopon is Nya-amane-kose, that is to say, “he is the one to whom if you report (or tell) any need or trouble, he is able to help you.” Onyankopon Kwame's further strong name is Brckyirihuade, that is to say, “he is the one who knows what is happening in his presence as well as behind his back.” He is the knower of the universe of things.' [961]

Supernatural Enforcement of Morality

♠ supernatural enforcement against harm ♣ inferred present ♥ Belief that morality flows from the gods in Akan religion, and widespread taboo against murder in African religions. "According to Opoku (1978), this [Akan] proverb [i.e. "God is against sin or evil"] is a clear indication that morality flows from God, and that the nature of God demands an appropriate response from His creatures. Adding to Opoku (1978), Harris and Sawyerr (1968) also refer to the Mende myth that explains the origin of sacrifice of fowls, performed when someone has offended another to illustrate God’s attitude towards morality. For Mbiti (1969), morality flows from religion. By this assertion, he argues that one should view morality as an authoritative code of conduct directly sanctioned by superhuman being (god, deities and even ancestors). The moral code that Mbiti (1969) refers to is therefore not autonomous, but its autonomy is derived from the creator god. Any breach of the moral code would accordingly be an offence against god and his instruction. Mbiti (1969) points out that there is in existence and operation numerous taboos and prohibitions in African societies which Ghana is of no exemption. These taboos and prohibitions, which have their source from religion according to Mbiti, are instituted to shape the moral lives of the people belonging to that society. Taboos and prohibitions such as, stealing, pre-marital sex, murder, incest, having sexual intercourse in the bush, adultery and suicide were viewed with serious concerns and offenders were seriously punished not by man as such, but predominantly by the gods and the ancestral spirits. By this, the divine (gods and ancestors) inflict drought, infertility and sicknesses on the life of the offender and the entire society."[962] The following is also worth noting, especially as it related specifically to this NGA: 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[963]
♠ supernatural enforcement of human reciprocity ♣ inferred present ♥ Inferred from belief that the gods safeguarded morality and the virtuous were rewarded in the afterlife, as well as from Akan proverbs emphasising the importance of reciprocity. 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[964] Proverbs emphasising human reciprocity include: "Man is not a palm-tree that he should be complete (or, self sufficient). (onipa nye abe na ne ho ahyia ne ho)", "The right arm washes the left arm and the left arm washes the right arm. (wo nsa nifa hohorow benkum, na benkum nso hohorow nifa)" and "Life is mutual aid. (Obra ye nnoboa)"[965]
♠ supernatural enforcement of fairness ♣ inferred present ♥ Inferred from belief that the gods safeguarded morality and the virtuous were rewarded in the afterlife, as well as from Akan proverbs emphasising the importance of reciprocity--which may be reasonably argued to include the equitable sharing of resources. 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[966] Proverbs emphasising human reciprocity include: "Man is not a palm-tree that he should be complete (or, self sufficient). (onipa nye abe na ne ho ahyia ne ho)", "The right arm washes the left arm and the left arm washes the right arm. (wo nsa nifa hohorow benkum, na benkum nso hohorow nifa)" and "Life is mutual aid. (Obra ye nnoboa)"[967]
♠ supernatural enforcement of property rights ♣ inferred present ♥ Belief that morality flows from the gods in Akan religion, and widespread taboo against theft in African religions. "According to Opoku (1978), this [Akan] proverb [i.e. "God is against sin or evil"] is a clear indication that morality flows from God, and that the nature of God demands an appropriate response from His creatures. Adding to Opoku (1978), Harris and Sawyerr (1968) also refer to the Mende myth that explains the origin of sacrifice of fowls, performed when someone has offended another to illustrate God’s attitude towards morality. For Mbiti (1969), morality flows from religion. By this assertion, he argues that one should view morality as an authoritative code of conduct directly sanctioned by superhuman being (god, deities and even ancestors). The moral code that Mbiti (1969) refers to is therefore not autonomous, but its autonomy is derived from the creator god. Any breach of the moral code would accordingly be an offence against god and his instruction. Mbiti (1969) points out that there is in existence and operation numerous taboos and prohibitions in African societies which Ghana is of no exemption. These taboos and prohibitions, which have their source from religion according to Mbiti, are instituted to shape the moral lives of the people belonging to that society. Taboos and prohibitions such as, stealing, pre-marital sex, murder, incest, having sexual intercourse in the bush, adultery and suicide were viewed with serious concerns and offenders were seriously punished not by man as such, but predominantly by the gods and the ancestral spirits. By this, the divine (gods and ancestors) inflict drought, infertility and sicknesses on the life of the offender and the entire society."[968] The following is also worth noting, especially as it related specifically to this NGA: 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[969] The following is also relevant, but does not clearly demonstrate any kind of supernatural enforcement of property rights. Ancestral spirits were thought to be the real owners of clan lands: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. … Abandoned land reverted to the stool.’ Matrilineages held and transmitted land and also acted as corporate groups in other contexts: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]'[970] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]'[971] This suggests some degree of supernatural enforcement.
♠ supernatural enforcement of kinship obligations ♣ inferred present ♥ Inferred from two things. First, the Akan belief that the gods safeguard morality and the virtuous are rewarded in the afterlife: 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[972] Second, the fact that, among the Akan, "lineage identities and kinship groupings are the locis of sets of rights and obligations."[973] From these two things, it seems reasonable to infer that one could be rewarded in the afterlife for, among other things, honouring kinship obligations. The following is also relevant, though it does not clearly demonstrate any kind of supernatural enforcement of kinship obligations. For most people, the in-group probably coincided with the matriclan. Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups. Matrilineages held and transmitted land and also acted as corporate groups in other contexts: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]'[974] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]'[975]
♠ supernatural enforcement of in-group loyalty ♣ inferred present ♥ Inferred from belief that the gods safeguarded morality and the virtuous were rewarded in the afterlife, as well as from Akan proverbs emphasising the importance of reciprocity--which may be reasonably argued to include the equitable sharing of resources. 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[976] Proverbs emphasising human reciprocity include: "Man is not a palm-tree that he should be complete (or, self sufficient). (onipa nye abe na ne ho ahyia ne ho)", "The right arm washes the left arm and the left arm washes the right arm. (wo nsa nifa hohorow benkum, na benkum nso hohorow nifa)" and "Life is mutual aid. (Obra ye nnoboa)", where nnoboa specifically means "helping each other work on the farm."[977] The following is also relevant, but does not clearly demonstrate any kind of supernatural enforcement of in-group loyalty. For most people, the in-group probably coincided with the matriclan. Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups. Matrilineages held and transmitted land and also acted as corporate groups in other contexts: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]'[978] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]'[979]
♠ supernatural enforcement of respect ♣ inferred present ♥ Inferred from two things. First, the Akan belief that the gods safeguard morality and the virtuous are rewarded in the afterlife: 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[980] Second, the fact that, among the Akan, respect for elders is an important cultural value, though elders are more likely to be respected if they have had "successful" lives.[981] The following is also relevant, though it does not clearly demonstrate any kind of supernatural enforcement of respect. Seniority was important. It appears that social stratification accelerated during the Ashanti period and largely relied on unfree labour. New formal titles were created, which were subject to wealth payments and ceremonial initiations. According to some sources, obedience to authority was valued. Insulting or attacking the Asantehene or his officials was a capital offence. The stools of ancestral chiefs retained ceremonial importance: 'The [unavailable]manhene and his elders, through the Barimhene purify the soul of King Ameyaw (the chief defeated by the Asante in 1723), adorn his grave with the royal regalia of the incumbent [unavailable]manhene, recall the deeds that Ameyaw performed for the State ([unavailable]man), and present drinks, sheep, and food to his soul and those of the other ancestral chiefs of the Techiman-Bono State.'[982]
♠ supernatural enforcement of bravery ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We have found no information on supernatural enforcement of bravery specifically. More material is needed. However, it is worth noting that broad supernatural enforcement of morality was present: 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[983] The following is also relevant, but does not clearly demonstrate any kind of supernatural enforcement of bravery. 'Bravery, determination, courage and skill in war were emulated by the Akan, and the Ancestor who had these earned a tribute in the dirges of the lineage. Apeanin Kwaforo Amoa's exploits are alluded to: Atakora of Mamp[unavailable]n is represented as a person full of determination; and Hwerebe Akwaa is a notable Ancestress because, although a woman, she took to arms when the occasion demanded it.' [984] 'Then comes the special class of chiefs known as the Abirempong. In former times, these were ordinary chiefs but bravery in war led to their being elevated to a new status as warlords. After elevation, an Obirempong had to swear an oath of allegiance to the Asantehene. This time, stressing his willingness to serve during war.' [985]
♠ supernatural enforcement of purity ♣ inferred present ♥ Belief that morality flows from the gods in Akan religion, and widespread taboo against sexual transgression in African religions. "According to Opoku (1978), this [Akan] proverb [i.e. "God is against sin or evil"] is a clear indication that morality flows from God, and that the nature of God demands an appropriate response from His creatures. Adding to Opoku (1978), Harris and Sawyerr (1968) also refer to the Mende myth that explains the origin of sacrifice of fowls, performed when someone has offended another to illustrate God’s attitude towards morality. For Mbiti (1969), morality flows from religion. By this assertion, he argues that one should view morality as an authoritative code of conduct directly sanctioned by superhuman being (god, deities and even ancestors). The moral code that Mbiti (1969) refers to is therefore not autonomous, but its autonomy is derived from the creator god. Any breach of the moral code would accordingly be an offence against god and his instruction. Mbiti (1969) points out that there is in existence and operation numerous taboos and prohibitions in African societies which Ghana is of no exemption. These taboos and prohibitions, which have their source from religion according to Mbiti, are instituted to shape the moral lives of the people belonging to that society. Taboos and prohibitions such as, stealing, pre-marital sex, murder, incest, having sexual intercourse in the bush, adultery and suicide were viewed with serious concerns and offenders were seriously punished not by man as such, but predominantly by the gods and the ancestral spirits. By this, the divine (gods and ancestors) inflict drought, infertility and sicknesses on the life of the offender and the entire society."[986] The following is also worth noting, especially as it related specifically to this NGA: 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[987]
♠ general supernatural enforcement of morality ♣ present ♥ Menstruation was considered unclean, and contact with a menstruating woman made a man vulnerable to "evil powers". 'In the belief system of the Asante, blood (mogya) was the vital force which, transmitted from generation to generation, bound the living and the ancestors together in a web of kinship (abusua). The shedding of blood was therefore seen as fundamentally antithetical to the natural order and was regulated by the Seventy-Seven Laws of Okomfo Anokye. Putting criminals to death and the slaying of persons to accompany the dead in the next world were sanctioned, but had to be carried out by the highly trained and ritually prepared adumfo or public executioners. The same Laws addressed the matter of menstrual blood. Menstruating women were forbidden from entering any regular dwelling house and were provided with special buildings for the duration. They were not allowed to swear an oath, to address any servant of the king (ahenkwaa) or any priest ([unavailable]komfo), or to have sexual intercourse. Pollution was the issue. “Even by indirect contact,” Rattray wrote in 1927, 'an unclean woman is capable of breaking down all barriers which stand between defenceless man and those evil unseen powers which beset him on every side. These protective powers once thus rendered inactive, have to be “recharged”, as it were, by propitiation, extirpation, and augmentation rites, to placate them and build them up anew.' [988]
♠ other supernatural enforcement ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We have found no information on supernatural enforcement of piety specifically. More material is needed. However, it is worth noting that broad supernatural enforcement of morality was present: 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[989]

Human Enforcement of Morality

♠ care/harm ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We have found no information on care/harm and fairness/cheating norms. More material is needed.
♠ fairness/cheating ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We have found no information on care/harm and fairness/cheating norms. More material is needed.
♠ in-group loyalty ♣ present ♥ For most people, the in-group probably coincided with the matriclan. Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [990] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [991] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [992] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [993] Matrilineages held and transmitted land and also acted as corporate groups in other contexts: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]' [994] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]' [995] Maternal relatives were entitled to heritable lineage property: 'Despite being jurally matrilineal, inheritance is to some extent divided between sister's children and a man's own children. The basic principle is that lineage-inherited property goes to sisters' children, and property acquired with the help of a man's wife and children is distributed among the latter at his death. [MG]' [996] Individuals were expected to value kin over affines: 'Giving precedence to husbands over kin was actually considered morally wrong and selfish. The ideal model for exchanges between spouses is short-term reciprocity, which is closely monitored by both sets of relatives as well as the spouses themselves (Abu 1983). Marriage serves personal preference, convenience, and pleasure rather than family interest, except in the cases of elite marriages of alliance. For Asantes marriage is structurally optional in a way that motherhood and fatherhood are not, so they talked of it as an individual, idiosyncratic relationship without an absolute moral mandate. Teenagers and young adults under thirty or forty are expected to devote their primary attention to courtship and marriage as part of enjoying a pleasurable stage of life without substantial family responsibility. Mature adults, either men or women, who continue to put a high priority on sexual or marital affairs were described to me by traders as immature, self-indulgent, and frivolous, and they often used sexual insults in such descriptions.' [997] Chiefs from related lineages formed close political ties with each other: 'Members of a clan are not a political unit, but are spread over all the Divisions or States of Ashanti in separate lineages, yet the clan has political significance in that chiefs of the same clan treat one another with special cordiality and tend to draw together. There is, for example, a close bond between the chiefs of Kumasi, Juaben, Kokofu, and Bekwai, who are members of the Oyoko clan. They treat one another as brothers, of whom the Asantehene is the senior brother. There is a similar bond between chiefs of the Bretuo clan, of whom the Mamponghene is the senior brother. Every chief belongs to one or other of the seven major clans of Ashanti. The ties of clanship helped to strengthen the Ashanti Union.' [998]
♠ respect for authority ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups rather than castes: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [999] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [1,000] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [1,001] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [1,002] Seniority was important: 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]' [1,003] Wealth stratification was present: 'The Portuguese “blueprint” of 1572 associates gold mining, forest clearing, and food production, and implicitly postulates the existence [Page 96] of an appropriating class and a producing class. It is, I suggest, mutatis mutandis, a paradigm of sorts for the early Akan state. Those who controlled the production and sale of gold were those able to procure a supply of unfree labor. Those who procured unfree labor were those able to create arable land within the forest. Those who created the arable were those who founded the numerous early Akan polities. We see, in other words, a class of Akan entrepreneurs emerging: a class of those able to use the strength of the world bullion market, and the availability of labor locally (whether through Wangara or Portuguese suppliers), in such a way as to create the new agrarian system. These entrepreneurs were known as the aberemp[unavailable]n (sing. [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n), literally “big men” but correctly glossed in an early European source as “a superior rich man.” ' [1,004] 'Akan village histories make frequent reference to hunters ranging the forest in search of land suitable for agricultural exploitation—taking account, presumably, of surface relief, water resources, soil, and so forth. The role of the aberemp[unavailable]n in these explorations is often described in considerable detail. By way of illustration I shall cite the cases of two, Tabiri Heman and Akuamoa Panin.' [1,005] 'The descendants of free settlers became [unavailable]manmufo, citizens. Those of the proprietors became adehyeε, nobility. There remain the unfree laborers. They must surely be those who became the third major element in the composition of an [unavailable]man, namely the gyaasefo. Literally “the people of the hearth,” they were absorbed into Akan society as servants of the adehyeε. They became responsible not only for their own subsistence but for that of the nobles. They farmed for them, assumed responsibility for their debts, and provided them with a wide range of personal services as stool-carriers, drummers, hornblowers, umbrella-carriers, bathroom attendants, messengers, tradesmen, sextons, and so forth. Their masters (or mistresses) were heirs to their property. Their status, unlike that of nobles and citizens, was transmitted through the male line. Rattray commented on the matter: [Page 100] 'There is little doubt that the Gyasefo were in olden times recruited from the slave class. A “Stool” slave became one of the Gyasefo. The descendants of a Gyase woman were of course considered as Gyasefo, down the female line for all time; not only was this so, but the son of a Gyase man would ordinarily also enter the office to which his father belonged, irrespective of the position of his mother.' [1,006] 'It is virtually impossible to render such terms as adehyeε, [unavailable]manmufo and gyaasefo into English with the appropriate nuances. Adehyeε may preside over the affairs of anything from villages on the one hand to kingdoms on the other. Their power will rest in no small measure upon the sheer numbers of gyaasefo whose services they command; indeed, this is one index of their rank. In 1936 Oheneba Sakyi Djan manfully struggled with the problem, though with reference to the more southerly forest Akan: 'The term “Gyaase”…applies to the most immediate adherents attached to the household of any important personage. In this instance, even an ordinary well-to-do man (rich man) may have his own Gyaase, so much so that the head of a family (Opanyin or Atrankonnua) or a ruler of a town (Odekro), or a head of a division of a state (Ohene) or the supreme head or king of a state (Omanhene) should necessarily have his own Gyaase-men, and the number of the members constituting the Gyaase of each of the above heads depends on the importance of the party concerned. That is to say, the number of the members of the Gyaase attached to the Ohene's household is by far fewer than that attached to the Omanhene household.' It was all to do with achievement. The fortunes of an [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n depended first on his ability to procure the labor that, the estate established, became his gyaasefo, and second on his ability to attract free settlers to the estate. Measured in these terms the relatively unsuccessful [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n emerged as no more than a village head, an [unavailable]dekuro, and was absorbed in time into the aman (qua state) of his more successful peer, the [unavailable]hene of this or that group of towns and villages, and he in turn into the aman (qua kingdom) of those even more successful. We turn to a consideration of the most successful of all.' [1,007] It appears that social stratification accelerated during the Ashanti period and largely relied on unfree labour: 'ON THE BASIS OF HIS observations of Kumase society in 1817, Bowdich became strongly aware of the degree of social stratification present. Of the many indicators of this—housing, diet, hygiene, toiletry, marriage, and so forth —he commented most fully on matters of the household economy:[Page 140] 'the higher class could not support their numerous followers, or the lower their large families, in the city, and therefore employed them in plantations (in which small crooms [villages] were situated) generally within two or three miles of the capital, where their labours not only feed themselves, but supply the wants of the chief, his family, and more immediate suite. The middling orders station their slaves for the same purpose, and also to collect fruit and vegetables for sale, and when their children become numerous, a part are generally sent to be supported by these slaves in the bush.' [1,008] 'Bowdich's “higher class” would appear to refer to the wealthy citizens, high officeholders for the most part, whose gyaasefo or “retainers” supported them; his “middling orders” to aspirant citizens in the process of creating, through utilization of slaves, their own gyaasefo; and his “lower class” to those who perforce ensured their survival by the use of family labor. If Bowdich may be understood to be suggesting that the commanding morality of metropolitan society was one of upward mobility based on wealth, then he was undoubtedly correct. Had Bowdich remained in Kumase a few months longer, he would have observed that upward mobility was an institutionalized process.' [1,009] New formal titles were created for individuals who had accumulated wealth: 'Those who attained wealth in Asante were known as the sikafo, “the monied people.” This category subsumed the smaller group of those who acquired fortunes sufficiently substantial for them to seek formal recognition of their achievement. Of these, those able to demonstrate that they had acquired through their own enterprise a modest fortune of 125 peredwans might, with the approval of the Asantehene, obtain the entitlement of wearing in public a specially designed and woven cloth known as nyaw[unavailable]ho, “you have become rich.” It would seem that it was after the acquisition of such a resource in gold dust that the aspirant (and wise) citizen would begin to invest in people and land. The title to be acquired thereby was that of asafohene, an ancient one originally and exclusively meaning “a war captain.” But the title was available at different levels depending upon the number of subjects acquired.
